Date:  Mon, 01 Jan 2007 19:15:36 -0000
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Comet 4P Faye January 1, 2007 0154UT
I brought in the New Year by imaging comet 4P Faye

Comet 4P Faye January 1, 2007 0154UT

http://bellsouthpwp2.net/c/h/charbell/4P-01012007-0154UT.jpg

There was bright moon light interfering, so I cropped the image down.

Charles Bell
H47 Vicksburg 

Date:  Tue, 02 Jan 2007 02:06:16 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  C/2006 P1 - 01/01/2006
Hello.
There was about a 4 minute window between too light and loss below
the horizion. Info is on the image. I tried many kinds of
combinations to show as much information as possible but this is a
tough one.

i think ccd will bring out more details. i observed P1 last evening
the lrgb image was only 11x0,1 sec filter clear
and rgb each 0,1 sec. the tail is nearly 0,5° long.

i post it in a few minutes.

Date:  Thu, 04 Jan 2007 02:32:29 -0000
From:  Terry Lovejoy 
Subject:  Re: C/2006 P1 - 01/02/2006
--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Holloway"
wrote:
>
> That is nice. This comet will take some inventive photography to
> capture this object and the DSLR's may be the way.

I think DSLR's can really do good work in deep twilight with these
shorter exposures as there is little latency between images (readout is
virtually instantaneous). This allows you to acquire many images in a
short time, improving signal to noise. I am hoping to image the comet
in daylight this way :).

Terry 

Date:  Thu, 04 Jan 2007 07:49:18 +0100
From:  ligustri rolando

Rolando

From:  schmidtcamera2500

thank you rolando and terry

for this images i drove yesterday 5 hours by car to the south of
austria. in the northern part we had bad wheather.

i think dslr will be useful for this comet. but when the comet is
very low you need a red sensitive chip/cmos for best results.

michael

Date:  Fri, 05 Jan 2007 12:18:43 -0000
From:  Burkhard Leitner 
Subject:  C/2006 P1 (McNaught) with DSLR (Widefield)
Hello!

This morning I got my first images (and observation) of C/2006 P1
(McNaught).

HereÂ´s a widefield-image with Canon DSLR and 100mm Telelens:
http://www.kometarium.com/images/2006p1_0501_100mm.jpg

It is already very bright (around 1.5mag)- could easily be seen in
8x30, should also be visible naked eye by now.

Burkhard Leitner

Date:  Sun, 07 Jan 2007 21:22:31 +0100
From:  Stefan Beck 
Subject:  C/2006 P1 (McNaught)
Hi list,

I could image the comet today evening with my Canon EOS 300D and 135mm
lens. I didn't made any imageprocessing.

At 16.20 UT I could see the comet with the naked eye.

http://www.cometchaser.de/comets/McNaught2006P1_07012007.html

--
Regards,

Stefan Beck

http://www.cometchaser.de
"Astrophotography with small telescopes"

http://www.cometchaser.de/d_index.html
"Astrophotography with small telescopes auf Deutsch"

http://www.frappr.com/cometobservers
"All comet observers of the world"

Date:  Mon, 08 Jan 2007 00:12:15 -0000
From:  Chris Cook 
Subject:  Comet McNaught from New England
Hi list,

I don't post here very often but I wanted to share this image of Comet
McNaught taken earlier this evening at 5pm EST.

http://www.abmedia.com/astro/current/comet-mcnaught-010707.html

Alan Dyer reports a mag of -1.0. Anyone else able to confirm this?
It was a beuty in 10x50's. I first picked it up around 4:45pm EST
about 5 degrees above the horizon.

Chris 

Date:  Mon, 08 Jan 2007 02:16:12 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  C/2006 P1 - 01/07/2007
Hello. Took a lot of information and then found my flats were no
good. Hope to post cleaner images tomorrow and color. This image
shows the comet bin 1x1 and a shot as the comet was going down below a
distant hill bin 2x2.
Thanks, Mike H.
http://fototime.com/422783E8271492A/orig.jpg 

Date:  Mon, 08 Jan 2007 08:16:26 -0000
From:  Chris Cook 
Subject:  McNaught split nucleus?
I've been discussing the high res crop of my image offline and there
seems to be two different nucleus. Here is an image showing the
possible split. If you take the RGB channels, the split really becomes
apparent in the G & B.

http://www.abmedia.com/astro/current/comet-mcnaught-010707.html

Anyone else notice this?

Chris 

Date:  Mon, 08 Jan 2007 10:25:50 -0000
From:  schmidtcamera2500 
Subject:  Re: McNaught split nucleus?
Hi chris

on some ccd-images (jan 3, 5, 7, f-540mm, o,1-0,3 seconds) i saw this
double nucleus too. but i think it is a athomsperic appearance,
cause i saw this only when comet was near horizon.

mj

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Chris Cook" wrote:

becomes
> apparent in the G & B.

Date:  Mon, 08 Jan 2007 10:58:51 -0000
From:  Terry Lovejoy 
Subject:  C/2006 P1 - Daylight Image Jan 8.103
I was again able to image the comet's coma (and now also the start of
the tail) just after local noon today despite hazier conditions. 54 x
0.0008 sec exposures yielded this result:

http://www.pbase.com/terrylovejoy/image/72783444

Brightness is conservatively -0.5 from direct comparisions with Venus.

Sorry its not as impressive as the images from the north hemisphere,
but the conditions weren't exactly ideal!

Terry 

Date:  Mon, 08 Jan 2007 12:36:50 -0000
From:  Martin Mobberley 
Subject:  2006 P1 from Suffolk, UK. Jan 8th.
Dear Group,

I managed my first (and probably only) sight of 2006 P1 McNaught
from Suffolk, UK this morning. The weather has been dismal and
the forecast for the next few days is just as bad. I have posted
a picture at the top of my comet page.

http://uk.geocities.com/martinmobberley/Comets.html

The actual image lives here:

http://uk.geocities.com/martin.mobberley@btinternet.com/2006P1_20070108_mpm.jpg

Comet 2 degrees altitude; Sun -8 degrees. 300mm lens. 0.8 secs.

Regards,
Martin Mobberley

Date:  Mon, 08 Jan 2007 10:29:01 -0500
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  we saw comet McNaught after sunset

I looked Sunday morning to find the comet.
Took some photos but could not see it definitely with my naked eyes or the photos (I have no binocuulars).

After getting home I realized through the reports that the comet can be seen after sunset as well as in the morning. I looked up with my Starry Night Pro and found this was true.

I rendezvouzed with a Doug Zubenel and another member David Young showed up after my alterts went out.

Doug Zubenel and I set up above a ridge looking West near 95th street west
of a Church building in Shawnee, KS, USA (West of Kansas City).

Looking in binoculars and Doug's telescope , David Young spotted the comet first
with his binocularabout 5:30. We then saw the comet with Doug's scope about 9
degrees above horizon.
Spectacular !
I think it looked like a light gold colored star like space shuttle
trailing a yellow-white fan shaped plume (that usually appears
the TV usually shows space shuttle with a telescope )

We figured it was -1. Once you know where to locate it , you can watch it for the next few nights.

We watched it for almost a half hour . Then as it went close to the tree on horizon we saw the last glimpses of it in between the distant trees.

Amazing all the comets that have appeared that did not fullfill expetations. Now this one comes out of the sky and is putting on an amazing show that may get even better.

Don't miss it.

We will try the next few days at the same spot.

Good sky chart on Sky & Telescope and a good one on Spaceweather.

Dr. Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com), Olathe, KS: Member #2572 IMCA
(International Meteorite Collectors Association) : E.O.A.S. (Earth, Oceans,
Atmosphere
and Space) Blog -:State of Kansas
Solar System Ambassador: Comet Observers Coordinator- Astronomy League/
Astronomical Society of Kansas, KC, MO-Louisburg,KS:
http://www.astroleague.org/al/obsclubs/comet/comet.htm: CometObserversAwardALsubscribe@yahoogroups.com

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Mon, 08 Jan 2007 12:44:46 -0600
From:  Bob King 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] McNaught split nucleus?
Hi Chris,
I just looked at my digital images of the comet this morning and I have
exactly the same affect recorded on some of the frames. About 1/3 of what I
shot is nice and steady and the rest are slightly blurred with
double "nuclei" present either from the wind or vibrations transmitted by my
hand when I released the shutter. In a couple, the images are identical to
yours while in a few others, the "split" is visible down the comet's tail.
In the telescope, even though seeing was not great, there was no question I
was looking at one nucleus. My observations were made on Jan. 8, 13:05 UT.
Best regards,
Bob King
Duluth, MN USA

On 1/8/07, Chris Cook wrote:
>
> I've been discussing the high res crop of my image offline and there
> seems to be two different nucleus. Here is an image showing the
> possible split. If you take the RGB channels, the split really becomes
> apparent in the G & B.
>
> http://www.abmedia.com/astro/current/comet-mcnaught-010707.html
>
> Anyone else notice this?
>
> Chris
>

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Date:  Mon, 08 Jan 2007 22:21:01 -0000
From:  Chris Cook 
Subject:  Re: McNaught split nucleus?
Hi Bob,

I think we're seeing the effects of some sort of mirror slap
vibration in the cameras. I was so convinced there was a double
nucleus but visual observations by numerous people do not confirm
this. I tripped my shutter by a cable release but did not lock up
the mirror. Next time, I'll use the old hat trick to reduce any
chance of vibrations.

Glad you got some shots of it!

Regards,

Chris

Date:  Mon, 08 Jan 2007 14:14:33 -0600
From:  Gary Kronk 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] McNaught split nucleus?
I imaged the comet on January 6 through my 20-cm SCT using the
MallinCam video camera. Both the daylight and twilight observations
revealed only one nucleus. I did not use my Canon Digital Rebel for
these images; however, I have a couple of images of C/2004 F4
(Bradfield) taken with one of my Minolta film cameras and a few
images of C/2006 M4 (SWAN) taken with my Digital Rebel which show a
"double nucleus" as a result of vibration.

Sincerely,
Gary

>Hi Chris,
>I just looked at my digital images of the comet this morning and I have
>exactly the same affect recorded on some of the frames. About 1/3 of what I
>shot is nice and steady and the rest are slightly blurred with

Date:  Tue, 09 Jan 2007 03:45:19 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  C/2006 P1 - 01/08/2007-Color
Hello. I took the RGB information and after new flats/darks combined
the info. Looked at the image and except for a crop, just left it the
way it was with no other processing.
Thanks, Mike H.
http://fototime.com/96AAE52E8A3811D/orig.jpg 

Date:  Tue, 09 Jan 2007 09:54:04 +0100
From:  Bernd Brinkmann 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: McNaught split nucleus?
Hello all,

> I think we're seeing the effects of some sort of mirror slap
> vibration in the cameras. I was so convinced there was a double
> nucleus but visual observations by numerous people do not confirm
> this. I tripped my shutter by a cable release but did not lock up
> the mirror. Next time, I'll use the old hat trick to reduce any
> chance of vibrations.

there could be another explenation: differential refraction. I'm seeing this effect
when imaging planets with a webcam up to 30 deg elevation. I have to adjust the
blue and red channels to merge with the green one to avoid coloured rims.

Clear skies
Bernd

Bernd Brinkmann

Sternwarte Herne, MPC code A18
Herne, Germany

e-mail: info@sternwarte-herne.de
http://www.sternwarte-herne.de

Greetings. This is a RGBL combination. The Sunset is to the lower
left and the Lum. image had a tree top which I thought broke the image
up a little. Looking forward to a comet which sits in a dark sky
again. 660mm TV 127is refractor and ST10XMEI ccd with .02 sec images.

Date:  Wed, 10 Jan 2007 01:32:50 -0000
From:  Chris Cook 
Subject:  McNaught from Massachusetts
Hi list,

I had much better conditions this evening for imaging the comet. I
picked it up around 4:45pm EST in 10x50's. It became a easy naked
eye target around 5:10pm and was truly spectacular in 10x50's.
Because of atmospheric extinction, the comet was a gorgeous golden
color with a tail visible for about 1.5° in length.

I used the Stellarvue SV80S triplet refractor @ f/6 with the 20D.
Considering how low this sucker is, around 4°, I'm quite pleased with
these shots. Imagine if this comet was visible high up in a dark
sky!! It's hard to estimate the magnitude but I'd put it around -1.0

http://www.abmedia.com/astro/current/comet-mcnaught1-010907.html

http://www.abmedia.com/astro/current/comet-mcnaught2-010907.html

http://www.abmedia.com/astro/current/comet-mcnaught3-010907.html

Thanks for looking.

Chris 

Date:  Wed, 10 Jan 2007 17:20:34 +1300
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Comet McNaught observed and photographed during the daytime from New Zealand
Hi all,

I visually observed and photographed Comet McNaught during the daytime today from New Zealand. It's a goal that's finally been achieved! (to see a comet during the daytime). It was bright enough to be seen not only with the bright Sun 14 degrees away but also to be seen through passing light cloud!!!

CometObs - ( http://groups.yahoo.com/group/CometObs/ )
C/2006 P1 (McNaught) 2007 January 10.06 UT: m1 = ~ -1.5, Dia.= ~2'.0, DC = 6, 41cm f4.5 Reflect (83x)...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [Saw McMaught during the daytime! (2:30pm local time). Quite easy to see in the 16". Has a tight, stellar nucleus and seems to be surrounded by a 'faint' small coma. Closest visible star for a mag comparison was the SUN!!! No tail seen. 57˚ alt in the NW (the Sun was 12˚ to the south). Stellar LM = ~3 near comet (scope), rural sky]. Photo taken…

Charles Morris's, 'The New Comet Observations Page' ( http://cometobservation.com/ )
2007 Jan 10.06 UT: m1=~-1.5, Dia.=~2', DC=6, Tail: none seen...41cm f4.5 Reflect (83x)...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [Saw McMaught during the daytime! (2:30pm local time). Quite easy to see in the 16". Has a tight, stellar nucleus and seems to be surrounded by a 'faint' small coma. Closest visible star for a mag comparison was the SUN!!! No tail seen. 57˚ alt in the NW (the Sun was 12˚ to the south). Stellar LM = ~3 near comet (scope), rural sky]. Photo taken…

ICQ (International Comet Quarterly) ( http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iau/icq/CometMags.html )
Jan 10.06, ~-1.5, 2', (John Drummond, Gisborne, New Zealand, 16" Newtonian

Daytime images of C/2006 P1 can be seen at:
http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet_mcnaught-c-2006p1-during_daytime-85x1-2000sec-060109ut-41cm_f4,5-john_drummond-nz-web.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/yxxgob

A closer view using added stacking can be seen below. Is it my eyes or do I see a VERY FAINT tail pointing down at about 7 O'clock? Am I crazy or what?
http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet_mcnaught-c-2006p1-during_daytime-20x1-2000sec-060109ut-41cm_f4,5-john_drummond-nz-add-tail-crop.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/tc4sb

A webpage with these images and other info can be seen at:
http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet_2006p1-mcnaught.htm
or
http://tinyurl.com/tqo9s

Cheers

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 177° 53', S 38° 37'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

Date:  Wed, 10 Jan 2007 18:39:03 +0000
From:  Simon Banton 
Subject:  Comet 2006 P1 McNaught from Wiltshire, UK, 10th Jan 2007
Hi,

Nice clear skies at sunset this evening for the first time in almost
a week, and I managed to snap the following with a Kodak DX6490, ISO
80, 0.7s @ f3.7 at 10x zoom from 3 miles north of Stonehenge in
Wiltshire, UK at 17:18 UT

http://community.novacaster.com/attach.pl/6044/420/100_6166.jpg

I'm very happy to have managed to get a good view of it at last!

Regards
Simon

Date:  Wed, 10 Jan 2007 22:29:15 +0100
From:  "H.Luethen" 
Subject:  P1 above the port of  Hamburg, Germany
After a period of warm and moist weather I finally had a chance to see
comet McNaught in a narrow gap in the clouds on Jan. 8, 16:29 UT. I also
got an image using a modded Canon 350D and a 135mm f/2.8 lens, 2 seconds
of exposure, 100 ISO:

http://home.tiscali.de/astrohardy/neat/mcn.jpg

Here is a crop:
http://home.tiscali.de/astrohardy/neat/mcn_crop.jpg

Hartwig Luethen

Date:  Wed, 10 Jan 2007 16:13:40 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: C/2006 P1 (McNaught) over city
Not just another pretty picture; this and other images being posted are positive
indicators that this is a very bright comet, contrary to words being written that this
comet should not be compared to "Cometxx" or that formulae "suggest" that the comet
cannot be brightening as it truly is.

Without a doubt, a "picture is worth a thousand words...." And these are textbook
quality.

Dr. Clay
-------------
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/

Hello,

a file has been uploaded to the Files area of the Comet-Images
group.

File : /2006P1200701-10LRGBnew2cml.jpg

You can access this file at the URL:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/2006P1200701-10LRGBnew2cml.jpg

Date:  Thu, 11 Jan 2007 03:24:14 +0100
From:  Danilo Pivato 
Subject:  C/2006 P1 of 2007/01/10
Hi all,

here's available a one shot of the Comet McNaught.
Instruments: Nikon D70s 400ISO with telelens: Nikon 300/2,8 ED IF
Exposure 1/4 seconds f/5,6
Site: Monte Campominio (1855m) Italy
Clear skies

Danilo Pivato

Date:  Fri, 12 Jan 2007 04:37:54 -0000
From:  Chris Cook 
Subject:  Evening splendor
Here's a shot from this evening. I used a Stellarvue SV80S triplet
refractor to get in close to this beauty. Weather was ideal with no
wind and clear skies. This will most likely be my last image of this
amazing comet. Weather is suppose to turn poor tomorrow and she's
diving into the glare of the Sun.

I'm not a expert on estimating the magnitude of comets, but I do know
it was much brighter this evening compared to yesterday. I picked it
up with my eye only seven minutes after sunset! Taking atmospheric
extinction into account, I'd put the mag at -3.0. I'll be interested to
see what the experts say.

http://www.abmedia.com/astro/current/comet-mcnaught-011107.html

Enjoy.

Chris

Date:  Sat, 13 Jan 2007 05:24:56 -0000
From:  Dave Kodama 
Subject:  McNaught from southern California
The view from southern California:

http://www.eanet.com/kodama/astro/2007/0112/

Due to the very low position for us and recent bad weather, I had
difficulty picking up the comet until this evening, though once I had
spotted it (with binos), I could see it naked eye. It may be bright
on an absolute scale, but because of the poor contrast it was a bit of
an underwhelming sight. :( I hope it performs well for those in the
southern hemisphere.

By the way, one of the better shots taken by one of our club's members
was shot from a commercial flight over Greenland!

http://www.ocastronomers.org/astroimages/album.asp?ID=4416

Dave Kodama 

Date:  Sat, 13 Jan 2007 12:22:22 -0500
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  fyi  More about Comet McNaught
I was able to videotape it and grab some videosnaps on Wednesday. They are
on my blog (below).
Hope you all could catch this magnificent comet.

More about Comet McNaught

Astronomy Picture of the Day
Nice picture of the comet after sunset
http://antwrp.gsfc.nasa.gov/apod/astropix.html
1/13/2007 (if not that date look in archives)

more about the Comet McNaught since its discovery at
http://cometography.com/lcomets/2006p1.html

see the comet now near the sun
http://www.spaceweather.com/

See the coronograph pics of the comet near the Sun
http://www.esa.int/esaCP/SEMMCRSVYVE_index_0.html
and
http://sohowww.nascom.nasa.gov/home.html

Latest SOHO image of the comet swinging by the Sun
http://sohowww.nascom.nasa.gov/data/realtime/c3/512/

http://space.com/
comet gallery 2
http://www.space.com/php/multimedia/imagegallery/igviewer.php?imgid=4559&
gid=326&index=0

Date:  Sat, 13 Jan 2007 20:35:28 -0000
From:  sunblack74 
Subject:  McNaught from Italy
Seen today 13th of Jan. from 5pm to 5.20-25 LT from the beach naked
eye and very well by a 9x63 bin. By naked eye was still visible a
trace of tail and i estimate comet less visible than Venus (about -
2.5/3mag).
Attached a pic with a Canon 5D +Sigma 170-500mm @ 500mm f/6.3, 100iso,
26 stacked frames from 1/180s to 1/15s. Cropped, stacked by Registax
and curves/levels by Paint Shop.

PS: hey, it's very little!!! Hale-Bopp was enormous if shooted at
500mm!!!

http://img371.imageshack.us/img371/3600/mcnaught13gen200726xun1we3.jpg 

Date:  Sat, 13 Jan 2007 17:26:36 -0500
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  amazing  photo of Comet McNaught in daytime
On the latest spaceweather.com

Hope you saw the comet .
more info and my pics and videoclips on my blog see below

amazing photo of Comet McNaught in daytime by others!!

***

Space Weather News for Jan. 13, 2007
http://spaceweather.com

Observers around the world are reporting that Comet McNaught is now visible
in broad daylight. The comet is very close to the sun, so it is tricky to find.
If you want to try, here's how to do it: Go outside and stand in the shadow
of a building so that the glare of the sun is blocked out.  Make a fist and
hold it at arm's length.  The comet is about one fist-width east of the sun.

This weekend is a special time for Comet McNaught because it is making its
closest approach to the sun.  Solar heat causes the comet to vaporize furiously
and brighten to daytime visibility.  McNaught is now the brightest comet in
more than 40 years, and it may become the brightest in centuries.

Visit http://spaceweather.com for photos and updates.

Dr. Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com), Olathe, KS: Member #2572 IMCA
(International Meteorite Collectors Association) : E.O.A.S. (Earth, Oceans, Atmosphere
and Space) Blog -:State of Kansas
Solar System Ambassador: Comet Observers Coordinator- Astronomy League/
Astronomical Society of Kansas, KC, MO-Louisburg,KS:
http://www.astroleague.org/al/obsclubs/comet/comet.htm: CometObserversAwardALsubscribe@yahoogroups.com - Dr.
Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com), Olathe, KS: State of Kansas Solar System

Date:  Sat, 13 Jan 2007 23:57:17 -0000
From:  Robert 
Subject:  daytime imaging of comet McNaught
Hello all,

during daytime on 13 Jan. I could obtain some images of the comet with
an 400mm/f5.6 Canon objektiv and 400D body. Exposure times are 1/2000
and 1/1000 at f8.

http://www.pbase.com/astrophoto/image/72996009
http://www.pbase.com/astrophoto/image/72996702

Times are 12h45 and 12h57 UT, 13.Jan.2007

I suspect the brightness around -5m, but could it not see with naked
eyes because of sky brightness near the sun.

In the future I could sum my images of that day (a few dozens) to get
more S/N out of it.

Robert Schulz
Austria/Europe

Date:  Sun, 14 Jan 2007 21:42:07 -0000
From:  Robert 
Subject:  Summed images of comet McNaught during daylight
Hi,

During daytime on 13 Jan. I could obtain some images of the comet with
an 400mm/f5.6 Canon tele and 400D body. Exposure times vary between
1/2000 and 1/800 at f8.
Yesterday I uploaded only two single frames. Today I worked through my
data and summed up 23 images. It results in two files- one in real RGB
and another in false color. (it brings details out better)

http://www.pbase.com/astrophoto/image/73068044/original
http://www.pbase.com/astrophoto/image/73068039/original

Times of the 23 raw images are between 12h45 and 13h06 UT, 13.Jan.2007

Today I observed the comet only for short time visually, because of
clouds. It maintained its brightness of about -5m.

Robert Schulz
Austria/Europe 

Date:  Tue, 16 Jan 2007 02:13:00 +1030
From:  belatrix 
Subject:  southern comet P1 McNaught shots :-)
Hi all, :-))))))

Grabbed a few shots as sunset tonight - both taken with wide field 50mm
f 1.4 canon 350D
First one was taken while suns disc still above horizon, enhanced
comet to stand out from background. details: 1/800 sec at f 6.3 (was in
full auto) 400 iso slightly blurry but all I have of that sequence is
out of focus slightly.

http://southern-x.org/so_x/p1/P1sun_0484.jpg

second one contains Venus in the upper right hand corner (not marked)
comet is encircled - over-processed image to highlight the two as a
maybe hazardous? comparison, possibly of Magnitudes even. At the time
nothing appeared to be obscuring view of venus, or interfere with its
brightness / normality.

http://southern-x.org/so_x/p1/p1venus_0510.jpg

Observed McNaught's comet for around 45 min this evening, from
overlooking Adelaide (suburbs) Australia - impressed :-)))))
time of sunset was around 8:30 pm this evening, local time, 10:00 UT
ish and onwards 15th Jan.

Cheers
Kearn 

Date:  Tue, 16 Jan 2007 02:18:46 +1030
From:  belatrix 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] southern comet P1 McNaught shots :-)
Forgot photo details for second shot - single shot 1/250 sec at f 3.5
iso 200 - both single shots
Cheers :-)

then I have tried to make some photos with a digicam.

Date:  Thu, 18 Jan 2007 02:23:41 +1030
From:  belatrix 
Subject:  McNaught from the 17th jan widefields
Hi All, not much in the way of tracking or close ups, yet. But these
will make nice keep sakes just the same, as they approximate the
natural vista we had, that was a bit affected by haze of various kinds,
still my third day of wonderful views looking over the suburbs again,
at last.
wonderful comet, I'm a bit worn out already thoough, lol, can you have
to much of good thing? ;) sheesh what a phenomenon! :-)))

Canon 350d/tripod 50mm f1.4 lens.

http://southern-x.org/so_x/p1/P1_17th.jpg

http://southern-x.org/so_x/p1/p1venus17th.jpg

http://southern-x.org/so_x/p1/p1solo_17th.jpg

Cheers,
Kearn Jones
Adelaide, Australia
~35 south

Date:  Wed, 17 Jan 2007 15:13:29 -0600
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Podcast on Comets
There is a very nice podcast on comets from Fraser Cain publisher of Universe Today and Dr. Pamela Gay professor from Southern Illinois University Evansville.

http://www.universetoday.com/2007/01/15/podcast-comets-our-icy-friends-from-the-outer-solar-system/

You don't have to have an iPod to listen to a podcast. Click the little button to play the episode right from your browser.

They encourage you to send in your photo images of C/2006 P1. 

Date:  Fri, 19 Jan 2007 00:44:49 +0100
From:  Juan Jose Gonzalez Suarez 
Subject:  C/2006 P1 perihelion images.
With some ( not-wanted ) delay, we've posted in the C/2006 P1
section of our site ( http://www.perihelio.org/brill2007.htm ) some Juan
Fernndez's images of the comet at perihelion, Jan. 12, taken from Monte
Naranco ( Asturias, N. Spain ).

Obviously, they are not as spectacular as recent South Hemisphere
images with a long curved tail showing synchrones ... But it was the
best that weather allow us to do from the cloudy Asturias.

Best wishes and clear skies,

Juan Fernandez + Juan Jose Gonzalez
Comets in Twilight
http://www.perihelio.org 

Date:  Fri, 19 Jan 2007 21:46:15 +0100
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  striae on comet C2006 P1
At this address I have inserted an image of this evening (17.30 TU)

http://comete.uai.it/comete/striae_C2006P1_070119.jpg

the field is 36x55 centered on Ancha Aqr.

best regards
Rolando Ligustri
===============================
C.A.R.A. http://cara.uai.it
CAST: Circolo AStrofili Talmassons
www.castfvg.it/fotoccd.htm#comete

> About the apparent size of comet McNaught's: I think that we haven't had yet the real
> "perception" of the total dimensions of its tail, since it's currently splitted in two
> hemispheres! Some friends (R. Ligustri and M. Fulle) were observing this comet few hours
> ago from northern Italy (Latitude +46 deg N), and were still able to see a magnificent
> series of striae extending well above the west horizon. In the next days it would be
> nice to put together the contributions from both sides of our planet, in order to have
> an idea about the "real" size of this monster...
> Cheers,
> Giovanni 

Date:  Sat, 20 Jan 2007 02:50:56 -0000
From:  Chris Cook 
Subject:  Synchronic bands from 42°N
I was able to capture these faint synchronic bands from Comet McNaught
earlier this evening. I read reports coming in from other areas and
thought I'd give it a try. The brighter bands were easily visible to
the naked eye. It looked like a very faint colorless aurora.

http://www.abmedia.com/astro/current/comet-mcnaught-synchronicbands.html

http://www.abmedia.com/astro/current/comet-mcnaught-synchronicbands-
1.html

Watch for link wrap...

5D, 24-70L @ f/2.8, ISO 500 or 800 and a 30 or 60 second exposure.

Thanks for lookin'.

Chris 

Date:  Sat, 20 Jan 2007 23:04:53 +0100
From:  "H.Luethen" 
Subject:  tail synchrones visible from 53 deg North
I just photographed the tail synchrones of McNaught from
Hamburg/Germany. The place is light-polluted, but the transparency was
excellent. It required quite a bit of image processing to get it done.
Briefly, I stacked 5 images (25 sek, 200 ISO, 50mm f/2.8, Canon EOS
350D) and used the blue channel. After flattening the image with
fitswork I got the following result. Not beautiful, but it's there.

I also received news from Christian Harder and Manfred Holl, who made
better images in the countryside south of Hamburg. So regardless where
you are, the comet is still a show.

http://www.gva-hamburg.de/mcnaught/synchrones.jpg

(17:14 UT, Jan 20, 2007)

Hartwig Luethen 

Date:  Sun, 21 Jan 2007 00:18:18 +0100
From:  Klaas Jobse 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] tail synchrones visible from 53 deg North
Hi Hartwig,

This evening I was also successfull in capturing this remarkable feature of
this beautiful comet.

You can find the image at:

http://www.klaas-jobse.net/cyclops/kometen/20070120_P1_striae_westkapelle.jpgIt was taken at the North-Sea coast ( 51.30 deg. N )Best Regards,Klaas JobseSubject: [Comet-Images] tail synchrones visible from 53 deg North>I just photographed the tail synchrones of McNaught from> Hamburg/Germany. The place is light-polluted, but the transparency was> excellent. It required quite a bit of image processing to get it done.> Briefly, I stacked 5 images (25 sek, 200 ISO, 50mm f/2.8, Canon EOS> 350D) and used the blue channel. After flattening the image with> fitswork I got the following result. Not beautiful, but it's there.>> I also received news from Christian Harder and Manfred Holl, who made> better images in the countryside south of Hamburg. So regardless where> you are, the comet is still a show.>> http://www.gva-hamburg.de/mcnaught/synchrones.jpg>> (17:14 UT, Jan 20, 2007)>> Hartwig Luethen>> 

Date:  Sun, 21 Jan 2007 14:10:32 +0100
From:  "H.Luethen" 
Subject:  Syncrones in color from 53.5 degs north
This morning I had a closer look on some images I took yesterday from
Hamburg, Germany. Excellent transparency, but of course taken from a
Megacity. The syncrones were also visible on these single raw images. I
did some processing to enhance them further (flattening, color
correction, contrast enhancement with Fitswork. Here is a result.

http://www.gva-hamburg.de/mcnaught/bunt.jpg

17:28 UT, Canon EOS 350D (modded), 25 seconds, 50mm f/2 lens, comet 27
degs below the horizon.

I am still trying to achieve a mosaik covering more field, but that is
difficult.

Hartwig 

Date:  Sun, 21 Jan 2007 15:33:03 -0000
From:  Pete Lawrence 
Subject:  Synchrones from 51N
A break in the clouds at last allowed me to catch some of C/2006 P1
McNaught's synchrones from a local beach in Selsey, West Sussex, UK.
The results can be seen here...

http://www.digitalsky.org.uk/comets/P1_McNaught/C2006-P1-McNaught_Jan20.html

Best regards,

Pete Lawrence
http://www.digitalsky.org.uk 

Date:  Sun, 21 Jan 2007 15:39:48 -0000
From:  Burkhard Leitner 
Subject:  C/2006 P1 striae from +47 deg latitude
Hi!

Here is my image from last evening.

http://www.kometarium.com/images/2006p1_2001_35mm.jpg

The striae were hard to detect visually, but easy on the photos (even
on the camera display).

Burkhard Leitner 

Date:  Mon, 22 Jan 2007 02:08:04 +1030
From:  William Godward 
Subject:  McNaught from South Australia
I have just photographed the comet. The comet tail was so bright i could see it through the clouds at one stage. All pictures were taken with a Canon 20D.
http://members.dodo.com.au/~godward/ObservingLog.htm

Cheers Will Godward

Moonta South Australia

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Sun, 21 Jan 2007 20:08:40 -0000
From:  amar10sharmaa 
Subject:  Re: C/2006 P1 striae from +47 deg latitude
Hello All,
It's surprising to see the striae in tails beign imaged from the
other half of hemisphere from where the comet is now visible! Looks
like the upper most faint reaches/extensions of the tail is being
imaged at the upper latitudes. But can anyone please tell the status
what will be for +13 degree latitude which is midway to both the
hemispheres? How 'good' or bright will the tail be from here? And
how long will the visibility last here? How above the horizon, the
exact direction, and what are the best times to look for it? Finally
if it needs to be photographed then what are the best exposure times
for a 28-105 mm SLR camera with ISO 400 film at lowest aperture of
f/4 to get it recorded on film? Any help will be appreciable. If
it's 'really' possible, then I'm planning to get it from here just
tomorrow. Thanking You. Amar.

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Burkhard Leitner"

wrote:
>
> Hi!
>
> Here is my image from last evening.
>
> http://www.kometarium.com/images/2006p1_2001_35mm.jpg
>
> The striae were hard to detect visually, but easy on the photos
(even
> on the camera display).
>
> Burkhard Leitner
> 

Date:  Sun, 21 Jan 2007 14:22:13 -0600
From:  Bob King 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: C/2006 P1 striae from +47 deg latitude
Hello Amar,
It's going to be difficult to see them now with the moon coming back into
the evening sky but they may still show on a camera with a time exposure. I
had good luck using ISO 800, f/2.8 and a 35mm lens with an exposure of 25-30
seconds. At f/4 you'll need to expose for about 1 minute. I think a 50mm or
shorter lens would work well.
Good luck to you and share your photos with the list if it works.
Best,
Bob

On 1/21/07, amar10sharmaa wrote:
>

Date:  Mon, 22 Jan 2007 12:20:48 +1030
From:  belatrix 
Subject:  I retract my statement :P
With the light pollution wiping out the great glow I experienced on sat
night at a dark site - she is prettier np -

this 1 sec twilight shot reminds me strongly of the naked eye view

http://southern-x.org/so_x/p1/p121twi_0789.jpg

next 4 sec exp - both with 50mm f1.4 lens, no cropping, over looking
the suburbs of Adelaide, 5 min drive from where I live, weather
surprised me by clearing up last night, for a short while anyway. :-)

http://southern-x.org/so_x/p1/P121st_0823.jpg

Kearn Jones
35 south 

Date:  Mon, 22 Jan 2007 14:11:22 -0000
From:  Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Subject:  New file uploaded to Comet-Images

Hello,

This email message is a notification to let you know that
a file has been uploaded to the Files area of the Comet-Images
group.

File : /TGCO Mulitply 4x Jan 20 2007 Small.jpg
Uploaded by : sabiajohn
Description : Comet Mc Naught tail, Four stacked film images. Kodak Max 800. Jan 20, 2007 7:00 EST.

You can access this file at the URL:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/TGCO%20Mulitply%204x%20Jan%2020%202007%20Small.jpg

To learn more about file sharing for your group, please visit:
http://help.yahoo.com/help/us/groups/files

Regards,

sabiajohn 

Date:  Tue, 23 Jan 2007 04:24:30 +1030
From:  belatrix 
Subject:  Sodium anyone?
Hi,
Had my first decent look at 2006 P1 from a dark sky site tonight (22
jan ), certainly missed the best of the 'spectacular widefield tripod
comet shot' comet, she's fading very fast, as you all know, yesterday
I could get a good image at iso 100 - today it needed to be 1600 with
the digital at a dark sky site! - yikes! many features have gone
sub-visual pretty much, or nearly anyway, wasnt nearly as prominent in
the twilight, what she must mag +1 easy i guess, is that a fading of
around a magnitude a day!!?, I think 2002 V1 was similar from memory?
P1 still covers a large part of the sky in its entirety thats for sure,
as I have seen it said 'it dominates the night sky' thats a good
description, P1 'owned' the sky!
hope some film shots turn out - not to hopeful unfortunately, anyway
what a amazing sight, glad I went out :-) thats engraved in my brain
thats for sure.

oh well, let the guiding begin! seen some good examples already, she's
a nice long duration exp. object still!

single 4 sec shot iso 1600, unprocessed except reduced for the web -
50mm f 1.4 lens uncropped

http://southern-x.org/so_x/p1/p122nd_0850s.jpg

cheers
Kearn
Adelaide, Australia
35 south (I was at 36 or so south tonight) 

Date:  Tue, 23 Jan 2007 16:52:13 -0000
From:  amar10sharmaa 
Subject:  C/2006 P1 striae from +13 deg latitude - negative
Hello Mr. Bob,
Thanks a lot for the kind advice. I went yesterday to our
dark-sky site and waited for sun to set and darkness to emerge. But
as will happen to most of them, clouds were present ONLY in the
south-western horizon, with other horizons totally clear, even
though some part of sky was clouded up. After it started getting
dark, Moon was too bright also reflecting light in the clouds, so
I didnt even want to attempt it. Maybe tomorrow when Moon's higher
up, it might be possible, but still it'll be more brighter. Looks
like the chance for our latitude of this is gone now..Is it? This
cant happen..we never got the best of the comet's visibility and now
the oppurtunity to capture the tail is also gone :(

By any chance is there some way to calculate how long this tail and
it's features will remain visible at best? Thanking You. Amar.

Date:  Wed, 24 Jan 2007 16:37:36 +1030
From:  belatrix 
Subject:  McNaught from monday night
Hi, I cant keep this to myself, on an aussie astro forum SCP (I havent
seen it elsewhere?) there is a couple of tracked longer exposure images
of P1 from dark skies on Eyre Peninsular, South Australia, Monday
evening 22nd of jan.
In particular, I love the one in message #118 from John/Asimov, check
out the perspective it gives of the fishbone tail/helix, that would
have to be now the most amazing amateur widefield image of a Great
comet in history, to my mind anyway. maybe unrepeatable? for a while
anywayz?.

http://southcelestialpole.org.au/forum/index.php?topic=2521.105

or

http://tinyurl.com/ywfx5r

cheers
Kearn 

Date:  Wed, 24 Jan 2007 08:21:24 -0600
From:  Bob King 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2006 P1 striae from +13 deg latitude - negative
Hello Amar,
I'm sorry to hear you could not see the tail. Yes, the moon really makes it
difficult now. I haven't heard of any naked eye sightings of synchrones for
the past day or two. Like you, I am hoping that after the moon is out of the
sky again, we'll have another chance at spotting the synchrones. I don't
know how long they might be visible. One observer on the list reported what
he believed were sychrones from the comet in the morning sky near
Aquila/Del. The dawn sky is still moonless so perhaps it might be a good
idea to try at that time. And if you don't see them, take photos anyway.
When I saw them last week, they were faint visually but showed up very well
in the camera.
Good luck and good observering,
Bob

Date:  Wed, 24 Jan 2007 13:59:59 -0500
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  comet tail and pics
Greetings Bellatrix and Amar and others

We had 4 marvelous days while observing the comet here in Kansas with binoculars and telescopes. I even took a video of it (my first out of 38 or so comets!!). \
While we got "the short end of the stick (so to speak)" in the Northern Hemisphere,The comet was still most exciting and marvelous to see, truly one of the best of all time.
I hope we might have a change to catch the comet tail here in Kansas City area after the clouds and snowstorms. So I echo the sentiments of those of us who still hope to try weather and moon permitting.

I hope we still have a chance.
I would be interested who else sees the tail in the next few days.

Meanwhile thanks for the website below to find those beautiful pictures by others down under. Makes us which we were there now seeing this true spectacle but I am glad we saw the lesser parts of this splendor nevertheless.

Thanks again.

PS if any one wants more information about possibly obtaining our Gold and Silver awards (certificate and pin) please contact me (must be AL member or part of a society or astro club belonging to AL which most do)

:)

Dr Eric Flescher (KCstarguy@aol.com)
Olathe, KS
Comet Observers Award Chairman, Astronomy League
Astroomical Society of Kansas City

***
1. C/2006 P1 striae from +13 deg latitude - negative
Posted by: "amar10sharmaa" amar10sharmaa@yahoo.co.in amar10sharmaa
Date: Tue Jan 23, 2007 8:59 am ((PST))

Hello Mr. Bob,
Thanks a lot for the kind advice. I went yesterday to our
dark-sky site and waited for sun to set and darkness to emerge. But
as will happen to most of them, clouds were present ONLY in the
south-western horizon, with other horizons totally clear, even
though some part of sky was clouded up. After it started getting
dark, Moon was too bright also reflecting light in the clouds, so
I didnt even want to attempt it. Maybe tomorrow when Moon's higher
up, it might be possible, but still it'll be more brighter. Looks
like the chance for our latitude of this is gone now..Is it? This
cant happen..we never got the best of the comet's visibility and now
the oppurtunity to capture the tail is also gone :(

By any chance is there some way to calculate how long this tail and
it's features will remain visible at best? Thanking You. Amar.

Date:  Fri, 26 Jan 2007 09:11:56 +1300
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Comet McNaught from New Zealand - John Drummond
Hi all,

just put together a quick webpage with photos I've recently taken of Comet McNaught. It can be see at:

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet_2006p1-mcnaught.htm
or
http://tinyurl.com/tqo9s

Cheers

Director - Royal Astronomical Society of NZ Comet and Meteor Section

Gisborne, New Zealand
E 177° 53', S 38° 37'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

Date:  Sat, 27 Jan 2007 14:23:14 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  2P Image Needed.
Was out last night for 2P. I got a good set of images of the entire
area Guide showed the comet to be but once again the clouds rolled in
and kep me from repeating a later imaging session to see movement. The
time I was out was 00:47ut 01/27/2007. I would like to post after
figuring out which is the comet. Blinked the DSS images but not sure.
If you imaged 2P last night would appreciate a link showing comet.
Mike H. 

Date:  Fri, 26 Jan 2007 13:50:40 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Re: Comet McNaught from New Zealand - John Drummond
John. Very well done. I like the head shot for perspective. (is
that you) The image done with the 11000 camera is great.
Interesting that before this comet traveled south I imaged it on the
8th and with the ST10XMEI the core area of the comet bloomed totally
out of controll with unfiltered images of only .02 seconds. In the
future if another brighter comet appears in dark skys this will be a
problem that blooming cameras will have to deal with. Hope the next
one is a northern comet as we never get any decent comets up here.
Cheers!
Mike H.

Date:  Tue, 30 Jan 2007 12:28:34 +1300
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Visual McNaught OBS and Photos-29Jan07
Hi all,

I visually observed and imaged Comet McNaught this morning...

CometObs - ( http://groups.yahoo.com/group/CometObs/ )
C/2006 P1 (McNaught)
2007 January 29.65 UT: m1 = ~+2.3, Dia.= ~4'.0, DC = 7, 15 degrees (naked eye), Naked eye, John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [Observed McMaught in the morning sky (Moon had set). Comet very easy to see. Has a lovely tail of about 15 degrees extending towards the south (roughly). Through an 80mm refractor and 410mm reflector the coma has lost its golden hue from a week ago and is now greeny-blue (carbon, cyanogen?). 9˚ alt in the SSE (Indus).Stellar LM = 6 near comet (NE), rural sky]. Photo taken…

Charles Morris's, 'The New Comet Observations Page' ( http://cometobservation.com/ )
C/2006 P1 (McNaught)
2007 Jan. 29.65 UT: m1=~+2.3,Dia.=~4'.0,DC=7,Tail: 15 deg. in PA 177 deg...Naked eye...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [Observed McMaught in the morning sky (Moon had set). Comet very easy to see. Has a lovely tail of about 15 degrees extending towards the south (roughly). Through an 80mm refractor and 410mm reflector the coma has lost its golden hue from a week ago and is now greeny-blue (carbon, cyanogen?). 9˚ alt in the SSE (Indus).Stellar LM = 6 near comet (NE), rural sky]. Photo taken…

ICQ (International Comet Quarterly) ( http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iau/icq/CometMags.html )
C/2006 P1 (McNaught)
Jan. 29.65 ~+2.3, ~4', (John Drummond, Gisborne, New Zealand, naked eye);

Images taken this morning can be seen at (top of page)...

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet_2006p1-mcnaught.htm
or
http://tinyurl.com/tqo9s

Cheers

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 177° 53', S 38° 37'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

Date:  Thu, 01 Feb 2007 08:16:29 +0100
From:  Jose Pablo 
Subject:  new outburts comet 29P/SW-1
Hi all ,

New outburts of the comet 29 P/SW-1 , the increase in brightness of ~ 2,6 magnitudes , my last observation ccd 24/01/07 m1=16.4 R , and 31/01/07 m1=13.8 R , more information and images here :

http://astrocometas.elpalmar.tv

Kindest Regards , J.P.Navarro Pina

MPC-J70

Date:  Sat, 03 Feb 2007 13:34:20 +0100
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  C2006 P1
At this address you can see two images of the comet in object
taked with RC 12.5" of the RAS observatory in AU.

http://comete.uai.it/comete/C2006P1_070201.jpg
http://comete.uai.it/comete/C2006P1_070203.jpg

The dust is very strange, like a disk around the nucleus.

best regards
Rolando Ligustri
===============================
C.A.R.A. http://cara.uai.it
CAST: Circolo AStrofili Talmassons
www.castfvg.it/fotoccd.htm#comete

Date:  Sat, 03 Feb 2007 21:50:10 +0100
From:  Klaas Jobse 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C2006 P1
Hi Rolando,

Yesterday (02-02) I was able to image P1 with the same instrument, just a
short testing session, and my first thought was that the "peculiar dust
feature" was caused by thin high clouds...
But after seeing your image I realized this feature must be real!

Image at:

http://www.klaas-jobse.net/cyclops/cometspage.htm

Best Regards

Klaas Jobse

At this address you can see two images of the comet in object
taked with RC 12.5" of the RAS observatory in AU.

http://comete.uai.it/comete/C2006P1_070201.jpg
http://comete.uai.it/comete/C2006P1_070203.jpg

The dust is very strange, like a disk around the nucleus.

Rolando Ligustri

Date:  Thu, 08 Feb 2007 15:47:44 +1030
From:  belatrix 
Subject:  C/2006 P1 McNaught 7th feb 2007
Hi group!,
Went out to a dark location last night and just caught the last half
hour before the moon rose. Whilst driving there, and out in the dark, I
thought I would look for comet out my drivers side window while
driving, as I knew where it was, and was amazed how easy it was to see
at a glance! naked eye, and at a glance, could instantly see the whole
tail, flash a curving spray over 26 degrees up to SMC - what a sight!
After taking a wrong turn, and arriving late at around 10 pm local time
7th feb 2007 (11:30 7th UT) , I didnt have time for some of the things
I had planned - but took a couple of tripod shots with 350D anyway.
Moon made a big difference to tail length once it was even slightly
over the horizon, instantly halving it.
I had charts all made up for proper obs, but didnt get a chance, but
did a rough estimate of coma's brightness, and it was certainly around
the +3.5 magnitude mark.
here are two, quickie processed, 30 sec, iso 1600 single shots, no
darks, and from hi-res jpg only at this stage, one using 50mm f 1.4
lens @ f 1.4 and other kit 18-55 mm @ 18mm and f3.5
18mm wide field was already affected by moon to a fair degree - so lost
some of tail in it.

http://southern-x.org/so_x/p1/p1_7feb_0894.jpg

http://southern-x.org/so_x/p1/p1_7feb_0902.jpg

One day I will put a page together, but I will have (hopefully) better
versions of all shots, as I am unfamiliar with much astro digital
processing atm, and need to work it out on a PC as well, with RAW
versions and stacking (I use a mac mostly) and I need some film shots
done as well, so no point atm.
Cheers
Kearn Jones
Adelaide,
Australia
images taken at around 34.5 south. 

Date:  Thu, 08 Feb 2007 11:58:26 -0000
From:  Martin Mobberley 
Subject:  2P and 29P on Feb 6th
Dear Group,

I imaged a number of comets from the UK on
Feb 6th. I have now posted images of 2P, and 29P in

The image URL's are:

29P
http://uk.geocities.com/martin.mobberley@btinternet.com/29P_20070206_mpm.jpg

Regards,

Martin Mobberley

Date:  Sun, 11 Feb 2007 20:55:36 -0000
From:  kometman55 
Subject:  first light with Astrograph 12" f 3.8 comet C/2006 E2 McNaught
Hello everybody!

The weather on this weekend was beautiful but unfortunately forced by
an electronic failure on our brand new Losmandy HGM mount the
autoguider doesn´t work. That happens just as we wanted to take first
light with our ASA 12" f 3.8 N. Therefore we decided to take some
frames of a faint comet in Gemini using 60 seconds subframes unguided.

As we blinked through the images to search for other moving objects
beside the comet, this action indicate us to two possible minor
planets. One was found at the upper right corner and one in the middle
below of the frame.

The Minor Planetery Checker recognized these objects as KP2000 UF103
Mag 17.9 and KP2022JQ4 Mag 18.2. That´s very deep for 60 seconds
exp.time and they are very easy to find! No flats are made! If you
click on the link buttons at the text files you can see an amintion.

http://www.astrostudio.at/Astrofotos/astrofotos.php?k_id=72

best regards

Gerald and Michael 

Date:  Mon, 12 Feb 2007 13:54:13 -0000
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: first light with Astrograph 12" f 3.8 comet C/2006 E2 McNaught
That's a very long thin tail on C/2006 E2 just like C/2006 U1 from a
couple of months ago.

You have a very fine astrograph. It must be very nice to have such
fine equipment.

From:  Mike Holloway

Gerald. Is the new scope a 1100mm FL at F 3.8? If so that will do a
great job on the small faint comets. I ordered a FR for the 127is to
have a 530mm at F 4.2. Hope to get some bigger, brighter comets to
use this with.
Mike H.

> That's a very long thin tail on C/2006 E2 just like C/2006 U1 from
a
> couple of months ago.
>
> You have a very fine astrograph. It must be very nice to have such
> fine equipment.
>
> --- In Comet-Images@
> yahoogroups.com, "kometman55"
> wrote:
> >
> > Hello everybody!
> >
> > The weather on this weekend was beautiful but unfortunately
forced
> by
> > an electronic failure on our brand new Losmandy HGM mount the
> > autoguider doesn´t work. That happens just as we wanted to take
> first
> > light with our ASA 12" f 3.8 N. Therefore we decided to take some
> > frames of a faint comet in Gemini using 60 seconds subframes
> unguided.
> >
> > As we blinked through the images to search for other moving
objects
> > beside the comet, this action indicate us to two possible minor
> > planets. One was found at the upper right corner and one in the
> middle
> > below of the frame.
> >
> > The Minor Planetery Checker recognized these objects as KP2000
> UF103
> > Mag 17.9 and KP2022JQ4 Mag 18.2. That´s very deep for 60 seconds
> > exp.time and they are very easy to find! No flats are made! If you
> > click on the link buttons at the text files you can see an
> amintion.
> >
> > http://www.astrostu
>
dio.at/Astrofotos/astrofotos.php?k_id=72>

Date:  Wed, 14 Feb 2007 18:07:00 +0100
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  Re: [comets-ml] Re: Latest thinking on the tail?
>I roughly measured 20 degrees of vertical tail and 30 degrees of horizontal
> tail to the horizon on the 19th Jan, so i took that as 50 degrees at least!
> It was nothing short of spectacular!
> Cheers!
> Chris W
> Walcha, NSW, Australia

Hi all,
at this address : http://comete.uai.it/2006p1/C2006P1_070213.jpg

you can see my latest image of the comet, photographed in remote
with the RAS Observatory, from Sidney.
The field is enough great, the complex structure of the tail of dusts is seen very well,
these, of brown color, they are predominant! only the nucleus is of color green-water.

best regards
Rolando Ligustri

Date:  Sun, 18 Feb 2007 18:50:27 -0600
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Comet C/2005 E2 (McNaught) February 18, 2007 0457UT
Comet C/2005 E2 (McNaught) February 18, 2007 0457UT

http://bellsouthpwp2.net/c/h/charbell/C2005E2-02182007-0457UT.jpg

12 x 300 second images stacked with Astrometrica
Log stretched with NASA/ESA Fits Liberator Plugin and PhotoshopCS2
Very faint tail approximately 5 arc min in PA 330 

Date:  Mon, 19 Feb 2007 04:07:50 -0600
From:  "Dr. D. T. Durig" 
Subject:  [Comet-Images] Comet C/2005 E2 (McNaught) February 19, 2007 , 24 arc minute tail length !


I have been imaging Comet C/2005 E2 McNaught for a few weeks as a class
project to measure the angular and physical length of the tail. I stack a
few more images and find a much longer tail length. Using 15x120 sec stacks
from Astrometrica, I got a tail length of over 24 arc minutes ! You can see
almost all of it in a GIF animation I posted to my results page at
http://arthur.sewanee.edu/obsv/view.php

I used a 0.30 m SCT at f/9.7 ( 2910 mm ) and a SBIG STL-1001E CCD. The FOV
is around 28x28 arc minutes. Pixel resolution is around 3.38 arc seconds per
pixel. I log scaled the FITS images with CCDOps to make the GIFs show more
detail and then used Microsoft's GIFAnimator to make the animation of the
three GIF frames. It is easier to see the end of the tail if you animate the
images. I did not do anything with the cosmic ray hits and other artifacts,
so it may look a little noisy, but it clearly shows a much longer tail than
other recent images.

Dr. D. T. Durig

Cordell-Lorenz Observatory

OBS COD 850

ddurig@sewanee.edu

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Tue, 20 Feb 2007 16:58:31 -0000
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: Comet C/2005 E2 (McNaught) February 19, 2007 , 24 arc minute tail length !
Your image clearly resolves the tail.

All I could really tell from the image from my last post was that it
was at least 5 arc minutes. It was so faint that I could not resolve
beyond that.

I think your camera is much more sensitive than the one I have at
present. I am imaging at 0.76 arc sec/pixel.

I found a potential new asteroid in the field of the 2/19 image and
went after it again last night, but it was very windy. The stars are
bloated but the comet's tail still shows well and I recovered the
potential new asteroid OK. I am still waiting for the designation
from the MPC. I will post the 2/20 image when I can label the
asteroid.

Date:  Thu, 22 Feb 2007 02:31:17 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  P/2001 Q2 - 02/22/2007
Hello. Another comet that sits low in the West at dark. This is a
5x40 sec exp with the 5" refractor at F5.2-660mm and ST10XMEI ccd.
smoke from fires in the windy dry conditions hurt the image. Close to
Venus
Thanks, Mike H
http://fototime.com/B593F9F2F2992BD/orig.jpg

Date:  Thu, 22 Feb 2007 22:43:34 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  2P/Encke - 02/22/2007
Hello. On feb 18th Gerald and Michael posted a 2P image showing two
tails very thin and faint. I have never seen such a set of tails and
actually thought it might have been a piece of space junk traveling
through or something. My appologies to you both. Last night i finally
got back out with some ok skys and 2P was my main target. This also
shows the string tail to each side. My image is stacked on the stars
so the comet is elongated a little. My question is, is this tail
structure? If so this is very odd.
Thanks, Mike H.
http://fototime.com/0B9B084847804B3/orig.jpg 

Date:  Fri, 23 Feb 2007 00:52:42 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Re: 2P/Encke - 02/22/2007
Received this in an email. Very interesting.

"I'm pretty certain that you've imaged Encke's dust _trail_ (rather
than tail). These structures were first observed by the IRAS
satellite, and they're thought to consist of mm-cm sized grains that
slowly spread around short-period comets' orbits. They've been
observed at visual wavelengths previously (though for the first time
only around 5 years ago, I think), but I think this may be the first
time that amateurs have reported detecting trails.

There's a nice description of the structures here, by someone studying
them in depth:
http://physics.ucf.edu/~msk/projects/trails/

Will try to access the images from IRAS if I can figure out how.
Thanks, Mike H.

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Holloway"
wrote:
>
> Hello. On feb 18th Gerald and Michael posted a 2P image showing two
> tails very thin and faint. I have never seen such a set of tails and
> actually thought it might have been a piece of space junk traveling
> through or something. My appologies to you both. Last night i
finally
> got back out with some ok skys and 2P was my main target. This also
> shows the string tail to each side. My image is stacked on the stars
> so the comet is elongated a little. My question is, is this tail
> structure? If so this is very odd.
> Thanks, Mike H.
> http://fototime.com/0B9B084847804B3/orig.jpg
>

From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] Re: 2P/Encke - 02/22/2007
Hello Mike,
indeed this is a dust trail. Its visibility is enhanced, since during these days our planet is crossing the orbital plane of the comet.
Cheers,
Giovanni

Hi Mike,

I confirm your observation. Also I have photographed the comet on February 16
and also in my image it is visible (very faint) the structure that you point out.
however I thought that it was a defect of the calibration, due to a bad dark.
thanks your image now I know that is not it! ;-)

Rolando 

Date:  Sat, 24 Feb 2007 14:18:00 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Re: 2P/Encke - 02/22/2007
Greetings. I want to post a reply I received and will not post the
sender name but this is legitimate. It is hard for an amature to gain
a "definite" sometimes but this is nessecary for confirmation.
Thanks, Mike H.
============================================================
"Hi Mike Holloway,

That is a very nice image. I'm not positive it is the trail, but it
does appear to be at the correct angle (55 and 235 degrees E of N),
assuming N and E are exact. Trails are notoriously difficult to
detect, usually because they are very faint. There is an optical image
of Encke's trail on the second page of the paper at:

http://www.lpi.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2003/pdf/2056.pdf

They took 17 hours of images from the Kitt Peak 2-meter and co-added
them to find the trail. The trail was at 4 AU from the Sun at the time,
but today it might take 30 minutes to an hour of 1-meter telescope time
to detect it. That being said, what could those features be?

That is a total exposure time of 720 seconds, right? How large is the
image's field-of-view? Encke moved about 15" over that exposure time,
not counting CCD read/download time. That seems small enough that,
besides moving along 68 degrees E of N, there probably isn't some weird
smearing effect. The direction of the sun is right along one of the
trail directions (237 degrees E of N). That complicates things a bit
more. The anti-solar feature might be an ion tail, and the feature in
the solar direction could be a sunward jet. That's my guess anyway
(Encke is known for strong jet activity).

The angle between the Sun and trail is changing and will increase to 8
degrees on March 6. Encke might be getting to low to image, but if you
can still get it, then that would be a better time to tell if this is a
trail or something else. Thanks for sharing the image!"

http://www.fototime.com/0A6A8C7F2E56659/orig.jpg

Date:  Sat, 10 Mar 2007 10:07:12 +1300
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  McNaught gallery from New Zealand
Clear DayHi all,

if anyone wants to look, the Royal Astronomical Society of New Zealand Astrophotography Section had a Comet McNaught image competition (we post the page and then people vote). There are some AMAZING McNaught photos from NZ astronomers.

PLEASE NOTE, THESE ARE ALL COPYRIGHTED AND MAY NOT BE USED EXCEPT BY EXPRESS PERMISSION OF THE CREATOR/OWNER - VIA ME (John Drummond)...

Go to:
http://possumobservatory.co.nz/rasnzaps/rasnzaps-comp-2007-02-feb-special-mcnaught.htm
or
http://tinyurl.com/3ahjl2

Have a look and enjoy the great images of a truly awesome comet...

Cheers

John Drummond
RASNZAPS Director

Subject:  Re: 2P/Encke - 02/22/2007
Hello Giovanni. I must have missed the replys from Quanzhi Ye and
Seiichi Yoshida to my post on the comet images board which you have
reproduced below. I communicated with Rolando about his image and he
ask that I not show it to anyone else and I respected his wishes.
Michael and Geralds image which was posted on the 17th of Feb was
listed as two comet tails. For this article I was given 300 to 400
words and ask to simply tell how I took this image and with what
equiptment I took the image and more important the help from Mr Reach
who I must say was a very kind and helpfull man. Who took what when
was not the point trhey wanted but rather the corperation between
profesional and amateur in what might be another field for the comet
imager to contribute in the future. Sorry if it is not to your
liking.
Thanks for your input
Mike H.

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "gvnn64" wrote:
>
> > Hello. On feb 18th Gerald and Michael posted a 2P image showing
two
> > tails very thin and faint. I have never seen such a set of tails
and
> > actually thought it might have been a piece of space junk
traveling
> > through or something. My appologies to you both. Last night i
> finally
> > got back out with some ok skys and 2P was my main target. This
also
> > shows the string tail to each side. My image is stacked on the
stars
> > so the comet is elongated a little. My question is, is this tail
> > structure? If so this is very odd.
>

Date:  Fri, 23 Mar 2007 03:58:21 +1100
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Comet 2007 E2 Lovejoy

I've posted an image of Comet 2007 E2 Lovejoy that I've taken after 2 weeks of continuous cloud. It can be viewed at:
http://tinyurl.com/2gug5v

It is a stacking of 5 x 4 min exposures, each tracking on the comet. Altitude was low, so seeing and tracking was not
good. The image shows an elongation in PA 230d of almost 2 arc mins from the nucleus. Presumably this is a forerunner of
a tail. [The image size is about 5 x 8 arc mins].

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia 

Date:  Sun, 25 Mar 2007 20:49:24 +1200
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  C/2007 E2 and E1 (Lovejoy and Garradd) VIS OBS, Photos, Astrometry
Hi all,

I visually observed C/2007 E2 (Lovejoy) and imaged C/2007 E1 (Garradd) last night - and did astrometry on both (below)...

CometObs - ( http://groups.yahoo.com/group/CometObs/ )
C/2007 E2 (Lovejoy)
2007 March 24.66 UT: m1 = 8.7, Dia.= 4'.5, DC = 4, 8cm f5 Refract (13x)...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [Can easily see C/2007E2 through my 8cm refractor as a distinct smudge of light. Through the 41cm I can see a very slight central condensation. No tail seen. Stars use are TYC 8406-877 (mag 8.5), TYC 8406-76 (mag 9.1), TYC 8406-126 (mag 8.8) - in-out method. 40˚ alt in the SE. Stellar LM = 6.5 near comet (naked eye), rural sky]. Photo and astrometry taken…

Charles Morris's, 'The New Comet Observations Page' ( http://cometobservation.com/ )
2007 Mar. 24.66 UT: m1=8.7, Dia.=4'.5, DC=4...8cm f5 Refract (13x)...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [Can easily see C/2007E2 through my 8cm refractor as a distinct smudge of light. Through the 41cm I can see a very slight central condensation. No tail seen. Stars use are TYC 8406-877 (mag 8.5), TYC 8406-76 (mag 9.1), TYC 8406-126 (mag 8.8) - in-out method. 40˚ alt in the SE. Stellar LM = 6.5 near comet (naked eye), rural sky]. Photo and astrometry taken…

ICQ (International Comet Quarterly) ( http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iau/icq/CometMags.html )
Mar.24.66, 8.7, 4'.5 (John Drummond, Gisborne, New Zealand, 8cm refractor):

Images of these comets can be seen at...

Lovejoy:
http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet_2007e2-lovejoy-41cm_f5,2-1min-5l,3r,3g,3b-25c-2x2bin-070324-john_drummond-scs-web2.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/2wpbcz

Garradd:
http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet_garrard-41cm_5,2-1min-5xlum-25c-2x2bin-070324-john_drummond-scs-web2.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/2oucr5

Astrometry of these comets is thus...

COD E94
CON J. Drummond [john_drummond@xtra.co.nz]
TEL 0.41-m f/5.2 reflector + CCD
ACK MPCReport file updated 2007.03.25 10:32:31
AC2 john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
NET UCAC-2
CK07E010 C2007 03 24.43801 14 10 03.15 -23 01 41.6 15.3 N E94
CK07E010 C2007 03 24.43902 14 10 02.54 -23 01 39.3 16.1 N E94
CK07E010 C2007 03 24.44206 14 10 00.53 -23 01 31.5 16.1 N E94
CK07E020 C2007 03 24.69594 20 31 53.72 -45 43 08.0 14.1 N E94
CK07E020 C2007 03 24.70226 20 31 53.09 -45 42 51.5 14.1 N E94
CK07E020 C2007 03 24.71013 20 31 52.34 -45 42 30.9 14.2 N E94
----- end -----

Cheers

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
IAU Code: E94
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

Date:  Sat, 31 Mar 2007 03:29:30 +1000
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Fw: Re:Fw: [comets-ml] Comet Lovejoy, Comet Garradd
Giovanni was kind enough to process the images I took of Comet Lovejoy on March 27. His comments on his processed images
are given below.

I've posted the processed images at:

Larson-Sekanina http://tinyurl.com/33t2r4

MCM (Azimuthal median subtraction) http://tinyurl.com/3c995u

RWM (Radial coma subtraction) http://tinyurl.com/2vxpoz

and the image showing the interesting 'what is it'
http://tinyurl.com/32lvsf

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

----- Original Message -----
From:
To: "DRHerald"
Sent: Friday, March 30, 2007 2:13 AM
Subject: Re: Re:Fw: [comets-ml] Comet Lovejoy, Comet Garradd

Hello dave,
I enclose here the image-processing output based on the averaged file.

This averaged image is much better than the previous one to extract fine details within the coma: I can confirm the
previous comments (i.e. asymmetric coma, presence of jets). But now it's clear that there is something more: I enclose a
"what is it"? file, where I have pointed to a nice feature not visible in the add .FITS I have seen before; I bet
dollars to donuts that this is another filament of the ion tail (~40" long toward PA 190 deg): it's visible in all the
elaborations, included the infamous Larson-Sekanina rotational gradient algorithm.

Looking carefully at you .FITS, I get the impression that actually all the SE quadrant of the tail (say, the sector
comprised between PA 240 deg and 180 deg) is somehow "mottled". Try by yourself to look at it through different
contrast/threshold visualization levels.
My suspicion is that it's rich of ion tail streamers, just a little above the detection threshold limit. Unfortunately
the S/N is not enough to be sure about the reality of this stuff, however it would be very funny if we find this kind
of, say, "noise" just in one over four quadrants of the tail image!

Thanks for having provided me the opportunity to play on such an interesting object.

Cheers,
Giovanni

****************************
I attach here the preliminary results of my image-processing:
1) cut_fut.fit is a part of your original frame, where I have subtracted the sky backgroud gradient
2) MCM and RWM are, respectively, an azimuthal median subtraction and a 1/r theoretical coma subtraction
3) LS is the classical Larson-Sekanina rotational gradient filtering

There is one possible problem with your stacking: it seems that in the nuclear region you are away from the linearity
regime of the CCD camera. This normally creates some trouble with image processing routines. If for the stacking you
used the "add" option of "Astrometrica", try to "average" the same frames: it might help.

For now, I would say that from this image we have hints of a slightly assymetrical coma (it looks like more developed in
the NW quadrant) with possible ion-tail filaments in PA ~237 deg (main componenet) and PA ~220 deg (secondary ray);
unfortunately these two features are embedded in a broad dusty-like tail, that makes difficult to understand the
situation unambiguously.

****************************

------------------------------------------------------
Leggi GRATIS le tue mail con il telefonino i-modeT di Wind
http://click.libero.it/imode

Date:  Sun, 08 Apr 2007 01:19:56 -0400
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy.


I photographed the latest comet Comet Lovejoy.
see blog
http://eoas-dreric1kansas.blogspot.com/
(near middle of picture hazy star)
Students will
(E.O.A.S.1) Compare and contrast this comet ( tail shape, size, distinct
nature etc) to the pictures of magnificent Comet McNaught , which we could see in
the Northern skies only for a few days in January 2007 before it displayed its
huge tail in the Southern Hemisphere.

(E.O.A.S.2) This comet will only reach magnitude 7 (but  comets can change,
as they are like cats - they are unpredictable,  someone said). Compare to the
other parts of the magnitude scale and compare it to McNaught, aided eye,
Venus and others.

This comet is famous for the fact that it is the FIRST comet to be captured
with a digital camera -a canon XT, just like the one I have . I was not in the
right place at the right time because the discoverer is in the Southern
Hemisphere.

I thought we could not see the comet in the Northern Hemisphere until around
4/15 but I captured it (Black and white here) last night (60 seconds). It has
a greenish tint and I am working on a color image and will try to show it
soon. It seems to have a slight fan tail shape and the coma (head is distinct ) as
you can see. It is about 8th magnitude which as many people know unobservable
to the naked eye. We won't be able to see it without a small telescope or
binoculars with its closest approach in about a week.

Picture
time taken 4:57 MT 4/07/2007
exposure:60 seconds

Celestial:
Right Ascension: 20h 4.8m
Declination: -30 degrees 55 minutes
More soon

Dr. Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com), Olathe, KS: E.O.A.S. (Earth, Oceans,
Atmosphere and Space) Blog -:State
of Kansas-JPL NASA Solar System Ambassador: Comet Observers Award
Coordinator- Astronomy League/ Astronomical Society of Kansas, KC, MO-Louisburg,KS:
http://www.astroleague.org/al/obsclubs/comet/comet.htm: Subscribe to (send your
email to):CometObserversAwardAL-subscribe@yahoogroups.com : Eric's Black Sun
Eclipse newsletter: Subscribe to (send your email to)<
blacksuneclipse-subscribe@egroups.com>:Website-
http://members.aol.com/kcstarguy/blacksun/eclipse.htm: Satori Astronomy Website-
http://members.aol.com/kcstarguy/satoriastronomy/satoriastronomy.htm : Member #2572 IMCA

**************************************
See what's free at http://www.aol.com.

Date:  Thu, 12 Apr 2007 20:32:19 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  2P-Encke - 04/12/2007
Hello. Weeks of bad weather allowed for a few minutes of imaging last
night. I almost in some way wish it hadn't. This image was not posted
untill now because of the strange look. It is a simple add of 4x30 sec
exp. I couldn't seem to get rid of the N/S (top to bottom)streaks.
Felt they were real but just didn't know what they are. Sent a private
email to Michael Jaeger as his image from the 9th of this month showed
faint structure to the north side of the comet so I knew he had it.
It seams to have increased. His image information (about the
structure) was undescribed. I now think it is real but have no idea
what this is. Jet? Was hoping to image again but bad storms are
moving in. Michael said he would try to get this on the chip again
tonight. I hope he can. This comet is a really amazing small object.
Hope discussion will begin was Michaels comment.
Thank You
Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/0A3E9816F79A611/standard.jpg

http://www.fototime.com/0A3E9816F79A611/orig.jpg 

Date:  Thu, 12 Apr 2007 21:19:10 -0000

Date:  Fri, 13 Apr 2007 23:29:20 +0900
From:  Masayuki Suzuki 
Subject:  Re: 2P-Encke - 04/12/2007
Hi Mike,

At first (in February) I did not think this structure was dust trail,
but now I think it is probably dust trail.
Because this curved structure coincides with the orbit of 2P/Encke.

for information
http://homepage2.nifty.com/mtnsuzuki/orb2p.htm

Best regards,

Masayuki Suzuki (Utsunomiya, Japan)

----- Original Message -----
From: "tricks46"
To:
Sent: Friday, April 13, 2007 5:35 AM
Subject: [Comet-Images] 2P-Encke - 04/12/2007

Hello. Weeks of bad weather allowed for a few minutes of imaging last
night. I almost in some way wish it hadn't. This image was not posted
untill now because of the strange look. It is a simple add of 4x30 sec
exp. I couldn't seem to get rid of the N/S (top to bottom)streaks.
Felt they were real but just didn't know what they are. Sent a private
email to Michael Jaeger as his image from the 9th of this month showed
faint structure to the north side of the comet so I knew he had it.
It seams to have increased. His image information (about the
structure) was undescribed. I now think it is real but have no idea
what this is. Jet? Was hoping to image again but bad storms are
moving in. Michael said he would try to get this on the chip again
tonight. I hope he can. This comet is a really amazing small object.
Hope discussion will begin was Michaels comment.
Thank You
Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/0A3E9816F79A611/standard.jpg

http://www.fototime.com/0A3E9816F79A611/orig.jpg 

Date:  Fri, 13 Apr 2007 20:08:49 -0000
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Comet C/2003 WT42 (LINEAR) 04132007 0614UT
Comet C/2003 WT42 (LINEAR)
April 13, 2007 0614UT
11 x 300 sec
0.3 m Meade 200LX SCT @ f/6.3 + ST-2000 + AO7
Tail 6 arc min in PA 315
C. Bell H47 Vicksburg

http://bellsouthpwp2.net/c/h/charbell/C2003WT42-04132007-0614UT.jpg

Date:  Sun, 15 Apr 2007 03:03:19 -0000
From:  algwat 
Subject:  Re: 2P-Encke - 04/12/2007
Gidday Mike, Masayuki, and others,

I have uploaded a short avi file that shows 20070410 images of 2P
Encke.
I think the radial tail features are becoming apparent. I get an
impression that they are curved. They are still quite faint, so I
will try to measure them in the next sequences.

Kind regards, Alan Watson

Date:  Mon, 16 Apr 2007 11:43:36 -0500
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Comet C/2007 E1 (Garradd) April 16, 2007 0139UT
Comet C/2007 E1 (Garradd) April 16, 2007 0139UT

http://bellsouthpwp2.net/c/h/charbell/C2007E1-04162007-0139UT.jpg 

Date:  Mon, 16 Apr 2007 18:58:28 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  C/2007 E1 (Garradd)
This comet is ideally positioned for imaging from the Midwest USA as
it high (57 degrees elevation) and transits at a "reasonable" hour 
that is, at astronomical darkness. At magnitude 13.0 it is an easy
target.

It has a relatively fast motion relative to the star field, 6.2 arc
seconds per minute. I imaged it in one-minute frames with at 5.0
arc seconds per pixel.

The fast relative motion lends itself to a nice animated GIF. I have
a small (422 kB) video of 1 hour of the comet traversing 6.2 arc
minutes of Leo. Take a look. The comet is really racing along!

Images, associated data and imaging notes at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

This is my first image of 2007. I've been spending time on another
hobby  an indoor, non-weather-dependent hobby . See
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/horr.htm

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

http://tech.ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/photos/view/5f08?b=2

Josef Mueller (JJM)

Westerwald-Sternwarte Irmtraut, #A21
Irmtraut, Germany
http://www.westerwald-astro.de
alte Homepage: http://rz-home.de/~jmuelle7/

http://astrofotografie.fg-vds.de 

Date:  Sat, 21 Apr 2007 21:51:31 +0200
From:  walcom77 
Subject:  COMET C/2007 H1 (MCNAUGHT) & COMET C/2007 H2 (SKIFF)
Hi All

http://tinyurl.com/2hocab

Giovanni Sostero and Ernesto Guido (AFAM - Remanzacco Obs.)

Date:  Sat, 21 Apr 2007 20:14:34 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Brightest Comet in the Sky  Dont Miss It!
C/2007 E2 (Lovejoy) is nearing its peak on light curve  see
http://www.aerith.net/comet/catalog/2007E2/2007E2.html

This is presently the brightest comet in the sky (save for a few
lucky souls near the equator who might still be able to view
2P/Encke). Better grab a view or an image now, before it fades into
oblivion.

It is racing though Aquila at 8.8 arc seconds per minute at
magnitude ~ 7.6. I was limited to 30 second exposures when I imaged
it to avoid blur.

I "think" I saw (using averted vision and averted imagination) the
comet in my 4-inch refractor piggybacked on the 6-inch E-160 f/3.3
astrograph. I synthesized a simulated eyepiece view for my web page
linked below.

I was baffled for quite a while looking for the "missing star", V606
Aquilae, that was depicted prominently in my SkyMap Pro screen shot
as being very bright but was missing in my image  even though all
the other stars were right where they should be. How could I not
image a bright star??? The mystery (for those that haven't figured
it out yet) is solved on the web page.

Let me know what you think of the movie. It really was hard for me
to get the hour's worth of frames to look about the same. The comet
was rising in the sky (and thus getting brighter as the atmospheric
extinction was decreasing); at the same time, the sun was rising, so
the sky glow was increasing. Balancing the two effects to achieve
consistent histograms drove me nuts! I've probably invested ten
hours in image processing and composing the web page.

Images, associated data, eyepiece view, imaging notes and *movie*
all at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Please take a look and give me some feedback. This was quite a
processing challenge for me. Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

structure shown in this processed negative image. I am sure it is
nothing but it does show on my images.
Thanks
Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/9B3A397D2E22FB6/orig.jpg

Date:  Mon, 30 Apr 2007 18:44:40 +1200
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Images: McNaught (P1) and Lovejoy (E2)
Hi all,

I imaged Comets McNaught (C/2006P1) and Lovejoy (C/2007E2) a few nights ago (April 26.72,73 UT). Both were imaged with a 41cm (16") f5.2 Meade Newtonian and SBIG STL11000M CCD. Exposures were (10L, 5RGB) 30 seconds for Lovejoy and 60 seconds for McNaught. Both were cropped slightly but show an approximate FOV of ~45' x 30'.

Lovejoy is looking good for you northern folk soon...

Lovejoy:
http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet_2007e2-lovejoy-41cm@f5,2-30sec-10l-5r-5g-5b-30c-2x2-070427-web-text.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/37c7sj

McNaught
http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet_2006p1-mcnaught.htm
or
http://tinyurl.com/tqo9s

Cheers

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 177° 53', S 38° 37'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz
