Date:  Fri, 04 May 2007 00:47:56 +0200
From:  Josef Müller 
Subject:  AW: [Comet-Images] Re: C/2007 H2 (SKIFF)
Hello Dennis,

how align the 20 second exposures?
No, I couldn't see the comet in a single frame!
You must have a program like "Astrometrica" (Herbert Raab, Austria).
here you can do astrometry of stacked images.
20 or 40 images, adding up the signal of a faint object. Stacking the
images:
By "Track and Stack" the images can be shifted to compensate the motion
of an object. If you select "Track and Stack" you must know the
coordinates
(you must have USNO B1 or UCAC2 for reference-star) and the speed (some
"/min)
and the direction (P.A.) of the apparent motion of the asteroid. You
will find all this datas
in the ephemerides in MPC.
I will give you the link for Astrometrica:
http://www.astrometrica.at/
If you have this program you will have a lot of work with the "Settings"
(in english):
- Observing Site
- CCD
- Program
- Environment
- Internet
When all settings are well done Astrometrica will work. You are already
able to
identify the asteroide as the only point among the star trails or you
will stack another pair
of images to identify the asteroide by blinking.
Finally Astrometrica will give you the "MPCReport" and you can send it
to harvard!
I hope this helps and you can understand my bad english!
(I was teacher of french and have forgotten all my english!)

Clear skies
Josef Mueller

-----Ursprüngliche Nachricht-----

An: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Betreff: [Comet-Images] Re: C/2007 H2 (SKIFF)

Hello Joseph,

Imaging a magnitude 19 comet is very impressive! How did you align
the 20 second exposures? I assume you couldn't see the comet in a
single frame. Also, what is your VLM?

Thanks.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk

home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Date:  Sat, 05 May 2007 21:17:08 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: C/2007 H2 (SKIFF)
Hello Joseph,

Thanks for the excellent explanation. I thought you must have used
Astrometrica or AstroArt 4.0. I have been avoiding those
applications because, as you say, there is a "lot of work" in the
settings. Hopefully the first few tries are the hardest and then it
gets easier. After seeing the way you brought the very faint comet
out of the noise, I am inspired to give your method a try.

Clear skies,

Dennis

Date:  Sun, 06 May 2007 12:00:28 +1000
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: C/2007 H2 (SKIFF)
It is unfortunate that you have avoided using Astrometrica because of a perception that
there is a lot of work to do in setting it up. Yes, there are settings that have to be
specified. The most critical are the pixel size, the telescope focal length (and you have
to go through a bit of trial and error to get the actual focal length, not the nominal
manufacturer's focal length), and the image orientation (both left/right, as well as
rotational angle about the optical axis). But that is the equivalent of setting up your
scope for the first time. Once you have done this, Astrometrica is a _brilliant_ piece of
software that makes astrometric measurement of images both incredibly simple, and highly
accurate. Typically it takes me about 60 secs to do a measurement (from selecting the
image(s) through to the generation of the position). IMHO, Astrometrica is the astrometric
solution of choice, being a highly optimised dedicated astrometric solution. (And don't
assess its value by comparing its nominal cost against the commercial price of other
packages. Price is not a valid indicator of the quality of the product...) With my 14" I
regularly do 'track & stack' to do astrometry on faint objects - the extreme being moons
26 and 29 of Saturn, which never get brighter than 20.5 and 20.0 respectively. And my
several asteroid discoveries have come about when doing a track & stack for faint comets -
and those asteroids were all fainter than mag 19.0 when I discovered them.

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

----- Original Message -----
From: "Dennis Persyk"
To:
Sent: Sunday, May 06, 2007 7:17 AM
Subject: [Comet-Images] Re: C/2007 H2 (SKIFF)

Hello Joseph,

Thanks for the excellent explanation. I thought you must have used
Astrometrica or AstroArt 4.0. I have been avoiding those
applications because, as you say, there is a "lot of work" in the
settings. Hopefully the first few tries are the hardest and then it
gets easier. After seeing the way you brought the very faint comet
out of the noise, I am inspired to give your method a try.

Clear skies,

Dennis

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, Josef Mller
wrote:
>
> Hello Dennis,
>
> how align the 20 second exposures?
> No, I couldn't see the comet in a single frame!
> You must have a program like "Astrometrica" (Herbert Raab,
Austria). here you can do astrometry of stacked images.
> 20 or 40 images, adding up the signal of a faint object. Stacking
the images:
> By "Track and Stack" the images can be shifted to compensate the
motion of an object. If you select "Track and Stack" you must know
the coordinates (you must have USNO B1 or UCAC2 for reference-star)
and the speed (some "/min) and the direction (P.A.) of the apparent
motion of the asteroid. You will find all this datas
> in the ephemerides in MPC.
> I will give you the link for Astrometrica:
> http://www.astrometrica.at/
> If you have this program you will have a lot of work with
the "Settings"(in english):
> - Observing Site
> - CCD
> - Program
> - Environment
> - Internet
> When all settings are well done Astrometrica will work. You are
already able to identify the asteroide as the only point among the
star trails or you will stack another pair
> of images to identify the asteroide by blinking.
> Finally Astrometrica will give you the "MPCReport" and you can
send it to harvard!
> I hope this helps and you can understand my bad english!
> (I was teacher of french and have forgotten all my english!)
>
> Clear skies
> Josef Mueller
>
> -----Ursprngliche Nachricht-----
> Von: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com [mailto:Comet-
Images@yahoogroups.com]
> Im Auftrag von Dennis Persyk

Date:  Sun, 06 May 2007 19:59:35 -0500
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  C/2003 WT42 May 6, 2007 0338UT with 4 arc minute Tail
C/2003 WT42 (LINEAR) May 6, 2007 0338UT

http://bellsouthpwp2.net/c/h/charbell/C2003WT42-05062007-0338UT.jpg

18 x 300 second exposures stacked with Astrometrica
0.3m Meade 200LX SCT at f/6.3 + SBIG ST-2000XCM binned 2x2 + AO-7
Coma diameter approximately 8 pixels or 8 x 1.52 arc sec /pixel = 12 arc secs
Tail length approximately 4 arc minutes in PA 320 Tail width approximately 24 arc sec
Astrometrica mag estimate 17.0N using 18 pixel or 28 arc sec aperture radius.

The coma and tail are very faint in 5 mnute subexposures, but very evident in stacked image.
Coma is circular and highly condensed. DC=9 

Date:  Mon, 07 May 2007 13:52:44 +0200
From:  Bernd Brinkmann 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] New file uploaded to Comet-Images
Hello Michael,

> File : /michael jaeger/2007H220070421UT22506x170.jpg

> 22506x170.jpg

interestingly there is MP (1096) Reunerta with 14.3 mag left of the comets
image. Motion is 35.489"/h at PA 282.4 deg. You can see it at a glance
because this trail has another direction.

Bernd

Date:  Tue, 08 May 2007 00:07:39 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Astrometrica vs. AstroArt 4.0 was  Re: C/2007 H2 (SKIFF)
Hello David,

Setup is not what's keeping me from using more sophisticated
stacking software  more like sheer laziness. My camera is hard-
mounted with the horizontal axis to within 0.1 degree of the RA axis
and I have all the imaging parameters established save perhaps for
the exact focal length of my astrograph.

In reading about Astrometrica, I see that one can only stack 6
images of a moving object. I don't think that is a limitation in
AstroArt 4.0, which seems to be an advantage. I wonder if anyone on
list has had the opportunity to use both applications?

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

New Images http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Dave Herald"
wrote:
>
> It is unfortunate that you have avoided using Astrometrica because
of a perception that there is a lot of work to do in setting it up.
Yes, there are settings that have to be specified. The most
critical are the pixel size, the telescope focal length (and you
have to go through a bit of trial and error to get the actual focal
length, not the nominal manufacturer's focal length), and the image
orientation (both left/right, as well as rotational angle about the
optical axis). But that is the equivalent of setting up your
> scope for the first time. Once you have done this, Astrometrica is
a _brilliant_ piece of software that makes astrometric measurement
of images both incredibly simple, and highly accurate. Typically it
takes me about 60 secs to do a measurement (from selecting the
> image(s) through to the generation of the position). IMHO,
Astrometrica is the astrometric solution of choice, being a highly
optimised dedicated astrometric solution. (And don't
> assess its value by comparing its nominal cost against the
commercial price of other packages. Price is not a valid indicator
of the quality of the product...) With my 14" I regularly do 'track
& stack' to do astrometry on faint objects - the extreme being moons
> 26 and 29 of Saturn, which never get brighter than 20.5 and 20.0
respectively. And my several asteroid discoveries have come about
when doing a track & stack for faint comets - and those asteroids
were all fainter than mag 19.0 when I discovered them.
>

> Canberra, Australia 

Date:  Tue, 08 May 2007 09:50:27 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] Astrometrica vs. AstroArt 4.0 was Re: C/2007 H2  (SKIFF)
Hello Dennis

> In reading about Astrometrica, I see that one can only stack 6
> images of a moving object.

This isn't true: I usually stack 100+ images without any problem.

> AstI wonder if anyone on
> list has had the opportunity to use both applications?

I'm using both applications: for stacking Astrometrica is far better, while for image processing Astroart is superior. Both of them are great softwares, however I think that you cannot make a comparison, since they were developed for different applications (Astrometrica is a very specialized package).

IMHO Astrometrica is simply the best software readily available to amateurs for astrometric purposes, while Astroart is an excellent general purpose image processing software (with the possibility to perform astrometry, but obviously with much less potentialities in this field of application compared to Astrometrica).

Regards,
Giovanni

------------------------------------------------------
Leggi GRATIS le tue mail con il telefonino i-mode di Wind
http://i-mode.wind.it/ 

Date:  Tue, 08 May 2007 20:20:24 +0400
From:  Romas Eugenе 
Subject:  E2 core destruction?
Hi everyone!

I took some pictures of a comet in period May 2nd 2007 20:23(UTC) - May 2nd 2007 20:32(UTC). I’ve got 19 good quality pictures with retention interval of 30 seconds each one.
After summation I discovered 4 dim and 1 luminous objects. I guess they are moving along with the comet.
So I have a supposition that the core of this comet is collapsing. But maybe it’s my mistake…
Has anybody of you guys watched taken some pictures of this one at the same time? Please, confirm or disprove the fact of collapsing.
My equipment is: Newton 150 1/5, Canon 350Da(baader filter), Vixen GPDX
And images:
two imges in JPEG format:
http://cerebrum.jino-net.ru/pic/18x30sec_iso1600.jpg
http://cerebrum.jino-net.ru/pic/19x30sec_iso1600.jpg
And BMP-format in the archive:
http://cerebrum.jino-net.ru/pic/19x30sec_iso1600.rar - 150kb
Thanks...

---------------------------------

Hi, Eugene,

It does appear that the smaller dimmer objects are actually tracking
with the comet.
Can you post a couple of higher resolution images?

Have you reported this to the IAU or anywhere else? Might be a good idea.

Astronomically, John
John O'Neal

> 

Date:  Fri, 11 May 2007 14:29:24 +0400

Subject:  C/2007 F1-05/13/2007
Knew this would be hard and it was harder than that. Arrows show a
galaxy in the lower right and a faint galaxy which guide did not show
or list (so the ?). Between the 10.18 mag star and the other arrow is
where guide showed the comet to be. I put the arrow on a place next to
a faint star (to the left) that is the only area I can find that did
not show on DSS images. Appears to be an elongated area compaired to
the DSS images. Maybe -- maybe not, or could be in another area or
maybe not showing at all!
http://www.fototime.com/845CB8494249EEE/orig.jpg

Date:  Sat, 19 May 2007 13:48:34 +0200
From:  Mike Androsch 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] comet lovejoy
Hi Gerald and Michael,

looks great! Can you give any info on your new processing technique?

Best regards

Mike
----- Original Message -----
From: kometman55
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, May 19, 2007 12:34 AM
Subject: [Comet-Images] comet lovejoy

Hi everybody!

We tried to use a new processing technic with long exposures and fast
moving comets:

http://www.astrostudio.at/Astrofotos/aufnahme.php?a_id=580&page=1&kategorie=&k_id=73

we hope you enjoy

Gerald and Michael

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Sat, 19 May 2007 12:33:34 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  96P - 2007/05/19
http://www.fototime.com/2D9DA086ADDC1E3/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sun, 20 May 2007 05:17:58 -0000
From:  Terry Lovejoy 
Subject:  Re: comet lovejoy
Very nicely done guys!

It looks like you have layered 2 versions of the same image, one a
median stack registered on the comet and a second registered on the
stars. Perhaps you did the second version on another night when the
comet wasn't there. In any case it definitely works.

Terry

Hi everybody!

moving comets:

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Sun, 20 May 2007 19:32:40 +0200
From:  Gerald Rhemann 
Subject:  AW: [Comet-Images] Re: comet lovejoy
Hi Terry,

Thanks - you are right the process is finished by Photoshop Layers but with
pictures taken in the same night. We only separated the stars from the
comet. We tried different kind of processing to remove the startrails from
the comet layer and to remove the blurred comet from the starfield layer.
There are some scores to consider to avoid a reduced information or to
obtain artefacts but I think we are on the right way now.

Gerald

_____

Von: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com [mailto:Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com] Im
Auftrag von Terry Lovejoy
Gesendet: Sonntag, 20. Mai 2007 07:18
An: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Betreff: [Comet-Images] Re: comet lovejoy

Very nicely done guys!

It looks like you have layered 2 versions of the same image, one a
median stack registered on the comet and a second registered on the
stars. Perhaps you did the second version on another night when the
comet wasn't there. In any case it definitely works.

Terry

Date:  Mon, 21 May 2007 20:22:52 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2007 F1 - ?
Has anyone imaged this comet in the past few days? I tried on the 20th
of this month with 20 minutes of information under very good skys and
position and came up with nothing. Checked at
http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iau/lists/LastCometObs.html
and it appears the comet has gotten dimmer.
Mike H. 

Date:  Mon, 21 May 2007 15:26:46 -0500
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Comet Images from May 20, 2007 C/2003 WT42, C/2007 E2, C/2006 V1
Comet Images from May 20, 2007

C/2003 WT42 (LINEAR) May 20, 2007 0357UT
http://bellsouthpwp2.net/c/h/charbell/C2003WT42-05202007-0357UT.jpg

C/2007 E2 (Lovejoy) May 20, 2007 0302UT
http://bellsouthpwp2.net/c/h/charbell/C2007E2-05202007-0302UT.jpg

C/2006 V1 (Catalina) May 20, 2007 0217UT
http://bellsouthpwp2.net/c/h/charbell/C2006V1-05202007-0217UT.jpg 

Date:  Mon, 21 May 2007 23:34:01 +0200
From:  Bernd Brinkmann 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2007 F1 - ?
Hello Mike,

> Has anyone imaged this comet in the past few days? I tried on the 20th
> of this month with 20 minutes of information under very good skys and
> position and came up with nothing. Checked at
> http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iau/lists/LastCometObs.html
> and it appears the comet has gotten dimmer.

I imaged it on 04/30/07 at 22:42 UT from A33 (Kirchheim, 0.5 m, f/5 Newtonian) with
the nearly full moon 60 deg away. 10 stacked 180 sec exposures gave a smudge of mag
18.4.

Clear skies
Bernd

Bernd Brinkmann
Sternwarte Herne, MPC code A18

http://www.sternwarte-herne.de
info@sternwarte-herne.de 

Date:  Mon, 21 May 2007 23:35:52 -0000

Subject:  Re: C/2007 F1 - ?
Thanks Bernd.
Checked your web sight at the link and will go back to do some more
reading when time allows. Do you have the latest image of C/2007 F1
posted anywhere? When you imaged the comet was it at the cordinates
as it should have been?
Mike H.

Date:  Wed, 23 May 2007 21:04:59 -0000
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: C/2007 F1 - ?
I recently attempted it and detected it just once several weekends ago.
I did not get enough sub frames to get enough SNR to make two MPC
observations. The next night out a week later, it had faded for me to
the point I could no longer detect it with lots more stacked frames. I
gave up on it.

I have a 12 inch SCT which I can autoguide with as long as needed
provided the comet is not moving too fast at F/6.3 with an AO-7. My
CCD camera (ST-2000XCM) does not have the sensitivity of your ST-10.

Have you tried binning 2x2. This works for me.
C/2007F1 has faded beyond my capability.

Last weekend I was successful with C/2006 V1, C/2003 WT42, C/2007 E2,
C2007 G1, 96P, C/2005 L3, 99P, and C/2002 VQ94.

Other bright comets are behind trees (29P and C/2007E1) or below
horizon from my location, or have become too faint for me (87P,
C/2007F1).

Date:  Thu, 31 May 2007 18:31:37 +1200
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Photo of C/2007K5 (Lovejoy)
Hi all,

here's a rather ugly photo and info about Terry's new comet (C/2007 K5) taken with a 41cm (16") @f5.2 Newtonian and SBIG STL11000M CCD last night (24 hours ago) - Wednesday 2007 May 30.25-29 (0600 - 0700 hours) UT. The sublights were one minute due to the very bright Moon. North is up and East is left. The FOV has been cropped to about 30' x 20'.

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet2007k5-lovejoy.htm
or
http://tinyurl.com/36f83v

Cheers

John Drummond (E94)
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 177° 53', S 38° 37'
Email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Website: www.possumobservatory.co.nz

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Sun, 03 Jun 2007 04:24:43 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2007 E2 - 2007/06/03
http://www.fototime.com/F70DCB644984A9B/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sun, 03 Jun 2007 04:25:54 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2007 WD4 - 2007/06/03
http://www.fototime.com/2961C674EFBA5FE/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sun, 03 Jun 2007 19:23:47 +1000
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy 2007 K5
I've posted an image of this comet at:

http://tinyurl.com/22ynmg

It is a stack of 9 x 90sec exposures with a 14". Image size is about 3 arc mins on each
side. By way of reference, the magnitudes of the bright star at the top left corner, and
the brightest of the group of stars very close to the comet (the one just under and to the
left) - extracted from the NOMAD catalogue are:

Mb Mr
12.09 11.88
14.81 14.53

I should add that a close look at the stacked images - esp. stacking sub-groups and
blinking them, does not indicate the presence of any tail - just a circular coma. To the
extent that the image suggests the possibility of a tail, the stars close below the
nucleus lead to a false assessment.

I've also done an update to the orbit solution. While I have again forced e=1, the initial
solution had e very close to 1 (a full solution gives a nominal e of 0.987 with no
noticeable improvement in the residuals - which means it should be forced to 1 at this
time. This implies the orbit is now fairly good.) There is not much change in the solution
since yesterday - about 0.2 deg in several of the elements...

Orbital elements:
C/2007 K5
Perihelion 2007 May 2.442719 TT Constraint: e=1
Epoch 2007 Jun 2.0 TT = JDT 2454253.5 Find_Orb
q 1.154789 (2000.0) P Q
H 13.8 Peri. 256.05282 0.13648578 -0.96727067
Node 193.67539 0.77000924 -0.03227012
e 1.0 Incl. 64.79638 -0.62326350 -0.25168646
>From 13 observations 2007 May 29-June 3; RMS error 0.773 arcseconds

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia 

Date:  Sun, 03 Jun 2007 23:26:38 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: C/2007 WD4 - 2007/06/03

corrected. Sorry!
Mike H.

Date:  Tue, 05 Jun 2007 19:40:26 +1000
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Re: Comet Lovejoy 2007 K5
I got some more astrometry tonite, and derived the following orbit - which is not much
different from the orbit of 2 days ago.

Orbital elements:
C/2007 K5
Perihelion 2007 May 2.394050 TT Constraint: e=1
Epoch 2007 Jun 2.0 TT = JDT 2454253.5 Find_Orb
q 1.154518 (2000.0) P Q
H 14.1 Peri. 256.00263 0.13749497 -0.96718908
Node 193.65687 0.76995568 -0.03131894
e 1.0 Incl. 64.80016 -0.62310783 -0.25211982
>From 15 observations 2007 May 29-June 5; RMS error 0.752 arcseconds

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

> Orbital elements:
> C/2007 K5
> Perihelion 2007 May 2.442719 TT Constraint: e=1
> Epoch 2007 Jun 2.0 TT = JDT 2454253.5 Find_Orb
> q 1.154789 (2000.0) P Q
> H 13.8 Peri. 256.05282 0.13648578 -0.96727067
> Node 193.67539 0.77000924 -0.03227012
> e 1.0 Incl. 64.79638 -0.62326350 -0.25168646
> From 13 observations 2007 May 29-June 3; RMS error 0.773 arcseconds
>
> Dave Herald
> Canberra, Australia
>

Date:  Tue, 05 Jun 2007 15:26:41 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2003 WT42 - 20070604
http://www.fototime.com/2934EEFA1991525/orig.jpg 

Date:  Tue, 05 Jun 2007 16:23:47 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2006 WD4 - 20070604
http://www.fototime.com/F691BD9AFE47CD6/orig.jpg 

Date:  Tue, 05 Jun 2007 12:15:11 -0500
From:  Bob King 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2006 WD4 - 20070604
Hi Mike,
Great image! I was trying to see this comet last night but wasn't sure of
seeing it. Could you tell me what time you shot the photo and which
direction is north? It would help in estimating how bright the comet was in
relation to the starfield for me. Many thanks!
Bob

From:  Juan Jose Gonzalez Suarez

Bob,

If I'm right, the time is June 4th, 3:30 UT approx., and North is up. The
brightest star is TYC 1417-765-1, mag. 9.59.

Hope it helps.

Clear skies,

Juan Jose Gonzalez

Date:  Tue, 05 Jun 2007 19:19:20 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: C/2006 WD4 - 20070604


Thanks Bob
The image shows N up and E left. Just in front of the comet is a
faint galaxy PGC 28006 mag 15.7. Below the dash at the bottom is star
GSC 1416 1100 mag 9.41. Time was 03:19UT or 10:13pm my time Central
Mike

Date:  Tue, 05 Jun 2007 14:50:57 -0500
From:  Bob King 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: C/2006 WD4 - 20070604
Juan,
Yes, I was out trying to find both Lemmon and C/2005 L3 Mc Naught. L3 was
faint but relatively easy to see at 13 mag with a stellar nucleus as viewed
in my 37cm reflector. It was only 30" across. Lemmon was a great challenge
because of its lower elevation. I could only suspect it so I was hoping to
use your image as a guide to its brightness. Tonight's skies look good so
I'm going to try again. Thanks for all of your detailed information - it
really helps.
Bob

Date:  Fri, 06 Jul 2007 20:21:46 -0000
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: C2006VZ13
Very nice comet image. Thanks for posting.

>From TheSky6 view for your July 5, 2007 2102UT, your image
orientation appears to be North up and East left, the inner coma
appears extended in PA ~185, as in development of tail. Seems more
obvious in red channel. Outer coma appears very diffuse and larger
in green channel with a diameter of about 6 to 7 arc mnutes. (arc
distance from GSC 4434:1175to GSC 4434:972)

Best wishes,
Charles Bell
http://cometskies.com

Hi at all,

http://comete.uai.it/comete/C2006VZ13_070706.jpg

elaborating the image, him note that the comet is following the evolution
of other comets, seen in these last years,
particularly with the filter LS are seen two throws depart from the forgery nucleus.

C/2005 L3 (McNaught) July 8, 2007 0526UT
11x120s 0.3m SCT@F/6.3 + ST2000XCM binned 2x2 + AO7
C. Bell H47 Vicksburg
Coma diameter ~16 arc secs PA 180
CK05L030 C2007 07 08.22663 17 34 58.50 -02 36 21.0 15.6
N H47

http://www.cometskies.com/images/C2005L3-07082007-0526UT.jpg

C/2007 G1 (LINEAR) July 8, 2007 0432UT
9x300s 0.3m SCT@F/6.3 + ST2000XCM binned 2x2 + AO7
C. Bell H47 Vicksburg
Coma diameter ~12 arc secs
CK07G010 C2007 07 08.18868 16 59 13.71 +33 00 56.0 17.1
N H47

http://www.cometskies.com/images/C2007G1-07072007-0432UT.jpg

Date:  Tue, 10 Jul 2007 17:38:22 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  C/2006 VZ13  100 minutes animation
It is racing though Draco at 8.4 arc seconds per minute at magnitude
~ 8.4. I was limited to 45 second exposures when I imaged it to
avoid blur.

Let me know what you think of the movie. Note that I have really
squashed the file size to permit rapid down load. It is only 679 kB.

It was really hard for me to stretch all the frames the same because
the high cirrus cloud layer was rapidly changing. I had to manually
adjust each frame to match the previous one. I've probably invested
six hours in image processing and composing the web page.

Images, associated data, imaging notes and animation at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Please take a look and give me some feedback. This was quite a
processing challenge for me. Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Pier Design Paper: http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/Pier_Design.htm 

Date:  Tue, 10 Jul 2007 12:29:19 -1000
From:  Carey Johnson 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] C/2006 VZ13 (LINEAR) Animation
Giovanni,

I couldn't really get it to stand out, I could barely make it out as I was
adjusting the curves.

But it looked like one of the images posted here earlier:

http://comete.uai.it/comete/C2006VZ13_070706.jpg

Below is the explination I gave in another group.

Carey

>Well here is my finished image:

http://aisig.sdaa.org/astroblogDetail.asp?imgID=1580&UserID=54

http://aisig.sdaa.org/objects.asp

The comet is coming in at a funny angle and not much tail being
shown.

http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=C%2F2006+VZ13&orb=1

Here is one someone else took:

http://tinyurl.com/ysnrte

In my image Up is to the right. Since it was just over Polaris,
Polaris is
to the Left.

So the tail should be to the 5 o'clock position, and the path of
motion is
toward 2 o'clock.

Hey that all works out.

And what I was seeing looks like this:

http://comete.uai.it/comete/C2006VZ13_070706.jpg

where there was a reddish tail going against/across the star
trails.

On another note:

With a q (perihelion) of 1.015 (almost the same distance from
the Sun as
Earth (1.0 AU)
So it almost crosses Earths orbit... Unfortunately just Outside
or we could
have gotten a new meteor shower next year.

http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=C%2F2006+VZ13&orb=1

If you change the date of Epoch by 20 days
from May 6
to May 26th
It would have passed only 0.02 AU from Earth on May 29th.

http://www.geocities.com/quarkcsj/2006VZ13.html

Carey

>From: "gvnn64\@libero\.it"
>Reply-To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com

Date:  Wed, 11 Jul 2007 10:41:27 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] C/2006 VZ13 (LINEAR) Animation
Hello Carey and Jeff,
thanks for your comments. The shape of this feature seems to point to an ion tail, that is normally blue (CO+ ions). However a reddish hue can be indicative of H2O+ (or dust; but the latter sound unlikely, since this comet has not shown till now great dust productions).
Cheers,
Giovanni

> Giovanni,
>
> I couldn't really get it to stand out, I could barely make it out as I was
> adjusting the curves.

Date:  Tue, 10 Jul 2007 22:56:48 -1000
From:  Carey Johnson 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] C/2006 VZ13 (LINEAR) Animation
yes, I was surprised to see that the tail was in anti-solar direction where
you would expect to find the ion tail, and not in the path of travel where
you would expect a dust tail. And the reddish color I would expect dust not
ion.

The tail is so short that it is covered by the glow of the coma.
My images were for 120 seconds. I wonder if I would get less glow and more
tail by taking more short exposures.

I have the next 2 days off, and will be out again Saturday.

So I'll see if I can get more.

Carey

Date:  Wed, 11 Jul 2007 23:11:32 +1000
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  C.2006 P1 McNaught - current appearance
Have you wondered what Comet McNaught looks like now? Its current declination is -71 deg,
and it has faded to a very ordinary object. I've just posted an image taken this evening
at:
http://tinyurl.com/2pk8gj

The image is a stack of 5 x 180 sec exposures, and is about 5 arc mins across. The image
shows a small coma somewhat less than 1 arc min across (although at higher f-ratio systems
a larger coma should be visible.),

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia 

Date:  Thu, 12 Jul 2007 00:00:15 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  C/2006 VZ13 (LINEAR) on 2007, July 11th
> The tail is so short that it is covered by the glow of the coma.

Hi Carey,
in the image we just shoot (twilight conditions) it's possible to appreciate its extension to, at least, 15'. However it's pretty faint, and you need to stretch quite a lot the image settings to evidence it.
http://tinyurl.com/2lp65v
>From its appearance, I think that it's definitely an ion tail.
Cheers,
Giovanni, Vincenzo and Ernesto

I have uploaed an image of C2006 VZ13 Linear taken on July 8, 2007
3:51 UT. I shows sign of a faint tail in P.A. 160 degrees. Is this
the same feature in your later images?

John D Sabia 

Date:  Thu, 12 Jul 2007 15:20:30 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] Re: C/2006 VZ13 (LINEAR) on 2007, July 11th
> I have uploaed an image of C2006 VZ13 Linear taken on July 8, 2007
> 3:51 UT. I shows sign of a faint tail in P.A. 160 degrees. Is this
> the same feature in your later images?

Hi John,
nice shot, congratulations. Yes, I think that it's the same stuff we were talking about. However, in order to extract it from the sky background more clearly, you need to stack a number of images and play a little with the image-processing.
Cheers,
Giovanni

I see that C/2006VZ13 is very close to the spindle shaped mag 11 galaxy NGC 5907 over the next few hours (about 30' away)... I sure won't see it from New Zealand!

Date:  Fri, 13 Jul 2007 01:38:56 -0000
From:  sabiajohn 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] Re: C/2006 VZ13 (LINEAR) on 2007, July 11th
--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "gvnn64\@...\.it"
wrote:
>
> Hi John,
> nice shot, congratulations. Yes, I think that it's the same stuff
we were talking about. However, in order to extract it from the sky
background more clearly, you need to stack a number of images and
play a little with the image-processing.
> Cheers,
> Giovanni

Thanks Giovanni. Just getting familar with the software and
evaluating the mount's polar alignment and tracking. The comet is
moving fast, I should have taken more Track and Accumulate series at
f/3.3. But, I reset to prime focus and tested image exposure and
tracking at that focal length.
I did not track and accumulate comet images therefore it took me
some time to process the series of images. Will upload that image
soon. Spend more time imaging other deepsky globulars and the Ring.

John D. Sabia

Date:  Fri, 13 Jul 2007 22:10:10 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  C/2006 VZ13 Complete with Ion Tail
The comet has an ion tail that I had difficulty bringing out in my
processing. It is just barely apparent in my stack of 40 x 60s.
However, I was able to bring out what appears to be a 15 arc minute
tail using the Larson-Sekanina filter in AstroArt 3.0. I realize
this is a somewhat "dangerous" filter since one can easily introduce
no end of interesting artifacts. I would thus appreciate feedback
from the comet cognoscenti (and everyone else) on whether my
processing is legitimate.

Images, associated data, imaging notes and all at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Please take a look and give me some feedback. Thank you for
visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Pier Design Paper: http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/Pier_Design.htm 

Date:  Fri, 13 Jul 2007 12:43:51 -1000
From:  Carey Johnson 
Subject:  RE: [Comet-Images] New file uploaded to Comet-Images
This is the best image I've seen yet. The coma looks a little
over-processed but you can make out the tail nicely.

Nicely done!

Carey

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Sat, 14 Jul 2007 14:02:09 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] C/2006 VZ13 Complete with Ion Tail
> I would thus appreciate feedback
> from the comet cognoscenti (and everyone else) on whether my
> processing is legitimate.

Hello Dennis,
your image is really nice (you have plenty of signal out of the coma). The faint tail visible in your Larson-Sekanina output is genuine.

Here I detail what I normally do applying the LS filter: first I locate the brightest pixel within the coma; this is the photometric center of the false nucleus, and we must refer (click on it with the mouse) on it in order to proceed further (remember: it must no be saturated, otherwise all the process will be compromised). Then it must be decided with which parameter the software has to be feed. Normally I start with delta=0 and alpha= 30 degrees. With this settings you can normally evidence radial structures that depart from the central condensation (i.e. tails, rays, jets, etc.). If you enter a delta parameter different from zero (either positive or negative) and several combinations of alpha angles, it shold be helpful to extract any possible concentric feature to the central condensation (like shells, halos, etc.). How to know which parameters one has to adopt? Well, there is no fixed recipe, just try and error. Particular care has to be taken to avoid the interference of stars (trailed or point-like) within the coma; for this reason, in crowded star fields is better to "median" a number of single exposures (the median will nearly delete the star trails). The LS is an "easy" method that enables to get a quick look at the coma; however, as you correctly pointed out, it is prone to generate artifacts, so a cross check with other image processing routines is needed, if you want to be sure about the results. In a sense, one can define the Larson-Sekanina filtering as "fast & dirty".
I will send you privately the output of my own experiments on your nice shot.
Cheers,
Giovanni

------------------------------------------------------
Scegli infostrada: ADSL gratis per tutta lestate e telefoni senza canone Telecom
http://click.libero.it/infostrada

Date:  Sun, 22 Jul 2007 10:13:52 -1000
From:  Carey Johnson 
Subject:  RE: [Comet-Images] Re: comet VZ 13 LINEAR
>I guess I was the only one
>that though the tail of this comet would have extended out a lot more
>after it's closest aproach to earth.

well, perihelion is yet to come on August 10th.
but it will only be .055 AU closer to the Sun
and .46 AU further from Earth
as Earth heads East and the comet heads West and South.

Carey

> >
>
> what to say... simply stupendous! ;-)))
>
> Rolando
>

Date:  Sat, 28 Jul 2007 02:25:39 -0000
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Comet P/2007 N2 (NEAT) July 22, 2007 0533UT
Comet P/2007 N2 (NEAT) July 22, 2007 0533UT

http://www.cometskies.com/images/P2007N2-07222007-0533UT.jpg

12 x 120 sec stack
12 inch Meade LX-200GPS @F/6.3
ST-2000XCM binned 2x2
Self guided with AO7

Time Stamp: 2007 07 22, 5:32:58 UT
Motion: 4.61"/min in PA 20.8°
Astrometrica magnitude: 18.2N
Astrometry:
PK07N020 C2007 07 22.23123 17 25 12.18 +00 19 01.5 18.2
N H47 

Date:  Sat, 28 Jul 2007 09:31:57 +0300
From:  "V. Nevski" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet P/2007 N2 (NEAT) July 22, 2007 0533UT
I apologize, but at your parameters of telescope and exposure, the image of
comet it has turned out strongly smeared.
It is desirable to apply exposures to this comet no more 30sec then it is
possible to receive much more details.
For example, comet 2007N2 on July, 26:
http://www.nevski.nm.ru/Rus/Observing/ccdims/2007N2.jpg

Vitali Nevski

> Comet P/2007 N2 (NEAT) July 22, 2007 0533UT
>
> http://www.cometskies.com/images/P2007N2-07222007-0533UT.jpg
>
> 12 x 120 sec stack
> 12 inch Meade LX-200GPS @F/6.3
> ST-2000XCM binned 2x2
> Self guided with AO7
>
> Time Stamp: 2007 07 22, 5:32:58 UT
> Motion: 4.61"/min in PA 20.8
> Astrometrica magnitude: 18.2N
> Astrometry:
> PK07N020 C2007 07 22.23123 17 25 12.18 +00 19 01.5 18.2
> N H47
>

-------
? - : http://tourism.tut.by 

Date:  Sat, 28 Jul 2007 11:27:22 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet P/2007 N2 (NEAT) July 22, 2007 0533UT
Thank you for your suggestion and critique Vitali. I
do have much to learn. Your image of P/2007 N2 is very
sharp showing a nicely defined short tail. Thank you
for sharing the info about it.

This was my first attempt at this newly recovered
comet. My sky was very humid that evening. I was not
sure I would even capture anything. I had no idea then
there was a tail. I was not aware that the motion was
so high until I stacked the images with Astrometica
the next afternoon. Those are my mistakes for not
checking and planning better.

Looking again at the announcement in IAUC 8856: P/2007
N2 = P/2002 O5 issued 2007 July 16, there is mention
of a tail about 15" long in p.a. 135 deg by G.
Lombardi and E. Pettarin (Farra d'Isonzo, Italy).

Also looking back on posts in this group, there have
been four image posts of P/2007 N2 since the IAUC on
July 15, 2007. While no one mentioned a tail, a small
tail is only obvious (at least to me) in Giovanni and
Ernesto's excellent image posted on Mon Jul 16, 2007
5:48 pm at http://tinyurl.com/34lm35

Best wishes,
Charles

Date:  Mon, 30 Jul 2007 14:19:29 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  P/2003 R5 - ?
I have a question. I found the following information for
P/Hoenig (2003 R5) Sep 11.3 0.05 3.99 2 12.5 5.0 6?
When I look for the animated orbit (http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/orbits/) it
continues to bring up C/3003 R5 a SOHO comet. Guide will not give me
anything but invaled object. Is there another designation for this
comet? I am sure I am just not putting the correct name in.
Mike H. 

Date:  Mon, 30 Jul 2007 17:03:01 -0000
From:  amar10sharmaa 
Subject:  Re: P/2003 R5 - ?
Hello Mike, I had coincidentally questioned about the very similar
topic on comets-ml during beginning of February. I came across this
comet, with a 6th mag prediction and a '?' while going through the
BAA's "A Comet's Tale" online file and "Comet Prospects for 2007". You
can see my post with heading "BAA's journals (correction?)" and the
answers that followed in comets-ml.

http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/comets-ml/message/11777 (#11777)

You can follow messages 11778, 11781, 11784, 11789, 11799, 11800,
11801 for further answers by some members. Probably that might help. I
am still not clear about the naming of the comet and was going to
re-start the thread once we get close to September (the perihelion).
Thanking You. Amar.

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "tricks46" wrote:

> P/Hoenig (2003 R5) Sep 11.3 0.05 3.99 2 12.5 5.0 6?

> comet? I am sure I am just not putting the correct name in.
> Mike H.

anyone hears otherwise, please let me know.

Date:  Sat, 04 Aug 2007 21:41:49 -0000
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  C/2007 M3 (NEAT) July 29, 2007 0517UT
C/2007 M3 (NEAT) July 29, 2007 0517UT

http://www.cometskies.com/images/C2007M3-07292007-0517UT.jpg

My second attempt at this one. Imaged under very humid sky conditions.
This is an Astrometrica stack of all 26 images taken for observations
(26 x 60 secs).

Time Stamp: 2007 07 29, 5:16:41 UT
Motion: 1.51"/min in PA 256.3°
Pixel Size: 1.51" x 1.51"
Field of View: 20.2' x 15.1' 

Date:  Sat, 04 Aug 2007 21:49:54 -0000
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  C/2005 L3 (McNaught) August 4, 2007 0241UT
C/2005 L3 (McNaught) August 4, 2007 0241UT

http://www.cometskies.com/images/C2005L3-08042007-0241UT.jpg

Astrometrica stack of all images taken for observations (6 x 180sec).
Time Stamp: 2007 08 04, 2:41:03 UT
Motion: 0.51"/min in PA 277.0°
Pixel Size: 1.51" x 1.51"
Field of View: 20.2' x 15.1'

The central coma measures approximately 18 arc secs in diameter.
The coma is extended about 45 arcs in PA 220. This looks to me like it
might be the beginnings of a fan tail. 

Date:  Sun, 05 Aug 2007 20:10:32 -0000
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: C/2005 L3 (McNaught) August 4, 2007 0241UT
Correction:
coma extended in PA 130

Date:  Sun, 12 Aug 2007 14:55:08 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  8P - 2007/08/12 - Animation
This is a close call for my equiptment. 2 frame animation each 300
seconds of exposure. Start at 03-51:33 and last at 05-39:36. Arrows
show position starting and second image with movement to the N/E. (up &
left) Last shows hint of possible tail which has been shown here
before, I think. File is small and large versions.

http://www.fototime.com/809824BC46E44D1/standard.jpg

http://www.fototime.com/809824BC46E44D1/orig.gif

Thanks Mike H.

Date:  Thu, 16 Aug 2007 09:25:17 +0300
From:  "V. Nevski" 
Subject:  17P
Image of 17P/Holmes:
http://www.astronomy.ru/forum/index.php?action=dlattach;topic=23449.0;attach=93696;image 

Date:  Thu, 16 Aug 2007 05:26:18 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Very unusual sky event of August 16
A very interesting event was captured this morning at ASO (Petit Jean Mountain South MPC
H45) while acquiring a routine CCD image for asteroid astrometry. What appears to be a
major breakup of some object passing through the frame was caught in a 60-second
exposure of NEO 2007 PP9 in the constellation of Aquarius at 09:24 U.T. (Aug. 16).

A full description of the capture and the actual image is posted on the ASO website News
Section at:
http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php?topic=1385.0

Your suggestions, comments and speculations are welcome. Aften recording tens of
thousands of routine images with all sorts of space debris passing through, I frankly
have never seen anything to compare with this unusual event.

Enjoy pondering....!

Dr. Clay
-------------
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/ 

Date:  Thu, 16 Aug 2007 11:46:27 -0000
From:  vitalinevski 
Subject:  Re: 17P
I apologize for an erroneous link.
Has corrected: http://www.nevski.nm.ru/Rus/Observing/ccdims/17p.jpg

-----------------------------------------------------------------
Vitali Nevski, B42 - Vitebsk observatory (Belarus)
http://www.nevski.nm.ru/eng/

Date:  Mon, 03 Sep 2007 19:06:35 -0000
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  C/2005 L3 (McNaught) September 1, 2007 0209UT
C/2005 L3 (McNaught) September 1, 2007 0209UT
http://www.cometskies.com/images/C2005L3-09012007-0209UT.jpg
Central condensation ~18"
Extended coma diameter ~30" appeared slightly elongated in PA150
7x300s images stacked with Astrometrica
Astrometrica CCD Magnitude estimate ~16.1

Time Stamp: 2007 09 01, 2:09:23 UT
Motion: 0.25"/min in PA 272.3°
Center Coordinates: RA = 16h 51m 59.00s, De = -01° 08' 27.2"
Focal Length = 2002.6mm, Rotation = -4.94°
Pixel Size: 1.51" x 1.51", Field of View: 20.2' x 15.1'
Telescope: 12 inch Meade 200LX-GPS @f/6.3 (0.3m SCT)
CCD: ST-2000XCM autoguided by AO7

C. Bell H47 Vicksburg
http://www.cometskies.com 

Date:  Mon, 03 Sep 2007 09:10:11 +0200
From:  francois kugel 
Subject:  8P/Tuttle August 30.84

Inst = Tel 0.5-m f/3 reflector + ccd stl 11k

Date:  Sun, 23 Sep 2007 15:31:22 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  DSLR Astrophotography
Greetings. A question to ask of all the members. As you know I
consider the members of this board the best at imaging comets in the
world. I've always tried to image and expand with the equipment I
have. I am currently using a ST10xmei and ST2000xm ccd. The digital
single lense reflex camera will extend with my 5" TV127is refractor
what my CFW8 and ccd's are doing now but I am after a single shot color
with the larger FOV and feel the DSLR's have reached a point that look
appealing over buying a larger ccd such as thge 11000. Can you please
give me your own oppinion of what you would use or what you are using.
My budget is not unlimited but the "you get what you pay for" is a true
statement in most cases. Attaching the camera, pix, cost, ease of use,
true color output, chip noise, manual setup, shutter speed are some
considerations for me. I am looking at future bright comets for this
camera although it will be used in everyday work/play with a lense.
Thanks for your time and if the members feel this is not comet related
please answer off page at the listed email tricks46@yahoo.com .
Looking forward to your replys.
Mike H. 

Date:  Sun, 23 Sep 2007 18:34:22 +0200
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] DSLR Astrophotography
> Thanks for your time and if the members feel this is not comet related
> please answer off page at the listed email tricks46@yahoo.com .
> Looking forward to your replys.
> Mike H.

Hi Mike, I try to give you an answer in base to my experience.

for different years I have tried to photograph the comets with ccd Sbig and filters or
also ccd Sony and filters.
however these beautiful objects have the particularity to be, a lot of times, fast and
visible to strange times: just before the dawn or shortly after the sunset...
for this, I have noticed whether to use the traditional ccds with the filters, to the
times, it is really difficult.

for this, two years ago I have purchased a ccd of the Starlight the SXVM25C and honestly I
can say that it works really well!

in comparison to the DSLR, I have compared this with my partners, you have from 1 to 2
mags. in more, you don't have to make the dark and he is cooled for which, in the summer,
you don't have big problems.

But there are two problems:
1) it is that you owe, with openings F5, to do at least 5 minutes of laying, better if
longer; in contrary case you owe "to work" more to balance the colors.
2) because of the strong sensibility, in comparison to the DLSRs, the stars have the
tendency to saturate and to become white, with a light halo (using my NP 101)

the other problem is the cost and the dimensions of the sensor that are not comparable to
the format 36mm.

an alternative could be the modified DSLRs, but you lose in sensibility and in the summer
they don't work very well.

regards
Rolando

PS: I hope that my monstrous English is comprehensible... ;-))) 

Date:  Sun, 23 Sep 2007 22:39:00 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: DSLR Astrophotography
Thanks Rolando. That is the kind of information I am looking for.
This is a new product to me and a new possiblity I am now reading
about and learning. I hope others will express there opinions.
Mike

Date:  Mon, 24 Sep 2007 09:58:24 -0000
From:  Terry Lovejoy 
Subject:  Re: DSLR Astrophotography
Mike,

The pros for DSLRs:

* Low cost + Large field of view.
* Moderate sensitivity, the blue and green pixels well matched to
comet photography.
* One shot.
* Very low read noise in some cameras.
* Live view (depending on model) very handy for focusing.
* Autofocus also works well on bright stars.
* Dual daytime use.

The cons of DSLRS:

* Not as sensitive as CCDs (for stars about 1 mag difference in
limiting magnitude, but perhaps less for comets - see my note above).
* Dark Calibration can be tricky because there is no temperature
regulation at the sensor.
* More artifacts in images. eg. you will often see faint vertical
and horizontal banding in images that can be hard to process out.
* Limited dynamic range (12 bits instead of 16), although this is
changing.
* Raw images are sometimes filtered with noise reduction (some
models are known to apply noise reduction to long exposures). This
can hurt sensitivity.

I have done a lot testing of DSLR cameras as well as monochrome CCDs
and in terms of quantum efficiency there is fair hit, although peak
green sensitivity seems to be around 40-50% (for the green pixels).
Although we are waiting for more tests its possible the new Nikon D3
may have pushed quantum efficiency to new levels for consumer
cameras. Pity its $5000!

Have you had a look into the Kodak KAF-9000 based cameras? The
sensor is huge (38 x 38 mm) with Quantum efficiency around 65%
(peaking around green) has antiblooming and low read/dark noise.
These sensors cost about the same as the KAF-3200ME that goes into
the ST10XME (~$3000) so hopefully SBIG can do one at a similiar cost
to the the ST10XME.

Terry 

Date:  Tue, 25 Sep 2007 06:10:18 -0000
From:  Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com

a file has been uploaded to the Files area of the Comet-Images
group.

schmidtcamera2500

Date:  Tue, 25 Sep 2007 13:06:06 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: DSLR Astrophotography
Terry.
Your method of comet searching is very smart. I can remember some
very faint comets with little central condensation this might have
been helpfull in discovery. C/2005 K2 comes to mind.
http://fototime.com/B7169411BF80838/orig.
Are you still using the 300D and 350D cameras?
Mike

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Terry Lovejoy"
wrote:
>
> Mike,
>
> The pros for DSLRs:
>
> * Low cost + Large field of view.
> * Moderate sensitivity, the blue and green pixels well matched to
> comet photography.
> * One shot.
> * Very low read noise in some cameras.
> * Live view (depending on model) very handy for focusing.
> * Autofocus also works well on bright stars.
> * Dual daytime use.
>
> The cons of DSLRS:
>
> * Not as sensitive as CCDs (for stars about 1 mag difference in
> limiting magnitude, but perhaps less for comets - see my note
above).
> * Dark Calibration can be tricky because there is no temperature
> regulation at the sensor.
> * More artifacts in images. eg. you will often see faint vertical
> and horizontal banding in images that can be hard to process out.
> * Limited dynamic range (12 bits instead of 16), although this is
> changing.
> * Raw images are sometimes filtered with noise reduction (some
> models are known to apply noise reduction to long exposures). This
> can hurt sensitivity.
>
> I have done a lot testing of DSLR cameras as well as monochrome
CCDs
> and in terms of quantum efficiency there is fair hit, although peak
> green sensitivity seems to be around 40-50% (for the green pixels).
> Although we are waiting for more tests its possible the new Nikon
D3
> may have pushed quantum efficiency to new levels for consumer
> cameras. Pity its $5000!
>
> Have you had a look into the Kodak KAF-9000 based cameras? The
> sensor is huge (38 x 38 mm) with Quantum efficiency around 65%
> (peaking around green) has antiblooming and low read/dark noise.
> These sensors cost about the same as the KAF-3200ME that goes into
> the ST10XME (~$3000) so hopefully SBIG can do one at a similiar
cost
> to the the ST10XME.
>
> Terry
> 

Date:  Tue, 25 Sep 2007 15:49:37 +0200
From:  walcom77 
Subject:  Comet C/2006 S5 ( Hill ) + with NGC 2266
Hi All,

Here You can find the rendez-vous image of comet C/2006 S5 ( Hill )
with NGC 2266. The details are in the caption of the image:

http://tinyurl.com/29wzr6

Cheers,

Ernesto Guido and Giovanni Sostero (AFAM - Remanzacco Obs. - mpc 473)
http://www.afamweb.com 

Date:  Tue, 25 Sep 2007 16:12:15 +0200
From:  walcom77 
Subject:  Comet P/2007 H1
Hi All,

Here You can find our latest image of comet P/2007 H1. The details are
in the caption of the image:

http://tinyurl.com/2cf5sw

Cheers,

Ernesto Guido and Giovanni Sostero (AFAM - Remanzacco Obs. - mpc 473)
http://www.afamweb.com

Date:  Fri, 28 Sep 2007 06:04:05 -0000
From:  Terry Lovejoy 
Subject:  Re: DSLR Astrophotography
Hi Mike,

I can't view thay image..?

Yes I still use the 300D and 350D, will continue to do so until a
better imaging solution becomes available at a reasonable price :)

Terry

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "tricks46" wrote:
>
> Terry.
> Your method of comet searching is very smart. I can remember
some
> very faint comets with little central condensation this might have
> been helpfull in discovery. C/2005 K2 comes to mind.
> http://fototime.com/B7169411BF80838/orig.
> Are you still using the 300D and 350D cameras?
> Mike
>
> --- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Terry Lovejoy"
> wrote:
> >
> > Mike,
> >
> > The pros for DSLRs:
> >
> > * Low cost + Large field of view.
> > * Moderate sensitivity, the blue and green pixels well matched
to
> > comet photography.
> > * One shot.
> > * Very low read noise in some cameras.
> > * Live view (depending on model) very handy for focusing.
> > * Autofocus also works well on bright stars.
> > * Dual daytime use.
> >
> > The cons of DSLRS:
> >
> > * Not as sensitive as CCDs (for stars about 1 mag difference in
> > limiting magnitude, but perhaps less for comets - see my note
> above).
> > * Dark Calibration can be tricky because there is no temperature
> > regulation at the sensor.
> > * More artifacts in images. eg. you will often see faint
vertical
> > and horizontal banding in images that can be hard to process out.
> > * Limited dynamic range (12 bits instead of 16), although this
is
> > changing.
> > * Raw images are sometimes filtered with noise reduction (some
> > models are known to apply noise reduction to long exposures).
This
> > can hurt sensitivity.
> >
> > I have done a lot testing of DSLR cameras as well as monochrome
> CCDs
> > and in terms of quantum efficiency there is fair hit, although
peak
> > green sensitivity seems to be around 40-50% (for the green
pixels).
> > Although we are waiting for more tests its possible the new
Nikon
> D3
> > may have pushed quantum efficiency to new levels for consumer
> > cameras. Pity its $5000!
> >
> > Have you had a look into the Kodak KAF-9000 based cameras? The
> > sensor is huge (38 x 38 mm) with Quantum efficiency around 65%
> > (peaking around green) has antiblooming and low read/dark
noise.
> > These sensors cost about the same as the KAF-3200ME that goes
into
> > the ST10XME (~$3000) so hopefully SBIG can do one at a similiar
> cost
> > to the the ST10XME.
> >
> > Terry
> >
>

> > > * Low cost + Large field of view.
> > > * Moderate sensitivity, the blue and green pixels well matched
> to
> > > comet photography.
> > > * One shot.
> > > * Very low read noise in some cameras.
> > > * Live view (depending on model) very handy for focusing.
> > > * Autofocus also works well on bright stars.
> > > * Dual daytime use.
> > >
> > > The cons of DSLRS:
> > >
> > > * Not as sensitive as CCDs (for stars about 1 mag difference in
> > > limiting magnitude, but perhaps less for comets - see my note
> > above).
> > > * Dark Calibration can be tricky because there is no
temperature
> > > regulation at the sensor.
> > > * More artifacts in images. eg. you will often see faint
> vertical
> > > and horizontal banding in images that can be hard to process
out.
> > > * Limited dynamic range (12 bits instead of 16), although this
> is
> > > changing.
> > > * Raw images are sometimes filtered with noise reduction (some
> > > models are known to apply noise reduction to long exposures).
> This
> > > can hurt sensitivity.
> > >
> > > I have done a lot testing of DSLR cameras as well as monochrome
> > CCDs
> > > and in terms of quantum efficiency there is fair hit, although
> peak
> > > green sensitivity seems to be around 40-50% (for the green
> pixels).
> > > Although we are waiting for more tests its possible the new
> Nikon
> > D3
> > > may have pushed quantum efficiency to new levels for consumer
> > > cameras. Pity its $5000!
> > >
> > > Have you had a look into the Kodak KAF-9000 based cameras? The
> > > sensor is huge (38 x 38 mm) with Quantum efficiency around 65%
> > > (peaking around green) has antiblooming and low read/dark
> noise.
> > > These sensors cost about the same as the KAF-3200ME that goes
> into
> > > the ST10XME (~$3000) so hopefully SBIG can do one at a similiar
> > cost
> > > to the the ST10XME.

Date:  Fri, 05 Oct 2007 13:18:59 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  8P-2007/10/05
Hello
A deep, dark sky when clouds were predicted allowed for some really
good comet work. This comet improved.
Mike H

http://fototime.com/B1B498EE19FDAD3/orig.jpg 

Date:  Fri, 05 Oct 2007 14:45:50 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  50P-2007/10/05
Hello.
This image of what I beleive the two arrows on the right side show
50P also contains the galaxy NGC 1058. The 2 markers #1 shows I think
a super nova or at least where there was a supernova. The #2 is
another area which I cannot ID with DSS images. Someone else might
tell if this is a star or something else. The comet was less than
expected if this is the comet.
http://www.aavso.org/publications/specialnotice/58.shtml
Thanks, Mike H.

http://fototime.com/A2322E5797B42B1/orig.jpg

> schmidtcamera2500
>

Date:  Thu, 11 Oct 2007 22:33:36 -0400
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  Comet LONEOS
Re: Loneos
Another surprise comet, one that may get to magnitude 4 is in the sky. It is
still very low on the horizon and difficult to see.

We shall see (it is now at mag 8). Once again this one has a green tint to
it so it is a little more difficult to see for some observers.

The guy who took the picture that for spaceweather.com is working towards his
silver comet award.
I encourage anyone (at ASKC or belonging to Astronomical League or another
astro club) who is interested in comets, to try for the silver award.

You get a cool pin and great certificate .

Remember that for the award you can make either sketches, ccd images or
regular photography or a combination of the 3 types.
Of the first 12 (for the silver) , 2 from that can also be before 1/1/2001 .

Those who have observers and data can send their results to me for
verification (let me know if you want the materials back) and to get your pin and
certification (includes a great photo by the late Vic Winters).

Dr. Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com), Olathe, KS: Lat 38.834, Lon
-94.778:: Eclipse sightings > http://eclipse-sightings.blogspot.com/: E.O.A.S. (Earth,
Oceans, Atmosphere and Space) Blog -
:State of Kansas-JPL NASA Solar System Ambassador: Comet Observers Award
Coordinator- Astronomy League/ Astronomical Society of Kansas, KC,
MO-Louisburg,KS: http://www.astroleague.org/al/obsclubs/comet/comet.htm: Subscribe to
(send your email to):CometObserversAwardAL-subscribe@yahoogroups.com

> 3a. Comet LONEOS
>     Posted by: "Elizabeth" ebrown2323@sbcglobal.net stardustiam23
>     Date: Tue Oct 9, 2007 11:08 am ((PDT))
>
> www.spaceweather.com has a report on Comet LONEOS and a sky map for
> tonight.  Right now it's below and to the left of the star Cor Coroli
> (?)and is in Coma Berenices below the handle of the Big Dipper. It's
> at 8th magnitude and has a greenish color.  Hopefully, I'll get to see
> it tonight.
>
> Elizabeth

Date:  Fri, 12 Oct 2007 14:40:19 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  8P - 2007/10/12
I thought some high clouds might be present on the image from the
11th. Last night improved conditions shows a nice improvement. The
galaxy in the image is about the same overall size as 8P is showing.

appears correct.

C/2007 T1 (McNaught) October 12, 2007 0046UT

http://www.cometskies.com/images/C2007T1-10122007-0046UT.jpg

Time Stamp: 2007 10 12, 0:45:58 UT
Motion: 1.78"/min in PA 192.4°
Focal Length = 2022.0mm, Rotation = -0.11°
Pixel Size: 1.51" x 1.51", Field of View: 20.1' x 15.1'

3x50sec
0.3m SCT F/6.3
ST-2000XCM binned 2x2 + AO-7

Date:  Sat, 13 Oct 2007 07:15:43 -0000
From:  schmidtcamera2500 
Subject:  Re: C/2007 T1 - 2007/10/10-I think
hi mike

this was no outburst. in the past we could see a lot of such comets.
first the brightens very fast, than the stopped.
for example, on the way to sun kudo-fujikawa stopped at 5-6mag

michael

between oct´8 and 12 the brighness of the tail doesn`t brighten.

Date:  Sat, 13 Oct 2007 12:53:19 -0400
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  nice  animation COMET LONEOS:


nice animation of the current 8th magnitude COMET LONEOS
http://spaceweather.com
10/13/2007 (if not this date go to archives)
COMET LONEOS: Comet LONEOS (C/2007 F1) is plunging toward the sun and solar
heating is doing its work: pieces of the 8th-magnitude comet are boiling off.
"We were surprised to see blobs moving in the tail," report Filipe Alves, Jan
Lameer and Jose Ribeiro at the AstroQueyras Observatory in the French Alps.
This 24-minute time-lapse movie shows the view through the observatory's 30-inch
telescope on Oct. 12th:

Comet LONEOS makes its closest approach to the sun--just outside the orbit of
Mercury--on Oct. 29th. At that time it may become faintly visible to the
unaided eye, a 4th magnitude fuzzball with an increasingly active tail. Amateur
astronomers, ready your telescopes! [sky map] [ephemeris] [3D orbit]
AL Gold comet award winner also writes
More: "This comet is so close to the horizon, it is almost too low for my
equipment," says astrophotographer Mike Holloway of Van Buren, Arkansas. "How
low? I ask my neighbor across the field to keep his cows penned up so they don't
block the view. Well maybe not quite that bad! I did manage to capture this
image on Oct. 11th using a 5-inch refracting telescope."

Dr. Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com), Olathe, KS
Comet Observers Award Coordinator- Astronomy League/ Astronomical Society
of Kansas, KC, MO-Louisburg,KS:
http://www.astroleague.org/al/obsclubs/comet/comet.htm: Subscribe to (send your email
to):CometObserversAwardAL-subscribe@yahoogroups.com

**************************************
See what's new at
http://www.aol.com

schmidtcamera2500 

Date:  Sun, 14 Oct 2007 17:52:25 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  75P - A waste of time?
Hello. The time was 2007/10/13 - 10:21 UT. N is up and E left. Skys
were extremely clear and dark. I know the possibility of finding the
comet were slim to none but you have got to try as magnitudes were
around 15. I find no reports on it but doesn't mean there are none.
Two frame animation. Star in center colored red. Movement of
equipment is shown by white spot on the left of the image. Comet
movement should be right to left with a little down angle. Guide
showed comet position to the right of the red star but I don't know.
Red arrow shows opposite side and the best possible area in the
imediate area. 2mb file
Thanks, mike H

http://fototime.com/90A679B24DACB23/standard.jpg

http://fototime.com/90A679B24DACB23/orig.gif 

Date:  Sun, 14 Oct 2007 12:56:50 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 75P - A waste of time?
Great effort!

75P is not on the current list of observable comets
from the MPC.

http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iau/Ephemerides/Comets/

Its not even on the MPC's Dates Of Last Observation Of
Comets:
http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iau/lists/LastCometObs.html

Seeichi Seiichi Yoshida's web pages show it might be
about mag 20.

http://www.aerith.net/comet/recovery.html

http://www.aerith.net/comet/catalog/0075P/2007.html

I have not been able to detect 44P, 1997V1, or C/2005
S4, despite exceptionally clear skies at H47 for 5
nights in a row. I have tried stacking exposures
totalling one hour per comet on one or more nights. It
appears that comets at mag 20 are way beyond the reach
of my equipment, 12 inch (0.3m) SCT with f/6.3 FR +
ST-2000XCM binned 2x2 and selfguided with AO-7. I've
been making subexposures limited by sky motion of 1
pixel. (arc secs/pixel / arc sec per min * 60 secs
per min = exposure time in sec per ccd pixel)

Best wishes,

Charles

--- tricks46 wrote:

> Hello. The time was 2007/10/13 - 10:21 UT. N is up
> and E left. Skys
> were extremely clear and dark. I know the
> possibility of finding the

Date:  Sun, 14 Oct 2007 22:42:23 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: 75P - A waste of time?
Thanks Charles. These animation exposures were 120 sec each.
movement in the 15 minute period was enough that as dim as the comet
is I have nothing to stack the comet on only the stars. I think you
should try 75P if you can use the astrometica software or some other
which will allow stack on the faint or unseen. Something tells me it
is there. It would be a good recovery
Mike

Date:  Sun, 14 Oct 2007 15:48:41 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  136P (Mueller) and NGC 7727 October 14, 2007 0519UT
Comet 136P (Mueller) is passing by NGC 7727, a
beautiful barred spiral galaxy in Aquarius.

136P (Mueller) and NGC 7727 October 14, 2007 0519UT

http://www.cometskies.com/images/136P-10142007-0519UT.jpg

12 x 330 sec stacked with Astrometrica by setting
comet speed to 0.

The trail of the comet is marked along with (162752)
2000 WF48 also passing through the field of view.

C. Bell H47 Vicksburg
http://www.cometskies.com/

____________________________________________________________________________________

Date:  Tue, 16 Oct 2007 03:00:01 -0000
From:  amar10sharmaa 
Subject:  Re: New file uploaded to Comet-Images
Hello All,
Amazing images in this group, as usual! Great work everyone. I would
like to ask could anyone see the short dust tail visible in some of
the images, atleast by Michael Jaeger, especially the ones on 14th
and 15th Oct? It's clearly visible there as a short and faint
extension some 20 degrees to the right of the main tail from the
coma. It appears to be 7-8 times smaller than the length of the main
tail.

Any updates on that? Is it observable visually in larger scopes by
any chance? Thank You. Amar.

PS - Which is the comet on the homepage? Can the moderator please
put a short note everytime an new homepge image is uploaded for
members to know?

Date:  Wed, 17 Oct 2007 13:51:10 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  8P - 2007/10/17
Hello.
Not the best of conditions but the weather was better than
predicted. Comet shows easy on single frames.
Thanks, Mike H.

http://fototime.com/DBCC188863DEC48/orig.jpg 

Date:  Wed, 17 Oct 2007 16:30:30 +0200
From:  Josef Müller 
Subject:  AW: [Comet-Images] 8P - 2007/10/17
Hello Mike,

how can you see the comet (8P/Tuttle)
"easy on single frames" ?
It is not easy to find it on your photo (10x50s)!
It is easy to find UGC 7956A !
Minor Planet Ephemeris Service you gives 13.5 mag
but I got - with Astrometrica - only 18.2 mag
I got in the morning of 2007-10-17 with 12" Newton, f/4.8
+ SXV-H9 :
17P/Holmes 18.7 mag
29P/Schwassmann-Wachmann 17.9 mag
110P/Hartley 17.8 mag
and 8P/Tuttle 18.2 mag
I will sebd the photos the next days.

PS: I found your 8P/Tuttle because I had prepared the
material for astrometrie.

Regards

Josef Mueller

-----Ursprüngliche Nachricht-----
Von: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com [mailto:Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com]
Im Auftrag von tricks46
Gesendet: Mittwoch, 17. Oktober 2007 15:51
An: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Betreff: [Comet-Images] 8P - 2007/10/17

Hello.
Not the best of conditions but the weather was better than
predicted. Comet shows easy on single frames.
Thanks, Mike H.

http://fototime.
com/DBCC188863DEC48/orig.jpg

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Wed, 17 Oct 2007 16:56:10 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: 8P - 2007/10/17
Hello josef.
That is a fair question. My opinion of easy to find is and object
seen on the raw image being downloaded from the camera to the
computer in real time. Many times I have had to process the raw
images with all kinds of tricks to get a comet to show up. UGC 7956A
is an easy object even at magnitude 16.5(guide). For a little
reference I have posted two images.
#1 - this is a single image with only a dark applied and no other
processing. It was the first image of the 10x50 stack I used for the
posted image you refered to. It was converted to a jpg with no
compression.
http://fototime.com/EABCFE2BAFAD1DA/orig.jpg
#2 - This is a 2 frame animation of the first and last image used in
the refered to image. Movement is slight but there.
http://fototime.com/4BE5FCE18B1D2DE/orig.gif
I do not estimate magnitudes. Past discussion on equipment used and
magnitudes arrived at is where an image like this might be effected.
I tried to find 8P with my LX200 10" last week and could not. I went
to the 5" used here and had no problem. Maybe some of it has to do
with computer monitors used by each person? I don't know what the
magnitude of this comet is but a condensed central area for me works
out good.
Thank you
Mike H.

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, Josef Müller
wrote:
>
> Hello Mike,
>
> how can you see the comet (8P/Tuttle)
> "easy on single frames" ?
> It is not easy to find it on your photo (10x50s)!
> It is easy to find UGC 7956A !
> Minor Planet Ephemeris Service you gives 13.5 mag
> but I got - with Astrometrica - only 18.2 mag
> I got in the morning of 2007-10-17 with 12" Newton, f/4.8
> + SXV-H9 :
> 17P/Holmes 18.7 mag
> 29P/Schwassmann-Wachmann 17.9 mag
> 110P/Hartley 17.8 mag
> and 8P/Tuttle 18.2 mag
> I will sebd the photos the next days.
>
> PS: I found your 8P/Tuttle because I had prepared the
> material for astrometrie.
>
> Regards
>
> Josef Mueller

Date:  Wed, 17 Oct 2007 21:12:36 +0200
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  Re: [!! SPAM]  [Comet-Images] Re: 8P - 2007/10/17
>I do not estimate magnitudes. Past discussion on equipment used and
>magnitudes arrived at is where an image like this might be effected.

I have photographed the comet on October 6 and 15 and with a filter Rc and with
Astrometrica I have measured a brightness equal to 17.0 and 16.8.

Date:  Wed, 17 Oct 2007 22:13:42 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: 8P/Tuttle
Please sir---What does this mean? "I" have no doubt "I" have imaged
the comet but your image shows little - to - nothing. This must
bring the apateure and size of the scope into issue. There needs
more input and I welcome it. Does my pictures show the comet or
not? Am I under a really false misconception I got the comet? If
not this requires a total revamp of my imaging, and if not at least
a total revaluation of which equipment can be used for giving
magnitude est. Perhaps it shpould be limited to a really restricted
kind of aperature giving magnitude estimates. Are there members here
who would give there opinion of yes or no to whether I have or don't
have the comet?
I understand this has been covered before by such estemed members as
Mr. Bortle but maybe one more time this can be addressed and although
I am not a member of the ML board transfered for discussion.
Thanks
Mike Mike H.

Date:  Thu, 18 Oct 2007 13:32:00 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re: [!! SPAM]  [Comet-Images] Re: 8P - 2007/10/17
> I have photographed the comet on October 6 and 15 and with a filter Rc and with
> Astrometrica I have measured a brightness equal to 17.0 and 16.8.

Astrometrica normally provides you a kind of m2 (nuclear magnitude). For diffuse objects (like 8P/Tuttle in this days) the m2 could be significantly fainther than the total magnitude of the comet.

The last CCD brightness measurement I found on the net for this comet, is that provided by the Observatoire Chante-Perdrix, Dauban, that measured a m1 (total) magnitude of 15.0 on 2007, October 07.78.
Seiichi Yoishida reports in his homepage that -"Now it is 15.4 mag (Oct. 7, Masayuki Suzuki)".
The ICQ webpage reports as last brightness estimation for 8P/Tuttle this entry:
2007
Sep. 16.04, 13.5:, 0'.6 (M. L. Paradowski, Lublin, Poland, 0.20-m reflector);

>From the above mentioned reports, I consider that the m1 of this comet should currently be close to ~mag.15 (unfiltered), so well within the reach of a 5 inch scope + CCD used under reasonably dark skies (expecially if the target is well above the horizon when imaged).

Regards,
Giovanni Sostero (AFAM, Remanzacco Observatory) 

Date:  Thu, 18 Oct 2007 18:25:49 +0200
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  Re: [!! SPAM]  [Comet-Images] Re: 8P - 2007/10/17
> Astrometrica normally provides you a kind of m2 (nuclear magnitude). For diffuse objects
> (like 8P/Tuttle in this days) the m2 could be significantly fainther than the total
> magnitude of the comet.

correct, in the hurry yesterday I have forgotten to write that the measure was with an
opening of 10."
with an opening of 30", always with the filter Rc, measures 15,8

regards
Rolando

Date:  Sun, 21 Oct 2007 04:36:42 -0000
From:  clearshot04 
Subject:  HILL 2006 S5 GIF
http://farm3.static.flickr.com/2351/1664058067_8b7eae73b2_o.gif

I also imaged 6 other comets last night after 11pm PST
Christensen W3, 110p, 17p, 128p, 50p, 93p

Since completing the observatory on Sep 12. I have imaged 18 comets
with the Meade 10" LX200 GPS a DSI proII w/ FR @ f5.
Its encouraging to see results and to see much room for improvement.
I use Starry Night Pro but the max mag is only 16, is there a free
web site or perhaps a better program. Regards James

From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] HILL 2006 S5 GIF
TheSky6 Pro by Software Bisque has stars down to mag
18, plus plots all the observable comets, plus all
asteroids.

Date:  Sun, 21 Oct 2007 23:03:45 -0000
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: HILL 2006 S5 GIF
I thought the mag upper limit was 18. But looking at the
documentation for UCAC2 its says 16.

UCAC web page:
http://ad.usno.navy.mil/ucac/

If you get a hard drive with USNO-B loaded then its possible to go
much deeper.

There is the Vizier on line service:
http://vizier.u-strasbg.fr/viz-bin/VizieR

Search for USNO-B1.0 catalog which is I/284 under their catalogs.

The Whole-Sky USNO-B1.0 Catalog of 1,045,913,669 sources (1045913669
rows)

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, Charles Bell
wrote:
>
> TheSky6 Pro by Software Bisque has stars down to mag
> 18, plus plots all the observable comets, plus all
> asteroids.

Date:  Mon, 22 Oct 2007 16:30:09 +0000
From:  Stéphane Garro 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] HILL 2006 S5 GIF --> Nb of comets in SNP
Hello James,

Le 21 oct. 07, à 04:36, clearshot04 a écrit :

> I use Starry Night Pro but the max mag is only 16, is there a free
> web site or perhaps a better program. Regards James

What version of Starry Night Pro (SNP) do you use ?

I use SNP v4.5 on Mac OS X.3 system to plot the positions of comets and
it works well up to m1=22 which is quite sufficient for me !
Beyong this threshold, comets aren't displayed and also not labelled,
you can only center the field of view on the computed position of the
comet.

I just made a try on 2 comets : 7P/Pons-Winnecke computed by SNP at mag
20,8 is displayed, but 6P/D'Arrest computed at mag 30,1 isn't.

I haven't the most recent version of SNP to see how the human interface
has evolved. In v4.5, you can adjust the magnitude threshold up to
which comets are labelled and also the brigntness of the displayed
pattern of them via the Options/Solar Sytem.../Comets submenu.

Are faint comets available when you do a search based on their name ?
If not, you can also adjust the number of comets in comets.txt file
read at SNP-startup within LiveSky/Preferences for auto updates...
submenu : I don't remember how many were present as a default value but
it wasn't sufficient (I have entered 250).

Please feel free to contact me privately if you want more details.

Regards,

Stephane

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Mon, 22 Oct 2007 20:21:33 -0700
From:  James schofer 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] HILL 2006 S5 GIF --> Nb of comets in SNP
Fantastic, I really like the SNP program. I have the 3.1 version and was looking at the newer versions but could not find the mag limits. Mag 22 should be well enough, the program is great as far as comet location, its the faint stars over mag 16 that would make it easier to pinpoint location. The 3.1 version enables comets to 22 mag and also number of * at startup so its really star mag that interests me. I use blink to confirm.
Any luck with 7P. That would be great to get that. Here is a page I have just started, any critic would be welcome. Thanks a bunch. http://www.flickr.com/photos/jrs63

Stéphane Garro wrote:
Hello James,

Le 21 oct. 07, à 04:36, clearshot04 a écrit :

> I use Starry Night Pro but the max mag is only 16, is there a free

I use SNP v4.5 on Mac OS X.3 system to plot the positions of comets and
it works well up to m1=22 which is quite sufficient for me !

you can only center the field of view on the computed position of the
comet.

20,8 is displayed, but 6P/D'Arrest computed at mag 30,1 isn't.

has evolved. In v4.5, you can adjust the magnitude threshold up to
which comets are labelled and also the brigntness of the displayed

Date:  Tue, 23 Oct 2007 21:02:41 -0000
From:  Martin Mobberley 
Subject:  C/2007 F1 (LONEOS) on Oct 23rd from UK
I have just added a murky, 8th, 2007 F1 (LONEOS) image,
taken with my C14, to the top section of my comet page at:

http://uk.geocities.com/martinmobberley/Comets.html

Probably my last image of 2007 F1, and conditions
were poor...very low altitude and hazy, plus various
horizon obstructions at 9 degs altitude...and 23 degs
solar elongation.

Regards,
Martin 

Date:  Wed, 24 Oct 2007 02:34:25 -0000
From:  Ramon Naves 
Subject:  outburst 17p
Juan Antonio Henríquez Santana (MPC J51) reports a outburst of Comet 17P/Holmes. Observations during the night of 2007 October 23/24 show that the comet is some 7 magnitudes brighter. The outburst has been confirmed by Gustavo Muler (MPC J47) and Ramon Naves & Montse Campàs (MPC 213).

Ramon Naves
Obs Montcabrer- MPC 213
http://astrosurf.com/cometas/
41° 31'11.01 N 2°23'07.39 E

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Tue, 23 Oct 2007 23:30:23 -0500
From:  Bob King 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] outburst 17p
Dear Ramon,
After seeing your e-mail, I looked for 17P/Holmes and found what appears to
be a yellowish, 7.1 magnitude star at the comet's position. With averted
vision I may have seen a faint coma or maybe not. Moonlight made it
difficult to be certain. Is this "star" actually 17P? Does this fit with
your observation? If so, this is a remarkable object. I used a 25cm
reflector at 76x and 214x on Oct. 24, 4:10 UT.
Thank you,
Bob King
Duluth, Minn. USA

On 10/23/07, Ramon Naves wrote:
>

> the comet is some 7 magnitudes brighter. The outburst has been confirmed by
> Gustavo Muler (MPC J47) and Ramon Naves & Montse Campàs (MPC 213).
>
> Ramon Naves
> Obs Montcabrer- MPC 213
> http://astrosurf.com/cometas/
> 41° 31'11.01 N 2°23'07.39 E

The comet was looking like a star mag 7 8

This morning have mag 7 aprox
We have observed it for several hours to estimate his,your movement

----- Original Message -----
From: Bob King
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, October 24, 2007 6:30 AM
Subject: Re: [Comet-Images] outburst 17p

Dear Ramon,
After seeing your e-mail, I looked for 17P/Holmes and found what appears to
be a yellowish, 7.1 magnitude star at the comet's position. With averted
vision I may have seen a faint coma or maybe not. Moonlight made it
difficult to be certain. Is this "star" actually 17P? Does this fit with
your observation? If so, this is a remarkable object. I used a 25cm
reflector at 76x and 214x on Oct. 24, 4:10 UT.
Thank you,
Bob King
Duluth, Minn. USA
