Date:  Wed, 24 Oct 2007 13:36:37 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] outburst 17p
> The comet was looking like a star mag 7 8
>
> This morning have mag 7 aprox
> We have observed it for several hours to estimate his,your movement

Hello Ramon and all,
yes, the outburst is real, and we congratulate wuth Juan Antonio Henríquez Santana and our spanish collegues for the discovery of this extremely interesting phenomena. Right now we are performing some follow-up of the outburst remotely from RAS-NM. Here is a preview: the proper motion of the comet is evident, as well as its extreme brightness (severe blooming on 60 sec image through a 25nm reflecotr + CCD):
http://tinyurl.com/ywgy7g

More on this later...

Kind regards,
Giovanni Sostero and Ernesto Guido (AFAM, CARA) 

Date:  Wed, 24 Oct 2007 07:06:44 -0500
From:  Bob King 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] outburst 17p
Hello Giovanni and all,
The comet is now naked eye at mag. 4.0!
Here are my observations over the past 10 hours:
After hearing of Ramon Naves' observation last night on comet-images,
I looked at 17P/Holmes with a 25cm reflector at 76x and 214x on Oct.
24, 4:10 UT. The comet was a mag. 7.1 "star" with a yellow hue. This
morning (Oct. 24, 11:15UT), the moon was out of the sky and seeing was
excellent. To my amazement, 17P had brightened to naked eye visibility
being nearly equal to 48 Per at visual mag. 4.0. In the same
telescope, the coma showed an intense, nearly stellar false nucleus
about 2.5"-3" across set in a small, 10" diameter, much fainter, fuzzy
disklike coma. The nucleus was distinctly yellow. The comet's
appearance was very reminiscent of McNaught last winter when seen in
the daytime sky. What a sight!
Bob King
Duluth, Minn. USA

On 10/24/07, gvnn64@libero.it wrote:
>
> > The comet was looking like a star mag 7 8
> >
> > This morning have mag 7 aprox
> > We have observed it for several hours to estimate his,your movement

> http://tinyurl.com/ywgy7g

Date:  Wed, 24 Oct 2007 22:38:58 +0200
From:  Toni Scarmato 
Subject:  Re: [comets-ml] 17P reached to maximum?

----- Original Message -----
From: Seiichi Yoshida
To: comets-ml@yahoogroups.com ; CometObs@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, October 24, 2007 9:33 PM
Subject: [comets-ml] 17P reached to maximum?

Dear colleagues,

17P/Holmes seems to have reached to the maximum. It kept the same
brightness during last two hours. The rapid brightening seems to have
stopped.

* Morris's web format:

17P/Holmes
2007 Oct. 24.80 UT: m1=2.9, Dia.=-, DC=9... 10x66R (10x) ..Seiichi Yoshida (Kanagawa, Japan)
2007 Oct. 24.80 UT: m1=2.8, Dia.=-, DC=9... NE ...Seiichi Yoshida (Kanagawa, Japan)

* ICQ format:

17P/Holmes
IIIYYYYMnL YYYY MM DD.DD eM/mm.m:r AAA.ATF/xxxx /dd.ddnDC /t.ttmANG ICQ XX*OBSxx
17 2007 10 24.80 I 2.9 YG 6.6R 10 9 ICQ XX YOS04
17 2007 10 24.80 I 2.8 YG 0.0E 1 9 ICQ XX YOS04

Best regards,

--
Seiichi Yoshida
comet@aerith.net
http://www.aerith.net/

Date:  Thu, 25 Oct 2007 01:11:45 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Comet 17P Holmes - Green comet and possible dispersion
What an incredible sight....to the naked eye, it appears as a bright new star in the
constellation of Perseus, high in northern skies and never rising nor setting throughout
the nights of the next few weeks.

Comet 17P Holmes, a very obscure and dim object to say the least only 30 hours ago, is
blazing away at a brightness increase rarely seen before in such a short period of time,
rising more than 15-16 magnitudes since October 23. Now at brightness 2.0 (ASO, Oct. 25
UT, 04:10) and perhaps still brightening, this comet must be watched continuously for
the next several weeks.

It appears as you seen in the first light photo from ASO; this is an RGB color image
from an ST 401-ME camera, 12 second images in each color and combined. No post
processing, just a raw image, showing the brilliant round yellow-green huge (nearly 3
arc minutes across) coma. The very high contrast negative imaging reveals a possible
dust tail coming nearly due north (down) from the comet as well as one streaming from
the south side of the coma. The image was taken with a 0.4m SCT at f/3 at the
observatory (Harvard MPC H45) at Petit Jean Mountain in Arkansas.

This unusual "round comet" to be so bright without a tail or irregularity is something
very extraordinary. The comet can easily be seen with the naked eye, but even
binoculars and telescopes give the impression that the viewer is peering at a very
bright star.

The field of view in both ASO images is 12 arc ' by 7' with SOUTH up.

For those with no image attached, please visit the report with both color and high
contrast negative (showing possible dispersion from the coma), at the Arkansas Sky
Observatory (ASO) website under the "ASO News Links" on the home page at:
http://www.arksky.org/

Clay
-------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Thu, 25 Oct 2007 08:16:46 -0500
From:  Kevin Muenzler 
Subject:  RE: [Comet-Images] Comet 17P Holmes - Green comet and possible dispersion
Hi Dr. Clay! Fancy meeting you here.

I just discovered this group a couple of days ago. Holmes is unbelievable.
I went out last night to try to see it and saw the "extra star: in Perseus
and thought to myself "That CAN'T be it." Then I checked and that was it.
It looks like it's going to pass right by Mirfak in a mid November!

Kevin Muenzler, WB5RUE
29º14'52"N 98º14'50"W
Eagle Creek Observatory
http://www.eaglecreekobservatory.org

Those who never look up avoid all of the cow manure but that's all they ever
get to see.

_____

From: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com [mailto:Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of P. Clay Sherrod
Sent: Thursday, October 25, 2007 1:12 AM
To: P. Clay Sherrod
Subject: [Comet-Images] Comet 17P Holmes - Green comet and possible
dispersion

What an incredible sight....to the naked eye, it appears as a bright new
star in the
constellation of Perseus, high in northern skies and never rising nor
setting throughout
the nights of the next few weeks.

Comet 17P Holmes, a very obscure and dim object to say the least only 30
hours ago, is
blazing away at a brightness increase rarely seen before in such a short
period of time,
rising more than 15-16 magnitudes since October 23. Now at brightness 2.0
(ASO, Oct. 25
UT, 04:10) and perhaps still brightening, this comet must be watched
continuously for
the next several weeks.

It appears as you seen in the first light photo from ASO; this is an RGB
color image
from an ST 401-ME camera, 12 second images in each color and combined. No
post
processing, just a raw image, showing the brilliant round yellow-green huge
(nearly 3
arc minutes across) coma. The very high contrast negative imaging reveals a
possible
dust tail coming nearly due north (down) from the comet as well as one
streaming from
the south side of the coma. The image was taken with a 0.4m SCT at f/3 at
the
observatory (Harvard MPC H45) at Petit Jean Mountain in Arkansas.

This unusual "round comet" to be so bright without a tail or irregularity is
something
very extraordinary. The comet can easily be seen with the naked eye, but
even
binoculars and telescopes give the impression that the viewer is peering at
a very
bright star.

The field of view in both ASO images is 12 arc ' by 7' with SOUTH up.

For those with no image attached, please visit the report with both color
and high
contrast negative (showing possible dispersion from the coma), at the
Arkansas Sky
Observatory (ASO) website under the "ASO News Links" on the home page at:
http://www.arksky. org/

Clay
-------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky. org/

Date:  Fri, 26 Oct 2007 23:51:50 +0200
From:  Toni Scarmato 
Subject:  17p observation
Comet 17P/Holmes in outburst
2007 10 26.86, 1.9, - (T. Scarmato, Calabria, Italy, naked eye)

With 20x90 binoculars is visible a coma estended for about 10' around th strong central condensation.
In color image is visible an outer faint coma of green coulor around the
inner coma. See images at address: http://digilander.libero.it/infosis/homepage/astronomia/17p.htm

Regards,
Toni Scarmato

Date:  Sat, 27 Oct 2007 06:00:19 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  ASO - Increasing activity and nucleus of 17P
Even more incredible each night; the comet 17P (Holmes) now measures 255 arc minutes
across (via CCD direct measure), and is easily naked eye at magnitude 1.9 visual (10 x
50 binoculars); this 5-second RGB composite was taken with the 0.4m SCT f/3 via CCD at
09:55 U.T. and the field measures 6 x 6 arc minutes. The nucleus was measured
photometrically at m1=11.8, offset significantly from center; also note the very bright
opposing (from the nucleus) scintillating condensation equally offset from center, but
in the opposite direction.

Note that on Oct. 25, similar measures of the coma revealed diameter of approximately
121 arc minutes.

The latest image, and a same scale comparison to that of October 25, is found at the
link:
http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php?topic=1429.msg6902#msg6902
or by clicking on the ASO News on the website homepage.

Dr. Clay
-------------
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/ 

Date:  Sat, 27 Oct 2007 06:25:22 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: ASO - Increasing activity and nucleus of 17P
Hello Dave and thanks for this correction; indeed of course that should have been "arc
seconds" rather than arc minutes; the field that is shown is approximately 7 x 6 arc
minutes with south at top. Much appreciated.

Clay
-------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/

----- Original Message -----
From: "Dave Tholen"
To: ; ;
Cc:
Sent: Saturday, October 27, 2007 6:17 AM
Subject: Re: ASO - Increasing activity and nucleus of 17P

>> Even more incredible each night; the comet 17P (Holmes) now measures 255 arc minutes
>> across (via CCD direct measure),
>
> Do you mean arcseconds instead of arcminutes? 255 arcminutes is over 4 degrees.
>
>> and is easily naked eye at magnitude 1.9 visual (10 x
>> 50 binoculars); this 5-second RGB composite was taken with the 0.4m SCT f/3 via CCD
>> at
>> 09:55 U.T. and the field measures 6 x 6 arc minutes.
>
> The picture on the web site has a rectangular field, not square, so it's hard to scale
> the size of the comet, but it's more like an arcminute, not 255 arcminutes. With the
> moonlight competing, it's hard to tell the full extent of the comet via eye, but it
> certainly didn't fill the field of my telescope, whereas something 255 arcminutes
> would. 

Date:  Sat, 27 Oct 2007 22:01:08 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  17P-20071027-07:35UT
Hello. After some rest I worked on information taken with a very good
focus and good information. I was going to use this for color but
already having a good color image I combined and desaturated the
information. Croped and gave a 2x or a little more enlarge. reduced
the light levels with no contrast adj. Was surprised after inverting
the image. Does this show a fragment? I have thought that a split of
some kind happened and would show about now. Of course we are all
entitled to our opinions and after Rolando's image on the ML board
hoped it was a matter of time. Hopefully I can reproduce this tonight
and this limb will not break that I am out on. You can of course
deside for your self. One other thing would be not just a split but
our point of view of a split as we see the comet almost head on. Let
the hate mail begin!
Thanks, Mike H.

http://fototime.com/1E497C8D364958E/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sat, 27 Oct 2007 22:30:39 -0000
From:  Martin Mobberley 
Subject:  17P Holmes outburst imaged from UK
In a very lucky cloud gap, in twilight and nearby moonlight,
I managed to bag a colour shot of the bizarre 17P/Holmes with
the C14. I have placed it at the top of my comet page at:

http://uk.geocities.com/martinmobberley/Comets.html

In 25 years of comet photography/imaging, this is a new
type of object to me!

Regards,
Martin

Date:  Sun, 28 Oct 2007 04:39:30 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  ASO_Comet 17P, bigger not brighter
UPDATE: October 28

The comet has increased dramatically in size and complexity; (see LAST image on this
page) details are:
NEW image is posted at: http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php?topic=1429.msg6902#msg6902
Coma diameter, overall: 348.3" (average 8 measurements, CCD)
Coma inner core (bright) diameter: 117.3"
Dark "compression/shock" ring in outer coma: 204.2"
Nuclear magnitude - 9.8 (average)
Total magnitude = 2.3

NOTE that even though the comet is considerably larger on this morning than on the
previous morning, the brightness overall has dropped (naked eye estimate utilizing Alpha
Perseii and Alpha Cassiopeia).

The last picture in this sequence below demonstrates the strong outgassing from the
central nucleus and the incredibly rich yellow color of this comet.

Clay
-------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/ 

Date:  Sun, 28 Oct 2007 09:43:13 -0000

whatever looks better.

Date:  Sun, 28 Oct 2007 16:38:34 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: 17P-20071027-07:35UT
Hi Mike,

Nice image!

Now help me out. What do you mean when you say you "desaturated" the
information? I don't see how you can turn the clock back and take a
shorter exposure to avoid saturation. I understand the part about
reducing the light levels, but once the pixels are at their maximum
white, quantitative brightness information is lost and no amount of
image processing can reclaim it.

Anyway, whatever you did, it made for an excellent image!

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Date:  Sun, 28 Oct 2007 18:05:58 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: 17P-20071027-07:35UT
Hello Dennis. Long time no hear from!. In PS the desaturate simply
takes a color channel and removes the color. When I transfer from
CCDSoftV5 to PScs2 I save in color this way I can use the images in
color or grayscale.
Mike

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Dennis Persyk"
wrote:
>
> Hi Mike,
>
> Nice image!
>
> Now help me out. What do you mean when you say you "desaturated"
the
> information? I don't see how you can turn the clock back and take
a
> shorter exposure to avoid saturation. I understand the part about
> reducing the light levels, but once the pixels are at their maximum
> white, quantitative brightness information is lost and no amount of
> image processing can reclaim it.
>
> Anyway, whatever you did, it made for an excellent image!
>
> Clear skies,
>
> Dennis Persyk
> Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
> Hampshire, IL
>
> --- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "tricks46" wrote:
> >
> > Hello. After some rest I worked on information taken with a very
> good focus and good information. I was going to use this for
color
> but already having a good color image I combined and desaturated
> the information. Croped and gave a 2x or a little more enlarge.
> reduced the light levels with no contrast adj. Was surprised
after
> inverting the image. Does this show a fragment? I have thought
> that a split of some kind happened and would show about now. Of
> course we are all entitled to our opinions and after Rolando's
> image on the ML board hoped it was a matter of time. Hopefully I
> can reproduce this tonight and this limb will not break that I am
> out on. You can of course deside for your self. One other thing
> would be not just a split but our point of view of a split as we
> see the comet almost head on. Let the hate mail begin!
> > Thanks, Mike H.
> >
> > http://fototime.com/1E497C8D364958E/orig.jpg
> >

unbelievable

Date:  Sun, 28 Oct 2007 22:14:49 +0100
From:  Lorenzo Comolli 
Subject:  17P/Holmes from Tradate, Italy
Here is an image of comet Holmes obtained with my 30cm f/2.0 digitalized
Schmidt Camera, from a light polluted city and with transiting clouds.
Total exposure was only 22 min (10 s individual frames). It shows the
external envelope of gas (green) and the internal dust disk (yellow).
The internal details was obtained with a LS filter.

http://www.astrosurf.com/comolli/com32e.htm

Clear Skys, (here is clouded again...)
Lorenzo

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

2007 10 28.82, 2.4, 4' (T. Scarmato, Calabria, Italy, naked eye; moonlight)

I have updated my HomePage http://digilander.libero.it/infosis/homepage/astronomia/17p.htm
with new images.

http://comete.uai.it/17p/17P_071028_647nm.jpg

made these images I have tried to observe her with a C11 to 200x

it is incredibly beautiful and particular, I would have remained times to observe her...

Date:  Mon, 29 Oct 2007 04:08:25 -0000
From:  Bill 
Subject:  17P Holmes imaged on Oct. 28th
A very clear night allowed me to capture this image of 17P. The next
few nights are going to remain very clear so I plan another image at
f/6.3 to give a wider field of view. I was able to easily see in with
the un-aided eye. Using an old 8x50mm finder provided a nice view.

http://web.ics.purdue.edu/~wlsnyder/17pholmes.htm

Bill 

Date:  Mon, 29 Oct 2007 00:58:15 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Update on 17P
UPDATE: October 29
Image update at: http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php?topic=1429.msg6902#msg6902
Comet is now maintaining somewhat of a plateau in both overall brightness and size;
details are as follows (NOTE current image at bottom of this page)
Coma Diameter, overall: 408", average 8 CCD measures
Jet imaged emanating at nucleus and extending SW into coma, this physically associated
it seems with the conspicuous knot, or cloud offset in coma.
Nuclear Magnitude (m2) = 9.9 to 10.0
Total Magnitude (m1) = 2.4, slightly down from previous night.
SEE LAST IMAGE IN SEQUENCE

Clay
-------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/ 

Date:  Mon, 29 Oct 2007 06:41:03 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Comet 17P Holmes CCD/CAT + DSLR/Refractor + Eyeball
I'm an equal-opportunity imager. I have images from my Epsilon
f/3.3 astrograph with SXV-H9 and my Televue 4-inch refractor with
Canon 20D. I also have a "digital sketch" of what my eyeball
perceived looking though the refractor.

This is truly an amazing comet to observe and/or image  don't pass
it up!

Here is the link to my New Images page featuring the comet in three
modalities and supporting data  please take a look at the link
below:
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

By now you have all seen images and posts regarding comet 17P
Holmes. It is truly an amazing comet. In the space of just 14
hours, the comet increased in brightness by 17 magnitudes -- that's
a factor of six million times brighter (2.51^17) ! You can view it
by naked eye, binoculars, or telescope. Imaging is easy because it
is so bright.

Here are a few links that I employ to scrounge up data on the comet
I'm going to image -- you may find them helpful for observing and
imaging:

General source  magnitude, sky charts, background info
http://www.cometchasing.skyhound.com/index.html

Light Curve
http://www.aerith.net/comet/catalog/0017P/2007.html

Orbit
http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/orbits/

Ephemerides, including arc-seconds per minute relative motion
(important to determine maximum imaging time  want less than one
pixel blur per exposure)
http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iau/MPEph/MPEph.html

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Pier Design Paper: http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/Pier_Design.htm 

Date:  Mon, 29 Oct 2007 08:11:20 -0500
From:  Kevin Muenzler 
Subject:  RE: [Comet-Images] Update on 17P
I was amazed when I went out last night to look. It's not a "star" any
more, it actually has some "fuzziness." To the naked eye it looks like an
out-of-focus yellow star. When I looked through my scope the only thing I
could say was "WOW!" It had a very star-like nucleus with what looked like
a couple of stars visible though the coma. This is as exciting as
2002/NY40!

Kevin Muenzler, WB5RUE
29º14'52"N 98º14'50"W
Eagle Creek Observatory
http://www.eaglecreekobservatory.org
http://www.cbcweb.net
Black holes are where God divided by zero.

From: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com [mailto:Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of P. Clay Sherrod
Sent: Monday, October 29, 2007 12:58 AM
To: comets-ml@yahoogroups.com
Cc: P. Clay Sherrod; CometChasing@yahoogroups.com; Comet Images Yahoo
Subject: [Comet-Images] Update on 17P

UPDATE: October 29
Image update at:
http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php?topic=1429.msg6902#msg6902
Comet is now maintaining somewhat of a plateau in both overall brightness
and size; details are as follows (NOTE current image at bottom of this page)
Coma Diameter, overall: 408", average 8 CCD measures Jet imaged emanating
at nucleus and extending SW into coma, this physically associated it seems
with the conspicuous knot, or cloud offset in coma.
Nuclear Magnitude (m2) = 9.9 to 10.0
Total Magnitude (m1) = 2.4, slightly down from previous night.
SEE LAST IMAGE IN SEQUENCE

Clay
-------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South) http://www.arksky.org/

Date:  Mon, 29 Oct 2007 13:54:28 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  17P-Animation - 27, 28 & 29
Hello. I droped the image from the 25th. Worked only on the center
portion of the comet. Stacked on the false nuke. Images were resized
equally and processed the same. Seeing, Moonlight and all the other
things make a difference. Whatever is in the cloud is moving away I
think and even appears to being supplied or connected still but that is
just from looking at this animation. I will be glad to see the Hubble
and or Spitzer images.
Mike H.

http://fototime.com/EB21DC04696A3EC/orig.gif 

Date:  Mon, 29 Oct 2007 15:07:52 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  17P-20071029
Hello. This is a color image from around 06:40UT 2007/10/29. I have
the reduced image and the full chip size with a 1x1 bin at the links.
Thanks, Mike H.

Date:  Mon, 29 Oct 2007 15:45:11 -0000
From:  Eddie Guscott 
Subject:  17/P from southern UK
Hi Group

This is a first time post for me although I've admired the images here
for a while.

Since the start of this outburst, the weather here has been dire -
100% cloud so it was a great surprise to get an hour of clear weather
last night enabling me to observe this wonderful sight. I have never
seen anything like it before.

I have put together some images on my webpage including an 'iffy'
composite with a rotational gradient filter (although it does show the
jet to the south-west).
http://www.astropics.co.uk/comet%20holmes.htm

Shame we won't get to see much of a tail...

Eddie Guscott
Essex, England

Date:  Mon, 29 Oct 2007 16:34:54 -0000
From:  Mike Borman 
Subject:  17P Image From Early Sunday Morning 10-28-07
I just discovered this group and am enjoying all the images of comet
17P.

We had rain all last week here in southern Indiana, so I was unable to
view 17P until early Sunday morning. I was impressed how easy it was to
see with the naked eye, despite the nearby Moon. Here is a shot I took
of it with my Televue 102iis refractor, 2X Televue Powermate, and Canon
20Da DSLR:

http://www.geocities.com/mfb_eas/

The exposure was 15 seconds at ASA 800.

Mike Borman
Evansville, Indiana, USA

Date:  Mon, 29 Oct 2007 18:07:27 -0000
From:  albertnobel 
Subject:  17P Holmes Images
Hello All, While I have certainly enjoyed the many images everyone had
posted of 17P, and incidentally many are very nice, I was wondering if
anyone knows if any "professional" observatories have taken an
interest. Wouldn't you enjoy a Keck or Hubble image? I have been unable
to find an answer. With all the mystery surrounding it's million fold
brightening, I would think the professionals would be equally
interested. Especially, since the nucleus is invisible. And, since the
tail is obviously pointed directly away from us, I would love to know
how long it is (though I realize that is probably impossible to
determine).

Al

Date:  Mon, 29 Oct 2007 23:03:33 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  A Dust Question.
Hello. I understand that there are all different kinds of chips and
each has it's own ability to record different colors. In the past
there was always a basic color a comet was putting out or actually 3
different colors red, green & blue but Red was dust. If this comet is
reflecting a lot of dust around the central portion , where is the red
and why is it yellow almost gold. I haven't seen any red color from
this comet. My camera chip is not as strong in the red but I would
have thought a hint of red would be around somewhere.
Any takers?
Thanks, Mike

Date:  Tue, 30 Oct 2007 00:33:25 -0000
From:  Pete Lawrence 
Subject:  Comet 17P/Holmes and tail structure
Hi all,

Here are some of my captures of Comet 17P/Holmes from the 28th October...

Inner coma region:
http://www.digitalsky.org.uk/comets/2007-10-28_22-32-17P-Holmes_800n.jpg

General shot of the comet showing the green outer coma:
http://www.digitalsky.org.uk/comets/2007-10-28_21h41m_275-292+core_800.jpg

Wide-field shot showing the comets postion relative to Mirphak:
http://www.digitalsky.org.uk/comets/Holmes-Mirphak-cropped-1024.jpg

My first result from the 29th, a 45 minute exposure of 17P extreme
stacked and contrast stretched to reveal faint structures around the
coma. A fully annotated version of this image will be prepared in due
course.
http://www.digitalsky.org.uk/comets/2007-10-29_22h57m_17P-Holmes-9x5mins_800.jpg

Best regards,

Pete Lawrence
http://www.digitalsky.org.uk

Date:  Tue, 30 Oct 2007 02:24:43 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  ASO, Update on 17P Holmes
UPDATE: October 30
*IMAGE on ASO website at:
http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php?topic=1429.msg6902#msg6902
Comet continues a plateau in brightness, but continues to enlarge; details are as
follows (NOTE current image at bottom of this page)
Coma Diameter, overall: 482", average 4 CCD measures
Jet images emanating at nucleus and extending SW into coma, measured 39.3" distant from
nucleus in P.A. 216 deg.
Nuclear Magnitude (m2) = 9.4 , slightly brighter within previous 24 hours
Total Magnitude (m1) = 2.4, constant
NOTE outer halo continues to enlarge and intensify relative to darker inner void (?)
ring
*Current image follows composite sequence

Clay
-------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/

Date:  Tue, 30 Oct 2007 09:27:37 +0100
From:  Jose Pablo 
Subject:  17p/Holmes + filter swan band

Area of the Comet-Images group.

File: 110P-Hartley_inv.jpg
Uploaded by Josef Mueller j.j.mueller@onlinehome.de

Description: 2007-10-17.12625 - 60x30s - 12"Newton f/4,8 + SXV-H9
without filter
You can access this file at the URL:
http://tech.ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/photos/view/5f08?b=19

Description: 2007-10-17.092 - 60x30s - 12" Newton f/4.8 + SXV H-9
without filter
18,2 mag
SNR = 17.5
FWHM = 2.6"
http://tech.ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/photos/view/5f08?b=20

Date:  Tue, 30 Oct 2007 14:47:09 -0000
From:  Martin Mobberley 
Subject:  17P Holmes inner coma animation
I've added an animation of the inner 8 arc-minute coma
expanding to the 17P section of my comet page at:

http://uk.geocities.com/martinmobberley/Comets.html

The nucleus position is marked with a white dot, as this is
subtracted away in the Larson-Sekanina process.

The gif animation itself is located at:

http://uk.geocities.com/martin.mobberley@btinternet.com/17P_20071027to29anim_mpm2.gifRegards,Martin

From:  tricks46 
Subject:  17P-2007/10/30-RGB
Hello. Same amount of information went into this image as yesterday.
Less Moonlight and less humidity allowed a stronger color and less
noise. Central portion of the comet overexposed this image and leads
me to beleive it is brighter in magnitude than yesterday.
Thanks, Mike H

Date:  Tue, 30 Oct 2007 16:51:23 -0000
From:  Vance Bagwell 
Subject:  P17/Holmes
Hello,
New to the group. I'd like to work on improving my skills imaging
comets and keep up with other's work.

http://www.flickr.com/photo_zoom.gne?id=1795882651&size=o

Aquired the evening of 10-27-07 from Cedar Hill, Texas. RGB image
5:5:5 minutes (30 second subexposures) with the camera at -20 degrees
C. Takahashi FS-152 (with flattener), SBIG STL-11000M astro CCD camera
on a Takahashi NJP mount.

Respectfully,
Vance Bagwell 

Date:  Tue, 30 Oct 2007 18:58:21 -0000
From:  Umberto Mulé Stagno 
Subject:  17P/Holmes
Hi peeps...

Finally the sky decided to clear up a little, and granted us a view of
Comet Holmes!

Using a 90mm Megrez Telescope the coma appeared less defined behind
the "dust jet". Nucleus is extremely well defined... Will take a peek
later in the night to note motion against background stars and maybe
attempt some photos with less wind.

Below is also my very modest attempt at capturing a photo of the comet:

http://outdoors.webshots.com/photo/2456521170030728289pUVZUb

It's a Single 15Sec shot with Nikon D80 on Hand-driven equatorial
mount, using 90mm William Optics Megrez. ISO1600

You can see it's badly tracked, but I'm happy to have recorded this
little souvenir.

I'm desperate to receive my CGE1400, hoping I can take at least
"half-way decent" shots :o)) Fingers crossed maybe the comet remains
like this at least through November.

Clear Skies!

Umberto Mule' Stagno
Naxxar - MALTA
+35.92N +14.42E 

Date:  Tue, 30 Oct 2007 22:52:25 +0100
From:  Toni Scarmato 
Subject:  17p observation

Comet 17P/Holmes
2007 Oct. 30.86 UT: m1=1.8, Dia=15', DC=7.... NE......T. Scarmato (Calabria, Italy)
[In 20x90 binoculars the show is fantastic. It is possible to note a strong false nucleus and the cloud in PA 220 deg extended about 2', the inner coma much intense is sorrounded by a large outer green coma extended at least 30'. No tail visible.]

Updated my HomePage: http://digilander.libero.it/infosis/homepage/astronomia/17p.htm

Regards,
Toni Scarmato

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Wed, 31 Oct 2007 04:20:30 -0000
From:  Bill 
Subject:  17P Images Tuesday Night
Hello all,

Did some more imaging of 17P tonight.

This one is with my cooled CCD camera, Cookbook 245. I used my 6.3
focal reducer on this vs the one I posted the other day which was at
f/10.

http://web.ics.purdue.edu/~wlsnyder/17pholmes2.htm

For this image I took the focal reducer off and used my Nikon D200 at
prime. My first color image of 17P.

http://web.ics.purdue.edu/~wlsnyder/17pholmes1.htm

Clear skies all!
Bill

Date:  Wed, 31 Oct 2007 07:07:47 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  17P update; comet maintaining status quo
Clear skies prevailed once again.
New update image on ASO at
http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php?topic=1429.msg6902#msg6902
The comet maintains both brightness and physical attributes; morphology has not
appreciably change, BUT overall diameter continues to grow at an extraordinary rate.
Coma overall diameter = 545" arc (CCD) with increasingly bright offset bright segment to
SW of nucleus - in PA 220, expanding to 45" from nucleus, up from previous dates
Coma appears considerably larger to the naked eye, perhaps as much as 12 arc minutes
Magnitude, m1 = 2.3, slightly brighter than previous night, very distinct cloud to the
naked eye
Nuclear magnitude, m2 = 10.2, substantially dimmer than previous night and nucleus is
very starlike
Overall color remains the same, very golden yellow throughout all expanses of the comet.

Equipment: 0.4m SCT @ f/3 CCD, ST402-ME C-I CCD, RGB @ 12 seconds. Overall magnitude
estimate via naked eye, Alpha Peg. by comparison.

Clay
-------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/ 

Date:  Wed, 31 Oct 2007 12:56:46 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: 17P-20071027-07:35UT
Hello. I am going to answer my own post with a followup? Anyway I
have been thinking - (watch out).
Watching some information on the Space Station, they took some salt
or or some kind of power and put it in a bag. It imediatly started
to gather into clumps. What if this comet belched out a cloud of
dust and debree and we all know this happened.
Could the debree in this cloud do the same thing as the substance and
start to clump. Could this be the start of what was imaged and could
this continue in the future and be construed as fragments as they
grow? That is if what I imaged is real. Is this too far fetched?
Mike H.

In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "tricks46" wrote:
>
> Hello. After some rest I worked on information taken with a very
good
> focus and good information. I was going to use this for color but
> already having a good color image I combined and desaturated the
> information. Croped and gave a 2x or a little more enlarge.
reduced
> the light levels with no contrast adj. Was surprised after
inverting
> the image. Does this show a fragment? I have thought that a split
of
> some kind happened and would show about now. Of course we are all
> entitled to our opinions and after Rolando's image on the ML board
> hoped it was a matter of time. Hopefully I can reproduce this
tonight
> and this limb will not break that I am out on. You can of course
> deside for your self. One other thing would be not just a split
but
> our point of view of a split as we see the comet almost head on.
Let
> the hate mail begin!
> Thanks, Mike H.

Date:  Wed, 31 Oct 2007 14:22:14 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Looking For Tail
I have images from 5 nights. No matter what I do I cannot get
streamers or tail to show. This doesn't mean it is not there or they
are not there. Just means my equipment does not record them. I did
see a difference in the images from 2007/10/30. You can process in or
out so I post this 1x60 second image through a Blue filter with only a
level applied to reduce light. N up E left. If I were looking for
tail here is what I would watch. Was not on other days images.
Thanks, Mike H.

http://fototime.com/E54F29E7BBA1979/orig.jpg

more of a tail or provide definition of that burst on one side.

Date:  Wed, 31 Oct 2007 13:22:26 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Animation of coma growth: 17P Holmes from ASO
Provided is a series of ASO images from Oct. 26, 27, 29, 30, and 31 that show the
remarkable explosion/expansion of the coma of comet 17P Holmes.
The images are all at exactly the same scale (the field is about 6 arc minutes square)
on each night and show the very rapid and dramatic growth of this unheralded event.
http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php?topic=1437.0

This may well be the most unique and impressive comet that we will ever see in our
lifetimes and is currently very easy to see naked eye about 10 p.m. local time.

Images are from the ASO 0.4m SCT at f/3, CCD, all 5 seconds RGB.

Much thanks to ASO Forum contributor Ron Wayman for this work in providing this fine
animation.

Clay
-------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/ 

Date:  Wed, 31 Oct 2007 22:01:22 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: Looking For Tail
--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "tricks46" wrote:
>
> I have images from 5 nights. No matter what I do I cannot get
> streamers or tail to show. This doesn't mean it is not there or
they
> are not there. Just means my equipment does not record them. I
did
> see a difference in the images from 2007/10/30. You can process in
or out so I post this 1x60 second image through a Blue filter with
only a level applied to reduce light. N up E left. If I were
looking for tail here is what I would watch. Was not on other days
images.
> Thanks, Mike H.
>
> http://fototime.com/E54F29E7BBA1979/orig.jpg
>

Hi Mike,

If by "streamers" you mean the finger-like structure like this
http://www.klaas-
jobse.net/cyclops/kometen/20071030_17P_11x12sUnsharp412_LS07.jpg

also found here (shorter link)
http://www.klaas-jobse.net/cyclops/cometspage.htm

then the secret is unsharp mask!

However, to bring them out, you need to meet two criteria:
1) High statistics, 16-bit images  lots of images (~50 or so) in the
stack, and
2) Unsaturated sub frames  50% well depth on the brightest pixels

Try a 5x5 mask, and rather aggressive parameter selection  you will
probably get gross-looking ring artifacts  "halos"  but don't
worry. You will bring out the underlying structure.

Here's what I posted to the Comets-ML:

Unsharp Masking artifacts vs. Real Morphology

Whereas the more complicated radial gradient operators various
imagers have applied are somewhat difficult to understand (for me,
anyway!) in terms of artifact generation, unsharp masking (USM) is an
edge operator, and as such, is incapable of producing streak
artifacts, or the kind of structure we are seeing in current images.
Aggressively applied, USM results in ring artifacts, or "halos",
around the stars.

Streak artifacts are radially disposed lines emanating from a high-
frequency central point. The "fingers" or "streamers" that we see in
nearly everyone's images are not all radially symmetric, and, as
such, are neither streak artifacts nor edge artifacts. They are real
underlying structure.

Giovanni illustrated the application of USM for me on my images, and
I later obtained similar a appearing structure myself by applying
USM. Alan Watson and Carl Hergenrother both have processed my images
by other more sophisticated, independent techniques and both obtained
identical looking structures.

It should be noted that these results can only be obtained on a high-
statistics, unsaturated images. I transformed my 16-bit FITs image
into an 8-bit JPG and the USM merely produced random noise and ring
artifacts.

I submit that the images presented to the list indicate that the
structure is real.

The question for discussion is, what is it and what causes it?

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

My 17P Images http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Date:  Wed, 31 Oct 2007 22:40:17 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: Looking For Tail
> If by "streamers" you mean the finger-like structure like this
> http://www.klaas-
> jobse.net/cyclops/kometen/20071030_17P_11x12sUnsharp412_LS07.jpg
>
> also found here (shorter link)
> http://www.klaas-jobse.net/cyclops/cometspage.htm

Hello Dennis. The images I took ranged form 2 seconds to 60 seconds
each depending on which night I imaged. A total of the clear
unfiltered images totaled 10 minutes in 60 second individual images.
These were not used as the pix bleed overpowered the entire center of
the comet. I also took RG&B images of 1x40 second exposures in a set
of 5x60 second images total for each channel. These were all processed
in as many ways including each way you said. In none of the final
images did I find what was refered to as streamers or a tail. Now---as
I said this does not in any way mean there are not streamers or a faint
tail. I see no reason there would not be a tail-tails. My equipment
did not record it. I see no reason for the tail to not be there as it
was there before the outburst per images by Josef Mueller -
http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/message/3364 Hopefully
I will image the tail with my equipment as it grows and brightens.
Good luck with your imaging
Mike H.

tail structure. Stunning image!

Mike H.

Date:  Thu, 01 Nov 2007 02:20:57 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: Image 17P/Holmes
Hi Rafa,

Very good image. You have nicely captured the internal
fingers/streaks/jets that have been the subject of much speculation
on the Comets-ML list. Many members thought they were artifacts but
your image shows them plainly.

Clear skies,

Dennis

Date:  Thu, 01 Nov 2007 01:40:51 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  ASO Update on Comet Holmes 17P, Nov. 1
Arkansas Sky Observatory (H45) update on Comet 17P:
Comet imaged and measured as high cirrus moved in.
New photo showing expansion of comet:
http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php?topic=1429.msg6902#msg6902
The comet maintains both brightness and physical attributes; morphology has not
appreciably changed, but again the overall diameter continues to grow at an
extraordinary rate.
Coma overall diameter = 596" arc (CCD) with increasingly bright offset bright segment to
SW of nucleus - in PA 214, now extending to 69.5"" from nucleus, up from previous dates
Coma appears considerably larger to the naked eye, perhaps as much as 17-20 arc minutes
Magnitude, m1 = 2.1, slightly brighter than previous night, very distinct cloud to the
naked eye with conspicuous nebulosity and yellow color; comparison star (naked eye) is
Alpha Per
Nuclear magnitude, m2 = 11.1, continues to drop rapidly as the nucleus becomes even more
pinpoint

Overall color remains the same, very golden yellow throughout all expanses of the comet.

Equipment: 0.4m SCT @ f/3 CCD, ST402-ME C-I CCD, RGB @ 8 seconds. Overall magnitude
estimate via naked eye, Alpha Peg. by comparison.

Dr. Clay
-------------
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/

Date:  Thu, 01 Nov 2007 22:19:49 +1100
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] New file uploaded to Comet-Images
Nice image.

A question.... While this image appears to show extended structure from the comet - what
is the cause of the structures surrounding the brighter stars? Is it diffraction spikes
from a secondary support, or something else? The bright star to the left of the comet (in
particular) appears to have structure that is not diffraction spikes.....

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

Date:  Thu, 01 Nov 2007 13:30:58 +0100
From:  Michael Jaeger 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] New file uploaded to Comet-Images
Hi Dave
hi dave

the instrument is a deltagraph (NO secondary mirror).
a 4" corrector (three lens) is mounted in the tubus on three points. therfore the ccd-camera is housed in the tubus too.
maybe some stars are deformed, as a effect of antiblooming.
but there is no connection beetween stars images and
comets tail.

michael

Date:  Thu, 01 Nov 2007 12:57:13 -0000
From:  Robert 
Subject:  Holmes with Registax4
Hello all !

Yesterday I shot Holmes with my Portaball Newton 12.5" at f5. Camera
used was a Lumenera 075m. Interesting structures were recorded
(wavelet filters in Registax). More info you could found under the image.

http://www.pbase.com/astrophoto/image/88236839/original

best skies for Holmes !

Robert Schulz
Vienna/Austria 

Date:  Thu, 01 Nov 2007 15:14:53 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  8P-20071029
http://fototime.com/A80256315519701/orig.jpg 

Date:  Thu, 01 Nov 2007 18:42:18 +0100
From:  Lorenzo Comolli 
Subject:  17P with tail from Tradate
Dear all,
yesterday finally the weather cleared up and I've capured some images of
the comet with my 30cm f/2.0 Schmidt Camera. As many others have noted,
the comet show a very fain tail, I've measured that the main component
is at PA 210° and a secondary tail is at PA 245°, extending from the
optocenter respectively about 32' and 26'. Many other filaments seems to
be present, as can be evidenced with a highly overprocessed blue frame.
The dust coma is 10' diameter and the gas coma is about 33'.

It would be interesting to compare the (quantitative) line profile of
the comet between the two dates below.

31 oct
http://www.astrosurf.com/comolli/com33e.htm

27 oct
http://www.astrosurf.com/comolli/com32e.htm

Regards,
Lorenzo

____________________________________________________________
Lorenzo Comolli
Internet: http://astrosurf.com/comolli/
E-mail: mailto:comolli@libero.it

Socio del Gruppo Astronomico Tradatese
Internet: http://www.gruppoastronomicotradatese.it/
____________________________________________________________

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Kevin Muenzler, WB5RUE
29º14'52"N 98º14'50"W
Eagle Creek Observatory
http://www.eaglecreekobservatory.org
http://www.cbcweb.net
In the beginning, there was nothing. And God said, 'Let there be Light.' And
there was still nothing, but you could see a bit better.

From: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com [mailto:Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of Lorenzo Comolli
Sent: Thursday, November 01, 2007 12:42 PM
To: undisclosed-recipients:
Subject: [Comet-Images] 17P with tail from Tradate

Dear all,
yesterday finally the weather cleared up and I've capured some images of the
comet with my 30cm f/2.0 Schmidt Camera. As many others have noted, the
comet show a very fain tail, I've measured that the main component is at PA
210° and a secondary tail is at PA 245°, extending from the optocenter
respectively about 32' and 26'. Many other filaments seems to be present, as
can be evidenced with a highly overprocessed blue frame.
The dust coma is 10' diameter and the gas coma is about 33'.

It would be interesting to compare the (quantitative) line profile of the
comet between the two dates below.

31 oct
http://www.astrosurf.com/comolli/com33e.htm

27 oct
http://www.astrosurf.com/comolli/com32e.htm

Regards,
Lorenzo

Date:  Fri, 02 Nov 2007 17:50:52 +0100
From:  Albert van Duin 
Subject:  17P tail
Hello all,

Here is an image from October 30, 2007 between 18:19 and 18:38 UT.
29 exposures of 20 seconds with a modified Canon 350D and a 8" F2.75 ASA Astrograph.
Pushing the curves in Photoshop and inverting shows some streamers from the coma.

http://www.astropix.nl/images/17P/29x20s-CombineFilesExcAvgDDPPSneg.jpg

Regards,
Albert van Duin
Netherlands

More images:
http://www.astropix.nl/images/17P/17P.html

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Fri, 02 Nov 2007 13:25:01 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  ASO, Comet 17P Update, Composite Images, Oct 25 through NOv2
Comet 17P Holmes UPDATE November 2 - Complete composite posting of all images since
outburst: October 25 through November 2 from Arkansas Sky Observatory
Image composites from Oct. 25 through Nov. 2 posted at:
http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php?topic=1429.msg6902#msg6902
Arkansas Sky Observatory (H45) update on Comet 17P for November 2

Comet imaged in moonless skies, high cirrus clouds
The comet maintains both brightness and physical attributes; morphology has not
appreciably changed, but again the overall diameter continues to grow at an
extraordinary rate. Coma is now somewhat of a bluish hue with a tint of yellow.
Coma overall diameter = 638" arc (CCD) with increasingly bright offset bright segment as
well as possible tail to
SW of nucleus - in PA 214, now extending to 88.5"" from nucleus, up from previous dates.
This inner condensed portion of the coma extends 183" arc from the nucleus, and is
surrounded by a symmetrical very dark circle, or void, that is located uniformly 202"
arc from the nucleus, surrounding the inner coma like a large "inner tube"

Coma appears considerably larger to the naked eye, perhaps as much as 20 arc minutes
Magnitude, m1 = 2.0, slightly brighter than previous night, very distinct cloud to the
naked eye with conspicuous nebulosity and NOW LESS yellow color; comparison star (naked
eye) is
Alpha Per
Nuclear magnitude, m2 = 11.6, continues to drop rapidly as the nucleus becomes even more
pinpoint

Overall color remains the same, very golden yellow throughout all expanses of the comet.

Equipment: 0.4m SCT @ f/3 CCD, ST402-ME C-I CCD, RGB @ 8 seconds. Overall magnitude
estimate via naked eye, Alpha Peg. by comparison

Clay
-------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/

Date:  Fri, 02 Nov 2007 22:38:50 +0100
From:  Toni Scarmato 
Subject:  17p observation
Dear all.

That is my observation.

Comet 17P/Holmes in outburst
2007 11 02.83, 1.9, 20', (T.Scarmato, Calabria, Italy, naked eye)
Clearly more active since yesterday night, at naked eye the comet show a
bright coma and a central condensation diffuse (DC=7),
in 25 cm Newton f/4.8 at 48x the ions tail is visible for about 0.5 deg with
some filaments. Also the outer green coma is faint but visible.
In the central zone I was able to detect some peculiar structure clarly
visible in my sum of 100x30 sec image taken on 2007 11 02 19:06:03 UT with
25 cm newtonian and CCD+Rc filter. The brigther 4 structures are in PA=220
deg.

See my homepage updated: http://digilander.libero.it/infosis/homepage/astronomia/17p.htm

Regards,
Toni Scarmato

Date:  Sat, 03 Nov 2007 11:57:08 -0000
From:  Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Subject:  New file uploaded to Comet-Images

Hello,

This email message is a notification to let you know that
a file has been uploaded to the Files area of the Comet-Images
group.

Date:  Sat, 03 Nov 2007 09:13:57 -0400
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  Holmes tail- where is it and  why we can't see it
from spaceweather.com

about why Holmes does not have a tail

"But where's the comet's tail? Like any good comet, Holmes' tail would tend
to point away from the Sun.
That direction is nearly along our line-of-sight behind the comet, making
its tail very difficult to see."

Dr. Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com), Olathe, KS: Lat 38.834, Lon -94.778:
Eclipse sightings > http://eclipse-sightings.blogspot.com/: E.O.A.S. (Earth,
Oceans, Atmosphere and Space) Blog -
:State of Kansas-JPL NASA Solar System Ambassador: Comet Observers Award

Date:  Sat, 03 Nov 2007 16:22:51 -0000
From:  Adrian Jones 
Subject:  17P Holmes - outer gas envelope
The outer gas envelope really is enormous. In this image from Nov 1-2
it measures over 30 arcmins. across!

http://universalconstant.com/17P_Holmes_grad.jpg

44 x 20 sec with Canon 350D at ISO 1600. Pentax 55 SDHF refractor.

The inset image is my attempt to reveal some detail using a rotational
gradient filter, but as you can see I'm no expert! I also need to
learn how to make a long exposure image tracking the comet, but avoid
trailing the stars.

Adrian
Maidenhead, UK

Dr. Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com), Olathe, KS: Lat 38.834, Lon -94.778:

your email to):CometObserversAwardAL-subscribe@yahoogroups.com : #2572 IMCA

**
> 4. Animation of coma growth: 17P Holmes from ASO
>     Posted by: "P. Clay Sherrod" drclay@tcworks.net drclay2002
>     Date: Wed Oct 31, 2007 11:28 am ((PDT))
>
> Provided is a series of ASO images from Oct. 26, 27, 29, 30, and 31 that
> show the
> remarkable explosion/expansion of the coma of comet 17P Holmes.
> The images are all at exactly the same scale (the field is about 6 arc
> minutes square)
> on each night and show the very rapid and dramatic growth of this unheralded
> event.
> http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php?topic=1437.0
>
> This may well be the most unique and impressive comet that we will ever see
> in our
> lifetimes and is currently very easy to see naked eye about 10 p.m. local
> time.
>
> Images are from the ASO 0.4m SCT at f/3, CCD, all 5 seconds RGB.
>
> Much thanks to ASO Forum contributor Ron Wayman for this work in providing
> this fine
> animation.
>
> Clay
> -------------
> Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
> Arkansas Sky Observatories
> Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
> Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
> Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
> http://www.arksky.org/

Date:  Sun, 04 Nov 2007 19:47:10 +1300
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  C/2007F1 (LONEOS) imaged last night in the southern sky
Hi all,

C/2007F1 (LONEOS) is just starting to appear in the southern skies. I imaged it last night in the late twilight as it was only a few degrees above the SW horizon. I imaged it with a Canon 10D DSLR camera and 41cm (16") f4.5 Newtonian. 8 x 1 minute subs @ 800ISO. I photographed it on Saturday 3.33 November 2007 (UT). Visually I could see a faint tail with an 8cm refractor...

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet_loneos-c2007f1-8x1min@800asa-20cm@f4,6-071103-drummond-web.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/ys7w6v

Cheers

John Drummond
Possum Observatory (IAU Code: E94)
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 177° 53', S 38° 38'
Email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz
Images: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/latest_images-all-continuing.htm

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Date:  Sun, 04 Nov 2007 10:30:05 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  ASO - 17P Update, Nov. 4
UPDATE November 4 - Latest Image at
http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php?topic=1429.msg6902#msg6902
Arkansas Sky Observatory (H45) update on Comet 17P:
Comet imaged in moonless skies, high cirrus clouds
The comet has decreased slightly in brightness, both total and nuclear morphology has
not
appreciably changed, but again the overall diameter continues to grow at an
extraordinary rate.
Coma overall diameter = 832" arc (CCD) with increasingly bright offset bright segment as
well as possible tail to
SW of nucleus - in PA 216, the previous very bright "knot" of concentration has lessened
drastically over the past 72 hours.
Coma appears very large and distinct to the naked eye, perhaps as much as 20 arc minutes
Magnitude, m1 = 2.4, (naked eye) noticeably dimmer than previous night, very distinct
cloud to the
naked eye with conspicuous nebulosity and yellow color; comparison star (naked eye) is
Alpha Per
Nuclear magnitude, m2 = 12.2, continues to drop rapidly as the nucleus becomes even more
pinpoint

Overall color remains the same, very golden yellow throughout all expanses of the comet.

Equipment: 0.4m SCT @ f/3 CCD, ST402-ME C-I CCD, RGB @ 8 seconds. Overall magnitude
estimate via naked eye, Alpha Peg. by comparison

Clay
-------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/

Date:  Mon, 05 Nov 2007 07:53:30 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  ASO Update, Comet 17P, Nov. 5
UPDATE November 5 - Latest Image is posted at:
http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php?topic=1429.msg6902#msg6902
Arkansas Sky Observatory (H45) update on Comet 17P:
Comet imaged in moonless skies, haze and poor conditions
The comet has maintained steady brightness, both total and nuclear morphology has not
appreciably changed, and although the coma appears to be attaining a more uniformly
spread intensity and density, the size has increased only slightly.
Coma overall diameter = 838" arc (CCD) with increasingly bright offset bright segment as
well as possible tail to
SW of nucleus - in PA 216, the previous very bright "knot" of concentration has lessened
drastically over the past 72 hours.
Coma appears very large and distinct to the naked eye, perhaps as much as 20 arc minutes
Magnitude, m1 = 2.4, (naked eye) nearly equal to previous night, very distinct cloud to
the
naked eye with conspicuous nebulosity and NOW appears to be losing the previous distinct
yellow color; comparison star (naked eye) is Alpha Per
Nuclear magnitude, m2 = 12.4, continues to drop rapidly as the nucleus becomes even more
pinpoint

NOTE that astrometry continues to place the very starlike nucleus at very nearly precise
to the predicted (MPC) center position of this comet, with very little offset since its
original outburst.

Overall color is nearly colorless, with slight yellow tint, throughout all expanses of
the comet.

Equipment: 0.4m SCT @ f/3 CCD, ST402-ME C-I CCD, RGB @ 8 seconds. Overall magnitude
estimate via naked eye, Alpha Peg. by comparison

Clay
-------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/ 

Date:  Mon, 05 Nov 2007 14:57:41 +0100
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  Comet 17P/Holmes from the Virtual Telescope, Italy - 4 Nov. 2007
Dear All,

Last night I tried to image comet 17P. I used the main unit
available at the Virtual Telescope, based on a C14@f/9
(scale: 0.58"/pixel) + SBIG ST8-XME + Paramount ME.

30 images, each 60 sec. long were used to finally get this:

http://virtualtelescope.bellatrixobservatory.org/17p_4nov07.jpg

Seeing was quite good: 1.5/2.0".

I tried to keep the image processing as much gentle as
possible. While the inner structures can be shown at their
full strength, I decided to handle them carefully.

Clear skies,
Gianluca

From:  David Nicholls

> File : /michael jaeger/17P20071104lrgbnet.jpg
> Uploaded by : schmidtcamera2500
> Description : 17P nov 4 LRGB 8"/f-540 M.Jger
>
> You can access this file at the URL:
> http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/michael%20jaeger/17P20071104lrgbnet.jpg

Totally amazing. I was hoping you'd do a colour version of the stunning
B&W images, and now you have.

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Mon, 05 Nov 2007 11:01:08 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Densitometer display of 17P core
Interesting aspect of the core of this comet; the scanning densitometer gradient (right)
extends a full 208 arc seconds in P.A. 216, the same as the developing straight tail or
ejection from the central nucleus of 17P Holmes. Note that the densitometry reveals
that the core has a uniform gradient, but that the gradient is centered on what "was"
the bright ejection mass that was some 65" arc from the nucleus on Nov. 3.

http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php?topic=1442.0

This monochrome image is 2 seconds to show the features within the core only, taken with
the 0.4m SCT at H45 Petit Jean Mountain South of Arkansas Sky Observatory, by P. Clay
Sherrod.
The nucleus on Nov. 5 at 04:40 UT was magnitude 12.4, the total size of the coma (not
seen to its entire extent in this image) was 838 arc seconds, with the developing tail
in position angle 216 deg.

Clay
-------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/ 

Date:  Mon, 05 Nov 2007 19:22:11 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  17P-20071105-color
Hello. What great images are being posted. michael--if you ever hold
a comet imaging conference---count me in! I will start saving money
for the airfair.
This image was inspired by something I did last night. I looked up.
For the first time in a long time I got out the binoculars and a 12:00
midnight our time I looked at this comet. Normally I only see what the
computer shows me. I then took 10 minutes each of RG&B filtered
images. Stacked on the false nuk of the comet and did a combine.
There was no color or levels processing. a mild sharp was done and
this was the result. It also shows the faint green around the outer
edge. Stand back and take a look.
Thanks, Mike H.

http://fototime.com/FAA836741F67237/orig.jpg

Date:  Tue, 06 Nov 2007 15:19:31 +1100
From:  Michael Mattiazzo 
Subject:  C/2007 T1 McNaught image Nov 5
Hello all,

I've uploaded a wide field image of C/2007 T1 McNaught with globular
clusters M19 and NGC 6293 in the field of view.
2007 Nov 5.42 UT. 3x2 min exposures, ISO 800, Canon 300D digital camera +
300mm zoom lens, cropped.

I estimated the comet at magnitude 10.0 through 25x100mm binoculars.

http://www.yp-connect.net/~mmatti/

Cheers,
Michael Mattiazzo

----- Segue Messaggio Originale -----
Da : "Gianluca Masi"
A : Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Cc: gianluca@bellatrixobservatory.org
oggetto : Comet 17P/Holmes from the Virtual Telescope, Italy
- 4 Nov. 2007
Data : Mon, 05 Nov 2007 14:57:41 +0100

> Dear All,
>
> Last night I tried to image comet 17P. I used the main
> unit available at the Virtual Telescope, based on a
> C14@f/9 (scale: 0.58"/pixel) + SBIG ST8-XME + Paramount
> ME.
>
> 30 images, each 60 sec. long were used to finally get
> this:
>
http://virtualtelescope.bellatrixobservatory.org/17p_4nov07.jpg
>
> Seeing was quite good: 1.5/2.0".
>
> I tried to keep the image processing as much gentle as
> possible. While the inner structures can be shown at their
> full strength, I decided to handle them carefully.
>
> Clear skies,
> Gianluca

Date:  Wed, 07 Nov 2007 10:31:50 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Comet 17P ASO Update, Nov. 7
UPDATE November 7 - Latest Image and information
New updates beginning Nov. 7 Posted at:
http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php?topic=1445.0
Please see: http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php?topic=1429.0 for daily updates, Oct.
25 through Nov. 5

Arkansas Sky Observatory (H45) update on Comet 17P:
Comet imaged in moonless skies, fair conditions
The comet has maintained steady brightness, both total and nuclear morphology has not
appreciably changed, and the overall size of the coma has grown considerably, as has the
developing tail emerged vividly in P.A. 219 deg.
Coma overall diameter = 11.3' arc (CCD) with increasingly bright offset bright segment
as well as possible tail to
SW of nucleus - in PA 219, the previous very bright "knot" of concentration has lessened
drastically over the past 72 hours.
Coma appears very large and distinct to the naked eye, perhaps as much as 25 arc minutes
Magnitude, m1 = 2.4, (naked eye) nearly equal to previous night, very distinct cloud to
the
naked eye with conspicuous nebulosity and NOW appears to have totally lost the previous
distinct yellow color; comparison star (naked eye) is Alpha Per
Nuclear magnitude, m2 = 12.4, continues to drop rapidly as the nucleus becomes even more
pinpoint

Overall color is nearly colorless, with slight yellow tint, throughout all expanses of
the comet.
NOTE that the updated image at the end of the ASO sequence here, is in MONOCHROME size
there is very little hue of color to the coma at this time.

Equipment: 0.4m SCT @ f/3 CCD, ST402-ME C-I CCD, RGB @ 8 seconds. Overall magnitude
estimate via naked eye, Alpha Per. by comparison.

Clay
-------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/ 

Date:  Wed, 07 Nov 2007 18:53:55 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  17P-20071106 #2
Hello. On the 6th information was taken at 2 different times. The
previous image posted was from the later session which was 2 minute
exposures. This image is from the 40 second images and I used blue
filtered images for the lum. channel. Once again I have not gone for
tail(s) but I am looking more for where the ion gas starts. I also
worked on the false nuk and the bubble effects in the center of the
area trying to keep all parts visible.
Hope you like it
Mike H.

http://fototime.com/941097314BDD234/standard.jpg

http://fototime.com/941097314BDD234/orig.jpg 

Date:  Wed, 07 Nov 2007 23:29:47 -0000
From:  sierrastars2 
Subject:  SSO Image of Comet Holmes

A couple of night agao I took images of comet Holmes that show what I
believe are part of the dust tail from the comet. As you can see
below I took Lunimance images using an IR filter instead of Clear to
try to bring out this detai.

To view the images go to www.sierrastars.com/gp/What's_New.aspx. The
seeing andtransparency were good so I wanted to see how much detail I
could image ofthe potential dust in the tail and in the coma. The
images are 30 minuteLRGB total exposures were the Luminance data
comes from an Infrared filter.

Exposure times were:

I = 30 x 30 seconds

B, V, R = 10 x 30 seconds each filter

Experimenting with the various filters I found that I could get most
detail using IR for the Luminance than a straight full spectrum
Luminance. You can make out subtle detail in the image. One of the
images has no image processing other than combining the color
composite while I used an FFT high band pass filter the other image
to try to bring out detail using that technique. I tracked on the
comet and stacked the images on the nucleus therefore you can see
some separation in the field stars. It seems that the comet is slowly
turning from coming almost straight on (or away) from our
point of view. This is quite an amazing serendipitous event and a
lot of fun to follow!

Rich Williams
Sierra Stars Observatory
115 Chambers Lane
Markleeville, CA 96120
Email: richw@sierrastars.com
Phone: 775-781-5700
Web: www.sierrastars.com

Date:  Fri, 09 Nov 2007 01:19:45 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  17P-20071108
Hello
I was not going to post information from last night untill I saw the
image Rolado linked and I knew then that there really wasn't any tail
in my images and I knew why. I just figured something had gone haywire
or something. This image is a 38x40 second exposure with a stack on
the comet and median combine. Applied a histrogram and no other
processing. The other two are the same image except turned negative.
IWe all have seen the tail structure over the past week or so and this
is what I was after. I am not sure if or where the other structure
running parallel comes from or if it is real.
Thanks, Mike H.

http://fototime.com/B680D19D2405B1C/orig.jpg

Date:  Fri, 09 Nov 2007 16:47:20 -0000
From:  byen00 
Subject:  Holmes astrograph photos 11/1, 11/5, 11/7
http://cometphoto.blogspot.com
[ did LIVE blogging from my 4x4 van w/mobile-satellite-DSL on 11/1 ]

I went out 3 days (11/1, 11/5, 11/7). On 11/7 I also got in a closeup shot of the nucleus
w/jet. I also found a new observation area, there are some nice panoramic views of the
comet w/Milky Way. I observed 3 neg magnitude meteors..very memorable. 1 had a red
nucleus, that left a persistent-trail.

It was really beautiful in the mountains, I did some 4x4'ing afterwards. Bad weather until
about Monday.

Has anyone noticed any weakening of the comet?

Date:  Sat, 10 Nov 2007 04:31:02 -0000

Date:  Sat, 10 Nov 2007 08:36:59 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Comet 17P, Inner coma structure
UPDATE November 10 - Latest Image at http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php?topic=1450.0
Arkansas Sky Observatory (H45) update on Comet 17P: Fine tail structure developing near
nucleus
Comet imaged in moonless skies, good conditions
The comet has decreased total brightness, both total and nuclear as coma continues
expansion;
appreciably changed, and the overall size of the coma has grown considerably, as has the
developing tail emerged vividly in P.A. 209 deg.
with at least one parallel secondary tail seen in negative inset image.
Coma overall diameter = 11.3' arc (CCD)
Coma appears very large and distinct to the naked eye, perhaps as much as 25 arc minutes
Magnitude, m1 = 2.9, (naked eye) nearly equal to previous night, very distinct cloud to
the
naked eye with conspicuous nebulosity and NOW appears to have totally lost the previous
distinct yellow color; comparison star (naked eye) is Alpha Per
Nuclear magnitude, m2 = 13.5, continues to drop rapidly as the nucleus becomes even more
pinpoint

Overall color is now somewhat blue.

Equipment: 0.4m SCT @ f/3 CCD, ST402-ME C-I CCD, RGB @ 40 RGB seconds. Overall
magnitude
estimate via naked eye, Alpha Per. by comparison.

Clay
-------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/ 

Date:  Sat, 10 Nov 2007 07:02:41 -0800
From:  Michael Borman 
Subject:  Comet Holmes 17P - 10/28, 11/4, 11/10
Here is a composite I put together of the growth of the coma from 10/28/2007 till last night 11/10/2007:

http://www.geocities.com/mfb_eas/

All three images were taken with the same setup - a Televue 102iis refractor, 2X Televue Powermate, and a Canon 20Da DSLR, on a Losmandy G11 mount.

Mike Borman
Evansville, Indiana, USA

Mike Borman

Mike's Astronomy, Rocketry, & Weather Site: http://www.geocities.com/mfb_eas/
EAS webpage: http://evansvilleastro.org/
Launch Crue webpage: www.geocities.com/launchcrue
Obsessed Of The EAS webpage: www.geocities.com/obsessed_eas
Carnivorous Plants Website: www.geocities.com/carniv_plants

From:  tricks46 
Subject:  17P-7 Day Animation
Hello. I was able to gather information after I added a FR to the
scope on 7 out of 9 nights. The images in this are from Nov.
2,4,5,6,8,9,10. Each image is a 5x35 sec exp through a blue filter
with a median combine. Enlarged 2x and croped for size. Animation
made in Gif Animation with a stack on the false center. About 650kb in
size
Thanks, Mike H.

Date:  Mon, 12 Nov 2007 01:17:22 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Nov. 12 Update, 17P from ASO
UPDATE November 12 - Latest Image at
http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php?topic=1450.msg7019#msg7019
Arkansas Sky Observatory (H45) update on Comet 17P:
Comet imaged in moonless skies, good conditions, perhaps last opportunity before moon
interferes
The comet has continued to decrease in total brightness, both total and nuclear as coma
continues expansion;
Physical morphology NOT appreciably changed, and the overall size of the coma has grown
only slight in past few days, developing tail streamers vividly in P.A. 209 deg.
with several parallel secondary tails seen in negative inset image.
Coma overall diameter = 15.9' arc (CCD)
Coma appears very large and distinct to the naked eye, perhaps as much as 25 arc minutes
Magnitude, m1 = 2.9, (naked eye) nearly equal to previous night, very distinct cloud to
the
naked eye with conspicuous nebulosity and NOW appears to have totally lost the previous
distinct yellow color; comparison star (naked eye) is Alpha Per
Nuclear magnitude, m2 = 13.6, continues to drop rapidly as the nucleus becomes even more
pinpoint

Overall color is now colorless, but somewhat blue.

Equipment: 0.4m SCT @ f/3 CCD, ST402-ME C-I CCD, RGB @ 40 RGB seconds. Overall
magnitude
estimate via naked eye, Alpha Per. by comparison

Clay
-------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/

Date:  Wed, 14 Nov 2007 01:01:31 -0000
From:  Eddie Guscott 
Subject:  What Colour is Holmes?
Hello List

I have been quite happy with my images for several nights showing the
yellowish inner coma and turquoise blue/green outer coma which seemed
consistent with many other images.

However, the past two nights have produced images with a distinct
yellowy/red inner coma! I have been processing all my images in
virtually the same way, and using the same camera (ST10 CCD camera
with RGB filters).

The majority of images that I have seen taken with a dSLR are showing
either a blue inner coma or a colourless (silvery/white) inner coma.

Am I experiencing problems with my filters or is there some rational
explanation? Maybe it has to do with the colour response of dSLR
cameras in general...

As an example:

An image with my CCD from Oct 28:
http://www.astropics.co.uk/17PHolmes-28October.jpg
An image from November 11:
http://www.astropics.co.uk/17PHolmes-11NovemberUSM.jpg
A dSLR image from Nov 10:
http://www.clearskies.se/Holmes%20meets%20Mirphak.htm
A dSLR image from Oct 28:
http://www.spaceweather.com/comets/holmes/28oct07/Xiang-ZHAN1.jpg

Can anyone shed any light? Offer any insights?

Appreciate any thoughts on this

Eddie Guscott 

Date:  Wed, 14 Nov 2007 08:28:21 +0100
From:  Klaas Jobse 
Subject:  Image P/2007 T2 Kowalski nov 14
Hello,

This morning I managed to image P/2007 T2 Kowalski;

http://www.klaas-jobse.net/cyclops/kometen/20071114%20T2%20%2010x60&9x120sWeb.jpg

Klaas

Tony Farkas
Okinawa Japan 

Date:  Wed, 14 Nov 2007 08:21:53 -0000

Date:  Wed, 14 Nov 2007 14:17:19 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: What Colour is Holmes?
I can only give my 2 cents here.
I try to follow one rule. Process your background and set your
stars to the real color. Doing this and not overprocessing will put
the comet close. You may not like it but if your stars are true the
comet must follow. You can't depend on images that are designed to
show outer faint aspects of the comet. This doesn't mean they are
incorrect just that inhancing the faint blows out the brighter
parts. Remembering there are no pink stars or green stars or all
stars can't be blue will only help you.
Mike H.

Date:  Thu, 15 Nov 2007 16:20:17 -0000
From:  Dave Kodama 
Subject:  Re: 17p image    True color  ?
Mike,

An unmodified DSLR with its broadband color filters should give the
most "natural" shots unless the comet has some emission lines that
fall into dips in the response curves (like the problem of OIII with
many films), but the main problem is everyone is processing the images
differently. I've seen white, yellow, green, and purple versions of
the comet!

Dave

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "tricks46" wrote:
>
> Thats nice! I wanted to get a DSLR but can't quite get there yet. It
> would be hard to say this is not a true color considering the camera.
> Sence you use a DSLR do you see a difference in the individual cameras
> or chips giving a different color outcome or are they all about the
> same?
>
> --- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "clearshot04"
> wrote:
> >
> > 2007 11 13
> > Canon 10D 400mm f5.6 400iso 500sec
> > Mount 10" LX 200 GPS
> >
> > No tweeks or PS tricks, just a little darkening.
> >
> > http://farm3.static.flickr.com/2083/2025408844_f60902052c_b.jpg
> >
>

Date:  Thu, 15 Nov 2007 22:33:17 -0000
From:  byen00 
Subject:  Comet Holmes from Baja/Mexico & Anza Borrego
http://cometphoto.blogspot.com

I'm posting from Anza Borrego (using my mobile satellite-DSL dish on my 4x4 van). I just
returned from the 40th anniversary Baja 1000. I was doing double-duty: LIVE race-coverage
& iTunes video-podcast coverage of the race (daytime) & nighttime astrophoto of Comet
Holmes.

My wide-angle photos don't seem to be picking up any ion tail, is this what everyone else is
getting. When I return home, I can develop the TP2415 film images from 8" f1.5 Schmidt-
camera..it might reveal something.

Date:  Thu, 15 Nov 2007 19:30:19 -0500
From:  Takbounorca@aol.com
Subject:  17P
Hi,
Tonight I imaged comet with a telephoto 300 mm F / 4 Sigma APO and Audine
3200 ME.
Around 19h00 UT coma covers just the stars TYC 3320 434 and TYC 3320 936.
It reached 30.8'.
The comet is located at 1.63086 AU (243972937 km) is a dimension: 2289150
km.
See image made tonight: http://napac.free.fr/.

Sincerely
S. Takbou

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Fri, 16 Nov 2007 00:40:45 -0000
From:  Dave Kodama 
Subject:  Re: Another widefield of Comet Holmes
Mike,

Yes, I think you're looking a a small string of stars. And the frame
top is slightly canted towards the NW, by the way. Keep those
detailed images of the the head coming. It seems that's where the
major action is happening. I think the outer structures are going to
dissipate and we're going to end up with just a gradually dimming dust
ball.

Dave

3x60 sec exp thru a clear filter. Removed the FR so the setup is
back to 660mm at F5.2. Croped out the comet and left the blooms.

Date:  Sun, 18 Nov 2007 07:28:36 -0800
From:  Michael Borman 
Subject:  17p/Holmes Approaching Mirfak
Holmes and Mirfak are now both in the same field of view of my 4" refractor:

http://www.geocities.com/mfb_eas/

A 3 minute exposure at ISO 1600 with a Canon 20Da through a Televue 102iis refractor with .8X focal reducer on a Losmandy G11 mount.

Mike Borman
Evansville, Indiana, USA

Date:  Sun, 18 Nov 2007 16:00:33 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  17P-2007/11/18rgb-rgbl
Hello.
Two versions of the same image. The second link has a 2 minute Lum
channel added. Mirfak is overpowering for a blooming camera. Seemed
and I say seemed to be a faint halo around the center false nuk
compaired to 2 nights ago. Also B&W shows streamers. I like the comet
more now than anytime before.
Thanks
Mike H
Holloway Comet Observatory
Van Buren, Ar

http://fototime.com/1C818B0E6B815EB/orig.jpg

http://fototime.com/B627095F3EE4786/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sun, 18 Nov 2007 17:19:49 +0100
From:  Albert van Duin 
Subject:  3D Holmes
Hi,

I made a 3D anaglyph picture of 17P/Holmes yesterday evening.
http://www.astropix.nl/images/17P/anaglyph.jpg

The left image was made around 19:30 UT, the right image was made around 21:50 UT on November 17, 2007.
Each image is a stack of 10 - 60 second exposures made with an 8" F2.75 ASA Astrograph and a modified Canon 350D DSLR.
Hope you like it. To view use a pair of red-green or red-blue glasses, red glass left.

More images at http://www.astropix.nl

Cheers,

Albert van Duin

works well!
Best regards,

Date:  Sun, 18 Nov 2007 20:13:14 -0000
From:  androsc2003 
Subject:  Re: 17p/Holmes
Hi Dave,

I probably should have clipped the edges of the image more. Due to
stacking, some of the stars in the upper left hand corner are green
due to the fact that the other colors are missing. Otherwise in the
main areas of the image, I tried hard to achieve a good color
balance.

Thaknk you for the comment -

Mike

http://digilander.libero.it/infosis/homepage/astronomia/17p.htm

Regards,
Toni Scarmato 

Date:  Mon, 19 Nov 2007 15:03:21 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  November 18 Update 17P
UPDATE November 18 - Latest Image updated at
http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php?topic=1450.msg7019#msg7019
Arkansas Sky Observatory (H45) update on Comet 17P:
Comet imaged in moonless skies, good conditions, offset coma cloud has all but
dissipated, but tail has developed
The comet has continued to decrease in total brightness, both total and nuclear as coma
continues expansion;
Physical morphology NOT appreciably changed, and the overall size of the coma has grown
only slight in past few days, developing tail streamers vividly in P.A. 209 deg.
with several parallel secondary tails seen in negative inset image.
Coma overall diameter = 13.9' arc (CCD)
Coma appears very large and now is very diffuse and difficult to the naked eye,
estimated at about 22 arc minutes
Magnitude, m1 = 3.4, (naked eye) very difficult and large to the naked eye, colorless
and NOW appears to have totally lost the previous distinct yellow color; comparison star
(naked eye) is Alpha Per
Nuclear magnitude, m2 = 14.2, continues to drop rapidly as the nucleus becomes even more
pinpoint

Overall color is now colorless, and therefore this image is has been taken in
monochrome.

Equipment: 0.4m SCT @ f/3 CCD, ST402-ME C-I CCD, 50 seconds. Overall magnitude
estimate via naked eye, Alpha Per. by comparison.

Clay
-------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/
