Date:  Wed, 21 Nov 2007 07:35:51 -0000
From:  Dave Kodama 
Subject:  Comet Holmes evolution

Here's a set of wide field comet photos from the past 3 weekends,
overlaid so the changes in the comet are apparent:

http://www.eanet.com/kodama/astro/2007/17p-holmes/novholmes.htm

The page is large because there are 4 large images involved. If you get
impatient, here'a a direct link to only the composite shot:

http://www.eanet.com/kodama/astro/2007/17p-holmes/composite3.htm

Dave 

Date:  Wed, 21 Nov 2007 13:21:43 -0500
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  happy T day and catch more comets
happy Thanksgiving day
Those trying for comet silver and gold awards, amateur astronomers and
other sky observers (se below).
Comet Holmes has lessened in brightness but still great in scopes and binocs.
It is still quite large around the diameter of moon angular wise. I think it
is around 5 mag or so.
My pics and more coming at
http://eoas-dreric1kansas.blogspot.com/
In the sky you can also see the following other Broughton, Lovas, Tuttle and
Linear Mueller.
You need a good scope for these. They are fainter and don't have much of
way of tails. So they are more difficult to find. Lovas in particular looks like
a nebulous little ball.
I will post pics when I can in the future.

Dr. Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com), Olathe, KS: Lat 38.834, Lon -94.778:
Comet Observers Award Coordinator- Astronomical League / Astronomical
Society of Kansas, KC, MO-Louisburg,KS:
http://www.astroleague.org/al/obsclubs/comet/comet.htm: Subscribe to (send your email
to):CometObserversAwardAL-subscribe@yahoogroups.com : : Eclipse sightings >
http://eclipse-sightings.blogspot.com/: E.O.A.S. (Earth, Oceans, Atmosphere and Space) Blog -<
http://eoas-dreric1kansas.blogspot.com/>:State of Kansas-JPL NASA Solar System Ambassador: #2572
IMCA

**************************************

hottest products.

(http://money.aol.com/special/hot-products-2007?NCID=aoltop00030000000001)

Subject:  Looking for Images of 8P Tuttle
Hello Group,
I am in the process of putting together my club's newsletter for
December and I am looking for recent images of 8P Tuttle to include in
an article I am writing. The article includes finder charts and images
of both 17P Holmes and 8P Tuttle along with at litte history about each
comet. If I use an image provided by you I will send you a copy (pdf
format) of the issue. I like to include as much image info as possible
so please try to provide.
Thank you in advance.
Mark S Deprest
msdeprest@comcast.net

Date:  Mon, 26 Nov 2007 20:57:59 -0000
From:  back40observatory 
Subject:  Holmes/17p
Wonderful photos! Has the orbit of Holmes changed since the explosion?

Thanks,
Charles 

Date:  Mon, 26 Nov 2007 15:41:55 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Holmes/17p
The outburst has NOT changed any orbital parameters of the comet, at least on the short
term; we have kept monitoring astrometrically the nucleus of the comet since the initial
outburst and there appears to be absolutely no shift from the parameters that were in
place prior to the event.

Clay
-------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/

Date:  Wed, 28 Nov 2007 16:54:28 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  8P - 2007/11/28
Hello. This is a 25x40 sec exp. After working on my setup I couldn't
figure out which way was N by compairing software and the image. I was
seeing faint tail structure in the N/E position if N is up which would
be correct. If N is down then I don't know what is what. Sometimes
things just go that way I guess. This is composed of 13 images
unfiltered through a clear non-IR blocking filter and 12 through rgb
with IR-block filters. Shows the difference in star bloat. Comet is
on the verge of looking really nice and is moving a lot faster than the
last time I imaged it a month ago.
http://fototime.com/inv/DE3CD658E136560
Thanks, Mike H.

http://fototime.com/97179902F907C5E/standard.jpg

http://fototime.com/97179902F907C5E/orig.jpg 

Date:  Wed, 28 Nov 2007 18:27:02 +0100

Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] 8P - 2007/11/28
> After working on my setup I couldn't
> figure out which way was N by compairing software and the image.

North down, East to the right.
regards,
Giovanni Sostero 

Date:  Wed, 28 Nov 2007 22:29:01 +0100
From:  Danilo Pivato 
Subject:  Comet 17/P (Holmes) 2007.11.28
Hi all,

Date:  Thu, 29 Nov 2007 22:09:21 -0000
From:  Carey Johnson 
Subject:  17P images.
Here is the results of last nights imaging of Comet Holmes.

http://www.flickr.com/photo_zoom.gne?id=2073920519&size=o

http://www.flickr.com/photo_zoom.gne?id=2074712006&size=o

Pretty ugly, I know. I took these out the window of my apartment in
Waikiki. I used a Meade 8" SCT with a 6.3 focal reducer and a Canon
300D.

2000mm f/10 X .63 = FL 1260 f/6.3

Time to go back to the 80mm,
FL 400mm f/5

I rushed the processing too, I have to rush off ro work :(

Carey

Date:  Thu, 29 Nov 2007 20:54:29 -0500
From:  Takbounorca@aol.com
Subject:  Wide-field: my best image of the comet 17/P Holmes (2007 nov 29.93)

Good evening,

Another image 17 / P Holmes conducted tonight before the rain arrived on the
North.

Audine Kaf 3200 ME
Alaudine NT
Temperature ext: 05.0 °
Cooling: -25 °
Tele Sigma 300 mm F / 4 APO
Time Exposure: 3 x (5 x 50 seconds filters (RGB))
Date and time of the shooting: 29 November 2007 22h20mn (Midfielder
Exposure)
Field: 3 ° x2 °.
See here:
_http://napac.free.fr/

Stéphane TAKBOU
_ (http://napac.free.fr/)

Observatoire de l'ancienne abbaye
MPC A11
N 50°52'48"
E 02°28'18"
Altitude 16 m
Wormhout
France
http://napac.free.fr/

Date:  Thu, 29 Nov 2007 22:03:13 -1000
From:  Carey Johnson 
Subject:  RE: [Comet-Images] New file uploaded to Comet-Images

This is a Great image.
I applied some tweaks to it to see some inner detail and have uploaded a copy to inquire about something that has been puzzeling me.

www.windowslive.com/smile?ocid=TXT_TAGLM_Wave2_oprsmilewlhmtagline

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Thu, 29 Nov 2007 22:10:58 -1000
From:  Carey Johnson 
Subject:  RE: [Comet-Images] New file uploaded to Comet-Images

For some time now we have been seeing these 3 lines in the tail. The center line traces back to the left side of the comets head, but the other 2 lines trace back to a point on either side of the head, out in the middle of nowhere.

Looking at the image I uploaded here, there seems to be some concentrated spots at 1 o'clock and 9 o'clock from the head of the comet.
What are these? Jets? Fragments?

With the Jets answer, I see (or imagine) a spiral coming off each side of the head of the comet.Actually the one at 1 o'clock looks like an ion tail.

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/17PCCrop.jpg

Carey

> From: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com> To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com> Date: Fri, 30 Nov 2007 08:00:27 +0000> Subject: [Comet-Images] New file uploaded to Comet-Images> > > Hello,> > This email message is a notification to let you know that> a file has been uploaded to the Files area of the Comet-Images > group.> > File : /17PCCrop.jpg > Uploaded by : quarkcsj > Description : Reproduction of michael jaeger/17P20071128rgbnet.jpg > > You can access this file at the URL:

Date:  Fri, 30 Nov 2007 17:45:25 -0000
From:  Mike Begbie 
Subject:  Re: 17P of this morning
--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "ligustri rolando"
wrote:
>
> Hi at all, this is my image taked this morning from NM with
> RAS system G14.
>
> http://comete.uai.it/17p/17P_071129.jpg
>
> best regards
> Rolando Ligustri
> ===============================
> C.A.R.A. http://cara.uai.it
> CAST: Circolo AStrofili Talmassons
> www.castfvg.it/fotoccd.htm#comete
>

Absolutely stunning! What amazes me is that your image shows all the
structures that are visible faintly with binoculars...just enhanced
and more apparent PLUS. The representation is fabulous...I remember
just a few years ago the images just did not match what was
attainable visually. The structure that is visible is not lost in
over-exposure, but instead it is wonderfully enhanced. Michael
Jaeger's images are incredible too...well done both of you. Your
previous images with Alpha Pegasi in the coma are also fantastic! I
just hope that there is still room for those of us who like to
sketch!!!

Best Regards

Mike

Date:  Mon, 03 Dec 2007 22:25:13 -0600
From:  Kevin Muenzler 
Subject:  It's HUGE!
Please excuse my excitement...it's been cloudy here since mid November. Is
it my imagination or is 17P about half the size of the full Moon (naked
eye)??

I haven't had time to view though the scope but naked eye it's very large.

Kevin Muenzler, WB5RUE
29º14'52"N 98º14'50"W
Eagle Creek Observatory
http://www.eaglecreekobservatory.org
http://www.cbcweb.net

Date:  Mon, 03 Dec 2007 19:34:49 -1000
From:  Carey Johnson 
Subject:  RE: [Comet-Images] It's HUGE!

Yeah, after learning how, I measured the diameter of 17P twice:

11/3/2007 it was 656,820 miles
http://www.flickr.com/photos/quarkcsj/1886770688/in/set-72157602205443426/

and

11/16/2007 it was 1,287,640 Miles
http://www.flickr.com/photos/quarkcsj/2036582711/in/set-72157602297783012/

I imaged it recently and it barely fit in my 8" SCT with a 6.3 Focal Reducer.
FL 2000mm f/10 X 0.63 = FL 1260mm f/6.3
http://www.flickr.com/photos/quarkcsj/2074712006/in/set-72157602205443426/

http://www.flickr.com/photos/quarkcsj/2082817193/in/set-72157602205443426/

So yeah, it's pretty huge.

The guest speaker at our astronomy club meeting tomorrow will be talking about their research on 17/P.

Cool!

Carey
http://www.windowslive.com/share.html?ocid=TXT_TAGLM_Wave2_sharelife_112007

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Tue, 04 Dec 2007 08:59:49 +0100
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  sequence and last image
Hi at all.

to these addresses you can see a sequence of images of the comet 17P sorts all with the
same setup in remote with the system Rent A Scope from the NM (USA):

http://comete.uai.it/17p/17P_071118.jpg
http://comete.uai.it/17p/17P_071129.jpg
http://comete.uai.it/17p/17P_071204.jpg

the last, made this morning, show the comet next to the Ngc1245

in the image of this morning (total 50min) with high contrast

http://comete.uai.it/17p/17P_071204_hc.jpg

I have measured a coma of 70'x130', equal to a dimension of
5600000x10300000 km, is this correct?

always on this image she is seen a structure that is cut by the comet:
is it an already present nebulosity or the comet is passing above to the
residue of the tail of ions of beginning November?

best regards
Rolando Ligustri
===============================
C.A.R.A. http://cara.uai.it
CAST: Circolo AStrofili Talmassons
www.castfvg.it/fotoccd.htm#comete 

Date:  Tue, 04 Dec 2007 14:23:26 +0100
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  Re: sequence and last image
> always on this image she is seen a structure that is cut by the comet:
> is it an already present nebulosity or the comet is passing above to the
> residue of the tail of ions of beginning November?

you excuse me.
checking with the catalog DSS, I have verified that nebulosity is
already present in the field before the comet!

regards
Rolando

Date:  Wed, 05 Dec 2007 10:41:26 +0100
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  comet 8P of this morning
Hi at all.
at this address I have inserted an color image of the comet 8P (Tuttle)
made this morning in remote from the NM:

http://comete.uai.it/8p/8P_071205.jpg

the color reports an interesting gaseous activity.

in this image to high contrast

http://comete.uai.it/8p/8P_071205hc.jpg

a bent tail is noticed to around PA 120
will we have a beautiful comet to end December? ;-)))

best regards
Rolando Ligustri

C.A.R.A. http://cara.uai.it

Date:  Wed, 05 Dec 2007 17:54:55 -0500
From:  Takbounorca@aol.com
Subject:  Holmes and NGC 1245

Good evening,
An image of the comet 17P Holmes and NGC 1245 realized tonight is now on my
site.
Shooting:
Field: 3 ° X 2 °
Audine Kaf 3200 ME
Alaudine NT
Temperature ext: 11.0 °
Cooling: -25 °
Télébjectif Sigma 300 mm F / 4 APO
Time Exposure: 2 x (5 x 60 seconds filtresRVB)
Date and time of the shooting: 05 December 2007 of 20h23mn (Midfielder
Exposure)
Reducing the image 50%.
Features: napac.free.fr
Thank you

Stéphane TAKBOU

Observatoire de l'ancienne abbaye
MPC A11
N 50°52'48"
E 02°28'18"
Altitude 16 m
Wormhout
France
http://napac.free.fr/

Date:  Thu, 06 Dec 2007 13:27:15 +0100
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] re:comet 8P of this morning
>ligustri
>That is a great image. Nice color and detail. One of the better ones I
>have seen and close up.

I thank all for the compliments that you have done to my images.

>What is the exposure , camera & telescope used etc etc and where did
>you take it?
>Dr. Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com), Olathe, KS: Lat 38.834, Lon -94.778:

Lately they are at home for convalescence, for this I am using different
telescopes of the system GRAS in NM (http://www.global-rent-a-scope.com/)

for the 8P photo I have used the system G3 that is constituted by an apo
TOA 150/852 with ccd ST10Xme, and I have used these times:
LBVR= 4x120sec each.
however I have to say that the quality of the sky is notable.
certain particular weak I succeed them in photographing only under that sky.

here, where we have us the observatory these skies them we can dream only ;-((((

best regards
Rolando Ligustri
===============================
C.A.R.A. http://cara.uai.it
CAST: Circolo AStrofili Talmassons
www.castfvg.it/fotoccd.htm#comete

The information for the images was listed on the B&W image. I took the
color information which was 3x40 seconds each for RG&B filtered images
just after the lum information was taken. Even at this short time
movement was an issue. Working on a 7 frame mosaic of 17p from last
night. Hope to get it put together soon but lots of work
Mike 

Date:  Thu, 06 Dec 2007 21:00:32 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  17P - 20071206
Hello. This was a project which includes 6 frames. Each frame has
10x40 second subframes. The original image was almost 4000 pix wide
but this has been reduced to 1650. Lots of faint galaxies and variables
along with the cluster NGC 1245. No color and the camera spikes are
left.
Thanks, Mike H.

http://fototime.com/D32DE57FB1A1AC3/orig.jpg

Date:  Sat, 08 Dec 2007 13:20:48 -0000
From:  Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Subject:  New file uploaded to Comet-Images

Hello,

This email message is a notification to let you know that
a file has been uploaded to the Files area of the Comet-Images
group.

File : /michael jaeger/17P20071205.jpg
Uploaded by : schmidtcamera2500
Description : 17P dec 5 Astrograph 4,5"/f2.8 M.Jger

You can access this file at the URL:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/michael%20jaeger/17P20071205.jpg

To learn more about file sharing for your group, please visit:
http://help.yahoo.com/l/us/yahoo/groups/original/members/web/index.htmlfiles

Regards,

schmidtcamera2500 

Date:  Sat, 08 Dec 2007 14:17:04 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Spitzer Images
Hello. Was wondering about the images that were attempted. Received
this.
This is part of the mail.
Thanks, Mike

"Dear Mike,
Spitzer is too sensitive to infrared emission to image the comet. I
took spectra of the infrared emission, and that worked very well. I
did also use the small peakup camera on the spectrograph to attempt
an image, but the result was completely saturated. So as a result I
have only the set of spectra. The comet was so bright that the
spectra are of very high quality, among the best ever taken. If you
want to spread this word, please feel free. There was a short and
very nice article in the Sky&Tel online about 17P that includes my
quotes on the Spitzer spectra.
Cheers,
Bill"

Date:  Sun, 09 Dec 2007 18:31:41 -0000
From:  Dennis 
Subject:  17P Holmes and 8P Tuttle
17P Holmes. It seems like 17P has elongated since last week. At the
eyepiece it looks as though a tail is trying to extend from the coma.
My observing partner (David Crum) and I observed comet 8P Tuttle in my
10" and his 16" scopes both last week and last night. The comet has
gained about 3 mags. from about 11.5 to about 8.5mag.No tail was
evident however. I think I saw a stellar looking core.
Dennis O'Day 

Date:  Sun, 09 Dec 2007 19:13:31 -0000
From:  Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com

Date:  Sun, 09 Dec 2007 20:13:39 +0100

Subject:  More 17P Holmes and 8P Tuttle
Hello all,

this evening.

http://www.astropix.nl/images/17P/17P.html

Weather has not been very favourable for astrophotography the last weeks...
But I keep hoping it will get better.

Netherlands

http://www.astropix.nl

Date:  Sun, 09 Dec 2007 17:55:59 -0500
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  wanted comet photos, ccd images or scanned sketches for new comet blog
I have started a new blog to feature photos of comet observations.
Comet Observers Blog
http://cometobservers.blogspot.com/

In 2001, I created the Comets Observer's Award for the Astronomical League.
Since then amateurs have gained silver and/or gold certificates and pins for
the achievements. This blog will showcase photos of comets by those who have
achieved the Comets Observer's Awards, those in process for the award as well
other amateur astronomers who have photographed with CCD images, regular
photos or sketched comets. This is an ongoing effort to post photos of recent comet
and encourage working towards the award(s).

I will attempt to post the best images of comets that I and others capture
through regular photos, ccd imaging or sketches (scanned jpeg). Observation/
photographs by other are welcome. My hope is more amateurs will begin and try
to achieve the silver or gold comet awards.

Send only your best.
I am looking for different images of various comets and photos. I can't post
all that arrive but I will do my best. ATTACH photo and include:(1) Name,
where you shot the comet; (2) your email address; (3) ccd/ reg photo/ sketch info;
(4) exposure, f stop camera info etc etc; (5) include "I (add your name) have
permission to use this image on the Comet Observers Blog" ; (6) all photos
are copyrighted by original author and will not be used in any other way by Dr.
Flescher unless permission granted.

More information about the comet award at
http://www.astroleague.org/al/obsclubs/comet/comet.htm

? let me know. I look forward to hearing from you-all.

Dr. Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com), Olathe, KS: Comet Observers Award
Coordinator- Astronomical League/ Astronomical Society of Kansas, KC,
MO-Louisburg,KS: http://www.astroleague.org/al/obsclubs/comet/comet.htm: Subscribe to
Comet Obervers Award Newsletter (send your email to):
CometObserversAwardAL-subscribe@yahoogroups.com :

**************************************
Check out AOL's list of 2007's
hottest products.

(http://money.aol.com/special/hot-products-2007?NCID=aoltop00030000000001)

Date:  Sun, 09 Dec 2007 21:52:34 -1000
From:  Carey Johnson 
Subject:  Comet 8P

Here is my first attempt at comet 8P, and my first processing run on the images.
I might re-work them. I took these while I was waiting for 17P to clear the top of my window frame in my apartment in Waikiki. I will have to get out and get these guys under some dark skies.

http://www.flickr.com/photos/quarkcsj/2099634043/

Carey

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Mon, 10 Dec 2007 12:11:38 -0000
From:  davidc22002 
Subject:  Comet 8/P Tuttle from Sanderson FL
The skies were really crappy, 4 out of 5, LOTS of moisture, lots of
clouds, we were shooting through the sucker holes all night, but a few
of us did manage to get some decent looks at Tuttle.

It has become much brighter since last week (Dec 1st). The core is
much brighter and the coma more pronounced (unless it was the moisture
causing some problems, lol) It was very easily seen through my 16 LB,
26mm Nagler.

My observing partner found it very easily through his 10 inch Dob as
well, views were a bit dimmer. 

Date:  Mon, 10 Dec 2007 16:41:23 -0000

Dennis O'Day 

Date:  Mon, 10 Dec 2007 19:42:04 +0100
From:  Albert van Duin 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] More 17P Holmes and 8P Tuttle
Hi James,

Thanks! My mount is a a Losmandy G11 with a Vixen SkySensor 2000 drive
system, thera are some pictures of my equipment on my main site.
http://www.astropix.nl
Yes, the fast f ratio is incredible and very nice for imaging fast moving
comets.
The Canon 350D chip is a nice match to the corrected field of the
Astrograph.
I just did some imaging as it was dark here two hours ago, but there was a
lot of moisture in the air.
So I don't think the results will be better than yesterday.

Regards,
Albert van Duin

Date:  Mon, 10 Dec 2007 20:32:46 +0100
From:  Albert van Duin 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] More 17P Holmes and 8P Tuttle
Hi James,

I forgot to tell about the magnitudes. To record faint stars, you need a
longer focal length,this Astrograph is about 560mm fl.
My telescope is ideal for nebulous objects because of its speed.

In my M51 image I got to about 20 from my back garden in two hours.
http://www.astropix.nl/images/M51/M51.html

Regards,
Albert van Duin

http://www.astropix.nl

Date:  Mon, 10 Dec 2007 18:44:50 -1000
From:  Carey Johnson 
Subject:  RE: [Comet-Images] Is that 8p  pretty much in the center?

Yes. I used a 400mm f/5 and a Canon 300D. Sorry I didn't get the specs up yet, I plan on processing it further. But this was over the light pollution of Honolulu, so it would be a lot better from a dark location.

Date:  Tue, 11 Dec 2007 17:54:25 -0500
From:  Takbounorca@aol.com
Subject:  Tonight a picture of 17P and NGC 1169

Hi All,

I just put on my site (http://napac.free.fr/) wide field images of the comet
Holmes RGB 10min.
It shows the small galaxy (NGC 1169) of mag 12.4 just below the comet.
Enjoy your visit.

Stéphane TAKBOU

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Tue, 11 Dec 2007 16:05:25 -1000
From:  Carey Johnson 
Subject:  RE: [Comet-Images] Is that 8p  pretty much in the center?

This will give you an idea of the condition in which I shot this.

I used an Orion ShortTube 80mm f/5 400mm FL and a Canon Digital Rebel 300D, 30 second exposures @ ISO 400.

The light pollution was too bad down that low, so I used ISO 400 for 8P and ISO 800 for 17P.

http://www.flickr.com/photos/quarkcsj/2103460388/

Carey

This is where something keeps cutting off my salutation and putting an advertisment link.
http://www.windowslive.com?ocid=TXT_TAGHM_Wave2_powerofwindows_122007

Date:  Wed, 12 Dec 2007 09:40:11 -0000
From:  Martin Mobberley 
Subject:  New images of 17P and 8P
I have just added my 27th night (!) image of 17P/Holmes and
my first decent 8P/Tuttle image to my comets pages at:

http://uk.geocities.com/martinmobberley/Comets.html

Regards,
Martin 

Date:  Wed, 12 Dec 2007 20:13:07 +0100
From:  Albert van Duin 
Subject:  Fw: Last nights images of 17P and 8P
Last night I finally got a clear sky long enough to image 17P Holmes for one hour.
I treated the image with a minimum filter to show the structure of the coma.
http://www.astropix.nl/images/17P/17P.html

I also took the chance to image 8P/Tuttle again under better conditions than before.
http://www.astropix.nl/images/8P/8P.html

Sky brightness was mag 20.0 / square arcsec according to the
Sky Quality Meter from Unihedron http://unihedron.com/projects/darksky/

Regards,
Albert van Duin

http://www.astropix.nl

Date:  Fri, 14 Dec 2007 16:30:14 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  17P-2007/12/14
Hello. Under an less than good sky with passing clouds, this is a
mosaic. Six frames were used with 5x30sec sub-frames. Croped by about
1/3 and then reduced in size by 50%. Might add color with time.
Rotated the image 90' CCW to better fit the widescreens.
Thanks, Mike H.

http://fototime.com/5382A1C5D28013C/orig.jpg 

Date:  Fri, 14 Dec 2007 18:06:39 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: 17P of this morning
Beautiful work Rolando!
Mike

Date:  Sun, 16 Dec 2007 00:49:35 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Merry Christmas List!
Hello.
Imaging comets is the hardest thing in the world. Direction, speed,
location, weather and all things make this true. If you don't take an
image at the correct time on a specific night, it is lost and unlike
deep space objects will be lost forever. I have always thought that
personal stuff and business was something that needed to be kept
seperate but this time I will break my own rule and say that to the
best group of comet imagers in the world
MERRY CHRISTMAS! You are without a doubt the best and special group
of imagers and deserve only the best so take care and whatever you do
keep your scopes busy imaging that which we all love and learning that
which we don't already know. Cheers!!!!

Mike Holloway
Holloway Comet Observatory
Van Buren, AR 

Date:  Sun, 16 Dec 2007 14:26:39 +0100
From:  Albert van Duin 
Subject:  C/2006 S5(Hill) last night
Hello all,

Last night I made an image of C/2006 S5 (Hill) showing a bit of tail.
It is a stack of 12 - 300second exposures acquired between 0:33 and 1:36 UT on December 16, 2007
http://www.astropix.nl/images/2006S5/S5.html

Regards,
Albert van Duin

http://www.astropix.nl

Date:  Sun, 16 Dec 2007 10:04:02 -0800
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2006 S5(Hill) last night

Date:  Thu, 20 Dec 2007 20:13:42 -0600
From:  Kevin Muenzler 
Subject:  17/P Holmes and Algol
According to my humble calculations 17/p will pass less than 10' from Algol
on January 21!

Am I off or is this going to be a very close encounter?

Kevin Muenzler, WB5RUE
29º14'52"N 98º14'50"W
Eagle Creek Observatory
http://www.eaglecreekobservatory.org
Eagles may soar, but weasels don't get sucked into jet engines. 

Date:  Fri, 21 Dec 2007 06:20:29 -0000
From:  Dave Kodama 
Subject:  Re: 17/P Holmes and Algol

http://www.eanet.com/kodama/astro/2007/17p-holmes/holmespath.jpg

Dave Kodama

Date:  Fri, 21 Dec 2007 07:56:10 -0000
From:  martin_piers_nicholson 
Subject:  Comet 8P Tuttle - December 16th 2007
Comet 8P Tuttle - December 16th 2007

Distance 0.3948 AU (59.1 million km) - magnitude 13.1

Méchain discovered this comet in the evening sky near Omicron Piscium
in January 1790. Several very famous observers, including Charles
Messier and William Herschel, observed the comet over the next three
weeks. 2007/2008 will be a good apparition for this comet and on
January 2nd 2008 it will be within 0.25 AU of Earth. The comet should
then be an easy binocular object.

http://www.martin-nicholson.info/tuttle/tuttle.htm

Martin Nicholson, Daventry, England.
http://www.martin-nicholson.info/1/1a.htm 

Date:  Fri, 21 Dec 2007 14:13:05 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  8P - 2007/12/21
Hello. Bright Moon. 1x1 Bin. Green filter.
Mike H.

http://fototime.com/E271D733B511E77/orig.jpg 

Date:  Fri, 21 Dec 2007 15:41:13 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  8P-2007/12/21/2x2
Hello.
This is info taken last night with a 2x2 bin. I used a Green filter
and cut the exposure to 3x30 so I could stack the stars. I love the
dark nebula and faint nebula the comet sits in. Left full chip size of
the ST10 and 5" TV127is. Moon cause gradients which were removed as
well as I could.
Mike H.

http://fototime.com/2F4459F6B4E023E/orig.jpg

Hello,

A picture of the comet 8P/TUTTLE is on my site: http://napac.free.fr/

Shooting:

Audine Kaf 3200 ME
Alaudine NT
Temperature ext: -1.0 °
Cooling: -25 °
Sigma tele 300 mm F / 4 APO
Time Exposure: 20 x (30 seconds)
Date and time of the shooting: 22 December 2007 18h35mn (Midfielder
Exposure)
Reducing the image 50%.

Stéphane TAKBOU

Observatoire de l'ancienne abbaye

Subject:  8P/Tuttle reworked
Hi all,

I reworked my last 8P/Tuttle images (15/16 December) to get a better registration.

http://www.astropix.nl/images/8P/8P.html

A faint tail pointing east is defenitly visible now. How will the comet look when the Moon is out of the way next week?

Regards,
Albert van Duin

http://www.astropix.nl

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Mon, 24 Dec 2007 13:30:26 +0100
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 8P/Tuttle reworked
> http://www.astropix.nl/images/8P/8P.html

great image!

how do you find yourself with the telescope ASA?
do you have him in fixed or mobile posting? do you have difficulty with the alignment of
the opticses?

if it is ordered, in how much time do they send it?

best regards and Happy Christmas

Rolando 

Date:  Mon, 24 Dec 2007 14:01:00 +0100
From:  Albert van Duin 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 8P/Tuttle reworked
Hello Rolando,

Thanks!

I like the ASA Astrograph very much! I use my ASA at home on a mobile G11
(tripod, not on a pier).
It is almost permanently set up in my observatory but during the holidays I
take it with me to darker skies in the south of France.
There are some pictures of the setup on my webpage.

BTW: In a few weeks I will upgrade to an Italian made 10Micron mount! I'm
looking forward to it!

Collimation is quite easy after some practise, I use CatsEye collimation
tools. You can collimate very precisely with the autocollimation eyepiece.
But the ASA keeps collimation quite well, even after transport in a car.

I don't know how long delivery time is at the moment, mine is over a year
old now.
You can ask Gerald Rehmann gerald.rhemann@astrosysteme.at about this

Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year to all on this list!
http://www.astropix.nl/IC443-Orionid.jpg

Albert van Duin

http://www.astropix.nl

From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  46P December 23, 2007 0019UT

46P December 23, 2007 0019UT

http://www.cometskies.com/images/46P-12242007-0019UT.jpg

46P (Wirtanen)
Time Stamp: 2007 12 24, 0:18:51 UT
Motion: 1.80"/min in PA 52.3°
Focal Length = 2012.6mm, Rotation = 1.01°
Pixel Size: 0.92" x 0.92", Field of View: 23.5' x 15.7'
12 x 33s stacked with Astrometrica
0.3m or 12 inch Meade LX200-GPS @ f/6.3 + SBIG ST-8XME + SBIG AO-7
0046P C2007 12 24.01309 23 12 47.22 -15 41 43.7 14.1 N H47
C. Bell H47 Vicksburg
http://cometskies.com

Date:  Mon, 24 Dec 2007 17:26:52 -0000
From:  martin_piers_nicholson 
Subject:  Comet C/2006 S5 Hill - December 9th 2007
Distance: 1.8057 AU (270.1 million km) - magnitude 13.5

Also of interest is the (as yet unidentified) artificial satellite
which was imaged by accident. Note how the brightness changes during
the 60 second exposure.

http://www.martin-nicholson.info/hill/hill.htm 

Date:  Mon, 24 Dec 2007 17:27:56 -0000
From:  martin_piers_nicholson 
Subject:  Comet 29P Schwassmann-Wachmann - December 9th 2007
Comet 29P Schwassmann-Wachmann - December 9th 2007

Distance 5.0317 AU (752.7 million km) - magnitude 15.3

Comet 29P/Schwassmann-Wachmann, or Schwassmann-Wachmann 1, was
discovered on 15 November 1925 by Arnold Schwassmann and Arno Arthur
Wachmann at the Hamburg Observatory.

The comet is unusual in that while usually around magnitude 16, it
sometimes suddenly brightens to magnitude 12. For this reason the
comet is well worth monitoring on a regular basis by amateur
astronomers.

http://www.martin-nicholson.info/hill/29p.htm

Martin Nicholson, Daventry, England.
http://www.martin-nicholson.info/1/1a.htm 

Date:  Mon, 24 Dec 2007 10:55:48 -0800

Charles Bell

Date:  Tue, 25 Dec 2007 03:52:32 -0500
From:  Takbounorca@aol.com
Subject:  17P/Holmes

Hello,

I just put on my site LRVB an image of the comet 17P/Holmes dated
17/12/2007, I had not had the opportunity to perform the image processing.

Shooting:

Audine Kaf 3200 ME
Alaudine NT
Temperature ext: -4.0 °
Cooling: -25 °
Tele Sigma 300 mm F / 4 APO
Time Exposure: 4 x (3 x 60 second filters RGB CL)
Date and time of the shooting: December 17, 2007 to 18h21mn (Midfielder
Exposure)
Reducing the image 50%.

See here: http://napac.free.fr/

Happy birthday, Christmas

Stéphane TAKBOU

Observatoire de l'ancienne abbaye
MPC A11
N 50°52'48"
E 02°28'18"
Altitude 16 m
Wormhout
France
http://napac.free.fr/

Date:  Tue, 25 Dec 2007 23:26:56 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: 8P-20071225
Thanks Rolando. No I haven't done any measurments. I will say that on
some lum images I took last night the coma around the false nuk was
elongated and I was seeing faint tail arching to the E/NE of probably
20 to 25 deg. Really faint and I hope to pick this up tonight as I am
heading out to image now. Cheers!
Mike H.

Date:  Tue, 25 Dec 2007 20:15:33 -0500
From:  Takbounorca@aol.com
Subject:  17P and Moon

Hi,

No new image of 17P/Holmes but just an image of the moon conducted tonight
with the same optical configuration as that used for photographing the comet
..
A montage of two images used to evaluate the size of the coma of the comet.

See here _http://napac.free.fr/_ (http://napac.free.fr/)

E 02°28'18"

Date:  Wed, 26 Dec 2007 03:26:10 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  8P-20071226
Hello.
This was not much of a picture but it was to show the very faint tail
I saw. Some of the faster scopes will probably bring this out better.
2x2 bin using 10x60 second images with a median combine. about 1.2 deg
across the image from W to E on the left with N up.
Thanks, Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/D0606CFCE405FC7/orig.jpg

Date:  Wed, 26 Dec 2007 13:08:13 -0800
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  8P December 26, 2007 0121UT
8P December 26, 2007 0121UT

http://www.cometskies.com/images/8P-12262007-0121UT.jpg

Its moving fast at 8+ arc secs/minute

Used 12 sec frames with ST-8XME CCD, stacked with Astrometrica, log stretched with FITS Liberator into PhotoshopCS2 with Levels adjustment.

---------------------------------
Never miss a thing. Make Yahoo your homepage.

Date:  Thu, 27 Dec 2007 01:53:27 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  17p-20071226-4x
Hello
I post this even though gradients from the Moon did not allow a smooth
image. The small cluster in the left lower part is NGC 1193 magnitude
12.6 and is 1.42 deg from the center of 17P. This is a 4 frame image
with each frame having 3x60 sub-frames. Hope you like it.
Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/9B71BD0AB9A3C93/standard.jpg

http://www.fototime.com/9B71BD0AB9A3C93/orig.jpg 

Date:  Thu, 27 Dec 2007 09:46:29 -0000
From:  martin_piers_nicholson 
Subject:  Comet 8P Tuttle - December 27th 2007
Comet 8P Tuttle - December 27th 2007

Distance 0.2742 AU (41.0 million km) - magnitude 6.5. The exposure was
15 seconds and the field of view is 15 x 15 arc minutes - note how far
the comet moves in just 25 minutes!

http://www.martin-nicholson.info/tuttle/tuttle2.htm

Martin Nicholson, Daventry, England.
http://www.martin-nicholson.info/1/1a.htm

Date:  Fri, 28 Dec 2007 08:20:12 +0100
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: 2 comets, 2 galaxies, 2 open cluster...
>a very nice shot rolando. do you work with f-50mm and
> the sxv-h25?
> michael

>Very nice! I like the contrast between the two comets.
>What are the equipment and exposure parameters for the shot?
>Dave Kodama

Hi Michael, Hi Dave.

you are right, I have forgotten to write the used setup,
in practice I have used an old lens canon FD from 50mm f1,8s closed to f4
and like ccd the SXVM25C.
I hoped that closing of 1-2 stops I would have reduced the problem of the coma...
the stars hear again some problem instead.
this morning with more calm I try to improve the quality of the color, have too quickly
elaborated last night the images and is seen! ;-)))

best regards
Rolando

Date:  Sat, 29 Dec 2007 01:33:34 +0100
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  8P/Tuttle: 27/28 - Dec. 2007
Dear All,

I have a couple of images of this comet to share. Details
are on the same pictures.

-
http://virtualtelescope.bellatrixobservatory.org/8p_27dec07.jpg

The next image is from Dec. 28: the tail is clearly visible:

-
http://virtualtelescope.bellatrixobservatory.org/8p_28dec07.jpg

Note: I used the paramount ME tracking feature and it worked
great, also assuming the high-res of the images
(0.58"/pixel). It looks like a movie is worth to be done :)

Cheers,
Gianluca 

Date:  Sat, 29 Dec 2007 02:15:49 +0100
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  [Comet-Images] 8P: possible structures?
Dear all,

processing some of the my latest frames with the LS
rotational gradient, I see a possible structure W of the
false nucleus.

The processed image is here:

http://virtualtelescope.bellatrixobservatory.org/8p_28dec07_ls.jpg

regards,
Gianluca

Date:  Sat, 29 Dec 2007 03:44:21 +0100
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 8P: possible structures?
Hi Charles,

thanks for your comments. Yes, I'm pretty sure that
structure is real. I managed to process also my 27 Dec.
images with the same technique, getting this result:

http://virtualtelescope.bellatrixobservatory.org/8p_27dec07_ls.jpg

The same features were visible, possibly fainter (but the
Moon impact yesterday was stronger).

Regards,
Gianluca

Date:  Sat, 29 Dec 2007 08:56:37 +0100
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 8P: possible structures?
> thanks for your comments. Yes, I'm pretty sure that
> structure is real. I managed to process also my 27 Dec.
> images with the same technique, getting this result:
> http://virtualtelescope.bellatrixobservatory.org/8p_27dec07_ls.jpg
> The same features were visible, possibly fainter (but the
> Moon impact yesterday was stronger).
> Regards,
> Gianluca

I confirm the observation of Gianluca.
In the two last nights,

http://comete.uai.it/8p/8P_071227.jpg
http://comete.uai.it/8p/8P_071228.jpg

a strong structure is seen (jet?) to PA 220 (on 27/12) and PA 280 (on 28/12)
in this last image a strange arc is noticed to also depart from the false nucleus,
but I would not like that she was created by the filter LS.

however, from some days the image of the forgery nucleus appears lengthened,
show of strong activity.

regards
Rolando Ligustri
===============================
C.A.R.A. http://cara.uai.it
CAST: Circolo AStrofili Talmassons
www.castfvg.it/fotoccd.htm#comete 

Date:  Sat, 29 Dec 2007 12:22:11 +0100
From:  Danilo Pivato 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] exposure time
Hi Eric,

in the new images of yesterday:
http://www.danilopivato.com/solar_system/comets/8p_tuttle/2007.12.28_contr.htm
http://www.danilopivato.com/solar_system/comets/8p_tuttle/2007.12.28.htm
I have used the exposure time of 6 x 300 seconds and the equiment
Flat Field Camera 760/4 + ccd St-10XME.
Regards

Danilo Pivato

group.

Date:  Sat, 29 Dec 2007 21:58:09 +0100
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 8P: possible structures?
Dear All,

new images from tonight still show the structures I
announced yesterday:

http://virtualtelescope.bellatrixobservatory.org/8p_29dec07_ls.jpg

Tonight, seeing was very good, ranging from 1.5" to 2".

Cheers,
Gianluca 

Date:  Sat, 29 Dec 2007 13:31:53 -0800
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 8P: possible structures?
Yes, the tail extending to the east ~PA 70 to 80 degress is showing much more fuller in recent images posted. I could just barely make it out in my first image of it from Dec 26.

8P seems to me more exciting than 17P.

I am not set up for wide field.

Gianluca Masi wrote:
Hi Charles,

thanks for your comments. Yes, I'm pretty sure that
structure is real. I managed to process also my 27 Dec.
images with the same technique, getting this result:

http://virtualtelescope.bellatrixobservatory.org/8p_27dec07_ls.jpg

The same features were visible, possibly fainter (but the
Moon impact yesterday was stronger).

Regards,
Gianluca

2007-12-29 mag 13.78

COD 213
OBS R. Naves
CATALOGO: USNO A2.0 - BANDA: R

Date:  Mon, 31 Dec 2007 03:53:07 +0100
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  8P: 29 Dec. 2007
Dear All,

here it is another Hi-Res image of this comet:

http://virtualtelescope.bellatrixobservatory.org/8p_29dec07.jpg

Details on the same picture.

I managed to create an image median combining all the
available frames and used it to perform a LS rotational
gradient, getting this result:

http://virtualtelescope.bellatrixobservatory.org/8p_29dec07_ls.jpg

The structure I reported on Dec. 28 is still very evident.

Happy New Year!

Gianluca/*Italy

Date:  Mon, 31 Dec 2007 15:56:22 +0100
From:  Emiel Kempen 
Subject:  8P/Tuttle passing M33
Hello group,

Last night I have been imaging comet 8P/Tuttle passing M33.

The resulting images can be found on my website:

www.ekempen.com

This is a direct link to the page:
http://www.ekempen.com/en/galerij/astronomie/8P-Tuttle/8p-tuttle.html

Kind regards,

Emiel Kempen.

Date:  Mon, 31 Dec 2007 16:44:03 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  8P-M33-2007/12/31 UT
Hello. Comet moving so fast. Started to gather information on the M33
area ahead of time but this time of year weather screws up and colors
change. All information was taken last night. 1x1 bin and croped.
Thanks, Mike H.

http://fototime.com/234B1860DFC20EC/orig.jpg

Date:  Mon, 31 Dec 2007 18:36:45 +0100
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  8P: 29 Dec. 2007
Hello everybody

here you can see my 29 Dec. image, grabbed under very good
seeing conditions:

http://virtualtelescope.bellatrixobservatory.org/8p_29dec07.jpg

Also, the LS gradient shows very well the features I
initially spotted on Dec. 28 (but visible on my 27 Dec.
images too):

http://virtualtelescope.bellatrixobservatory.org/8p_29dec07_ls.jpg

Happy New Year!
Gianluca
